<EOS>

<EOS>

Ainsworth
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Sir
Jeffery_.--Is
<EOS>
there
a
justice
in
Lancashire
have
so
much
    
skill
in
witch
as
I
have
?
<EOS>
nay
,
I
will
speak
a
proud
word
;
you
    
shall
turn
me
loose
against
any
Witch
-
finder
in
Europe
.
<EOS>
I
would
    
make
an
ass
of
Hopkins
if
he
be
alive.--shadwell
.
  
<EOS>
Third
Edition
.
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

.

1854
.
  
<EOS>
to

Crossley
,

.
,
(
of

,
)
 
President
of

,
and

of
"
the

of

in

Lancaster,"--
 
<EOS>
the
groundwork
of
the
following
pages,--
<EOS>
this
Romance
,
undertake
at
his
suggestion
,
be
inscribe
by
his
old
,
and
sincerely
attach
friend
,
the
Author
.

<EOS>
LANCASTER
CASTLE
    
INTRODUCTION
.
 
<EOS>
the
last
Abbot
of
Whalley
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
i.--the
BEACON
on
PENDLE
HILL
.
  
<EOS>
there
be
eight
watcher
by
the
beacon
on
Pendle
Hill
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
two
be
station
on
either
side
of
the
north
-
eastern
extremity
of
the
mountain
.
<EOS>
one
look
over
the
castled
height
of
Clithero
;
the
woody
eminence
of
Bowland
;
the
bleak
ridge
of
Thornley
;
the
broad
moor
of
Bleasdale
;
the
Trough
of
Bolland
,
and
Wolf
Crag
;
and
even
bring
within
his
ken
the
black
fell
overhang
Lancaster
.
<EOS>
the
other
track
the
stream
call
Pendle
Water
,
almost
from
its
source
amid
the
neighbouring
hill
,
and
follow
its
winding
through
the
leafless
forest
,
until
it
unite
its
water
to
those
of
the
Calder
,
and
sweep
on
in
swift
and
clear
current
,
to
wash
the
base
of
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
but
the
watcher
's
survey
do
not
stop
here
.
<EOS>
note
the
sharp
spire
of
Burnley
Church
,
relieve
against
the
rounded
masse
of
timber
constitute
Townley
Park
;
as
well
as
the
entrance
of
the
gloomy
mountain
gorge
,
know
as
the
Grange
of
Cliviger
;
his
far
-
reach
gaze
pass
over
Todmorden
,
and
settle
upon
the
distant
summit
of
Blackstone
Edge
.
 
<EOS>
Dreary
be
the
prospect
on
all
side
.
<EOS>
black
moor
,
bleak
fall
,
straggle
forest
,
intersect
with
sullen
stream
as
black
as
ink
,
with
here
and
there
a
small
tarn
,
or
moss
-
pool
,
with
water
of
the
same
hue
--
<EOS>
these
constitute
the
chief
feature
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
the
whole
district
be
barren
and
thinly
-
populated
.
<EOS>
of
town
,
only
Clithero
,
Colne
,
and
Burnley
--
the
latter
little
more
than
a
village
--
be
in
view
.
<EOS>
in
the
valley
there
be
a
few
hamlet
and
scatter
cottage
,
and
on
the
upland
an
occasional
"
booth
,
"
as
the
hut
of
the
herdsman
be
term
;
but
of
more
important
mansion
there
be
only
six
,
as
Merley
,
Twistleton
,
Alcancoats
,
Saxfeld
,
Ightenhill
,
and
Gawthorpe
.
<EOS>
the
"
vaccarie
"
for
the
cattle
,
of
which
the
herdsman
have
the
care
,
and
the
"
lawnd
,
"
or
park
within
the
forest
,
appertain
to
some
of
the
hall
before
mention
,
offer
the
only
evidence
of
cultivation
.
<EOS>
all
else
be
heathy
waste
,
morass
,
and
wood
.
 
<EOS>
still
,
in
the
eye
of
the
sportsman
--
and
the
Lancashire
gentleman
of
the
sixteenth
century
be
keen
lover
of
sport
--
the
country
have
a
strong
interest
.
<EOS>
pendle
forest
abound
with
game
.
<EOS>
grouse
,
plover
,
and
bittern
be
find
upon
its
moor
;
woodcock
and
snipe
on
its
marsh
;
mallard
,
teal
,
and
widgeon
upon
its
pool
.
<EOS>
in
its
chase
range
herd
of
deer
,
protect
by
the
terrible
forest
-
law
,
then
in
full
force
:
and
the
hardier
huntsman
may
follow
the
wolf
to
his
lair
in
the
mountain
;
may
spear
the
boar
in
the
oaken
glade
,
or
the
otter
on
the
river
's
brink
;
may
unearth
the
badger
or
the
fox
,
or
smite
the
fierce
cat
-
a
-
mountain
with
a
quarrel
from
his
bow
.
<EOS>
a
noble
victim
sometimes
,
also
,
await
him
in
the
shape
of
a
wild
mountain
bull
,
a
denizen
of
the
forest
,
and
a
remnant
of
the
herd
that
have
once
browse
upon
the
hill
,
but
which
have
almost
all
be
capture
,
and
remove
to
stock
the
park
of
the
Abbot
of
Whalley
.
<EOS>
the
stream
and
pool
be
full
of
fish
:
the
stately
heron
frequent
the
mere
;
and
on
the
craggy
height
build
the
kite
,
the
falcon
,
and
the
kingly
eagle
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
eight
watcher
by
the
beacon
.
<EOS>
two
stand
apart
from
the
other
,
look
to
the
right
and
the
left
of
the
hill
.
<EOS>
both
be
arm
with
sword
and
arquebus
,
and
wear
steel
cap
and
coat
of
buff
.
<EOS>
Their
sleeve
be
embroider
with
the
five
wound
of
Christ
,
encircle
the
name
of
Jesus
--
the
badge
of
the
Pilgrimage
of
Grace
.
<EOS>
between
them
,
on
the
verge
of
the
mountain
,
be
plant
a
great
banner
,
display
a
silver
cross
,
the
chalice
,
and
the
host
,
together
with
an
ecclesiastical
figure
,
but
wear
a
helmet
instead
of
a
mitre
,
and
hold
a
sword
in
place
of
a
crosier
,
with
the
unoccupied
hand
point
to
the
two
tower
of
a
monastic
structure
,
as
if
to
intimate
that
he
be
armed
for
its
defence
.
<EOS>
this
figure
,
as
the
device
beneath
it
show
,
represent
John
Paslew
,
Abbot
of
Whalley
,
or
,
as
he
style
himself
in
his
military
capacity
,
Earl
of
Poverty
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
eight
watcher
by
the
beacon
.
<EOS>
two
have
be
describe
.
<EOS>
of
the
other
six
,
two
be
stout
herdsman
carry
crook
,
and
hold
a
couple
of
mule
,
and
a
richly
-
caparison
war
-
horse
by
the
bridle
.
<EOS>
near
them
stand
a
broad
-
shouldered
,
athletic
young
man
,
with
the
fresh
complexion
,
curl
brown
hair
,
light
eye
,
and
open
Saxon
countenance
,
best
see
in
his
native
county
of
Lancaster
.
<EOS>
He
wear
a
lincoln
-
green
tunic
,
with
a
bugle
suspend
from
the
shoulder
by
a
silken
cord
;
and
a
silver
plate
engrave
with
the
three
luce
,
the
ensign
of
the
Abbot
of
Whalley
,
hang
by
a
chain
from
his
neck
.
<EOS>
a
hunting
knife
be
in
his
girdle
,
and
an
eagle
's
plume
in
his
cap
,
and
he
lean
upon
the
but
-
end
of
a
crossbow
,
regard
three
person
who
stand
together
by
a
peat
fire
,
on
the
sheltered
side
of
the
beacon
.
<EOS>
two
of
these
be
elderly
man
,
in
the
white
gown
and
scapulary
of
cistertian
monk
,
doubtless
from
Whalley
,
as
the
abbey
belong
to
that
order
.
<EOS>
the
third
and
last
,
and
evidently
their
superior
,
be
a
tall
man
in
a
riding
dress
,
wrap
in
a
long
mantle
of
black
velvet
,
trim
with
minever
,
and
display
the
same
badge
as
those
upon
the
sleeve
of
the
sentinel
,
only
work
in
rich
material
.
<EOS>
His
feature
be
strongly
marked
and
stern
,
and
bore
trace
of
age
;
but
his
eye
be
bright
,
and
his
carriage
erect
and
dignified
.
 
<EOS>
the
beacon
,
near
which
the
watcher
stand
,
consist
of
a
vast
pile
of
log
of
timber
,
heap
upon
a
circular
range
of
stone
,
with
opening
to
admit
air
,
and
have
the
centre
fill
with
fagot
,
and
other
quickly
combustible
material
.
<EOS>
torch
be
place
near
at
hand
,
so
that
the
pile
could
be
light
on
the
instant
.
 
<EOS>
the
watch
be
hold
one
afternoon
at
the
latter
end
of
November
,
1536
.
<EOS>
in
that
year
have
arise
a
formidable
rebellion
in
the
northern
county
of
England
,
the
member
of
which
,
while
engage
to
respect
the
person
of
the
king
,
Henry
VIII
.
,
and
his
issue
,
bind
themselves
by
solemn
oath
to
accomplish
the
restoration
of
Papal
supremacy
throughout
the
realm
,
and
the
restitution
of
religious
establishment
and
land
to
their
late
eject
possessor
.
<EOS>
They
bind
themselves
,
also
,
to
punish
the
enemy
of
the
romish
church
,
and
suppress
heresy
.
<EOS>
from
its
religious
character
the
insurrection
assume
the
name
of
the
Pilgrimage
of
Grace
,
and
number
among
its
adherent
all
who
have
not
embrace
the
new
doctrine
in
Yorkshire
and
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
that
such
an
outbreak
should
occur
on
the
suppression
of
the
monastery
,
be
not
marvellous
.
<EOS>
the
desecration
and
spoliation
of
so
many
sacred
structure
--
the
destruction
of
shrine
and
image
long
regard
with
veneration
--
the
ejection
of
so
many
ecclesiastic
,
renowne
for
hospitality
and
revere
for
piety
and
learning
--
the
violence
and
rapacity
of
the
commissioner
appoint
by
the
Vicar
-
General
Cromwell
to
carry
out
these
severe
measure
--
all
these
outrage
be
regard
by
the
people
with
abhorrence
,
and
dispose
them
to
aid
the
sufferer
in
resistance
.
<EOS>
as
yet
the
wealthy
monastery
in
the
north
have
be
spare
,
and
it
be
to
preserve
them
from
the
greedy
hand
of
the
visiter
,
Doctors
Lee
and
Layton
,
that
the
insurrection
have
be
undertake
.
<EOS>
a
simultaneous
rise
take
place
in
Lincolnshire
,
head
by
Makarel
,
Abbot
of
Barlings
,
but
it
be
speedily
quell
by
the
vigour
and
skill
of
the
Duke
of
Suffolk
,
and
its
leader
execute
.
<EOS>
but
the
northern
outbreak
be
better
organize
,
and
of
great
force
,
for
it
now
number
thirty
thousand
man
,
under
the
command
of
a
skilful
and
resolute
leader
name
Robert
Aske
.
 
<EOS>
as
may
be
suppose
,
the
priesthood
be
main
mover
in
a
revolt
have
their
especial
benefit
for
its
aim
;
and
many
of
them
,
follow
the
example
of
the
Abbot
of
Barlings
,
clothe

in

,
and

on
the
sword
and
the

for
the
redress
of

and

.
<EOS>
amongst
these
be
the
abbot
of
Jervaux
,

,

,

,
and

,
and

,

of
Whalley
,
before
mention
;
a

,
who
have

of
the
king
.
<EOS>
such
be
the
Pilgrimage
of
Grace
,
such

design
,
and
such

.
 
<EOS>
several
large

have

.
<EOS>
York
,
Hull
,
and

have
yield
;

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
term
be
next

.
 
<EOS>

;

to
be

.
<EOS>
this

the
eight

expect
.
 
<EOS>
though

,

,

"

"

?

?

impossible

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

.

talk
<EOS>
it
be
not
like

,

;

be

.
"

,

.

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,

,
          
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

;
"
<EOS>
but

,

have

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
          
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>
loud

.
 
<EOS>
"
by

of

,
the

be

,
"

;
"
send

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
the

,

the

;
but

be

take
,

.
<EOS>
the

laugh

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
this

before

,

.
<EOS>
but
what
be

stop
--
ha
!
<EOS>
he
be

on

's

.
"
 
<EOS>
It
would
seem
that
the
abbot
have

,
as

,
have

,
be

trace

.
<EOS>
He
then
speak

,

,
and
after
trace

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"
for

.
"
 
<EOS>
Ashbead

,
and
on

,

that

;

,

,

,

--

--
would
"
brast
.
"
<EOS>

,

to

.
<EOS>
the

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ere

,

,

as

,

in

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
the
signal
!
<EOS>
the

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be

on

,
"

;
"

!
<EOS>
a

--
another

--

<EOS>
Our

come

.
<EOS>

!
"
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

!
"
 
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
"
<EOS>

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Ill
_

<EOS>

,

.

.

.

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
now

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
 
"

,

.
<EOS>

.

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
nay
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
lose
!
"

,

.
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
twenty

be

--
ay
,

,

thou

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
what

,

?

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
the

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
ha
!
"

,
"
let

,

.
<EOS>
but

,

.
<EOS>
Thou

.
<EOS>
Whence
gott'st

thine

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
heed

,
"

;
"
thou

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

this

,

,

--

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell

thou
liest
,

!
"
<EOS>
cry

abbot
,
strike

on

.
"
<EOS>
Quit

hold
,
and
let

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
not
till

have
do
,
"
reply

,
maintain

.
<EOS>
"
well

style
thyself
Earl
of
Poverty
,
for
thou
art
poor
and
miserable
enough
.
<EOS>
Abbot
of
Whalley
thou
art
no
longer
.
<EOS>
thy
possession
will
be
take
from
thee
,
and
if
thou
returnest
thy
life
also
will
be
take
.
<EOS>
if
thou
fleest
,
a
price
will
be
set
upon
thy
head
.
<EOS>
I
alone
can
save
thee
,
and
I
will
do
so
on
one
condition
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
condition
!
<EOS>
make
condition
with
thee
,
bond
-
slave
of
Satan
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
abbot
,
gnash
his

.
<EOS>
"
I
reproach
myself
that
I
have
listen
to
thee
so
long
.
<EOS>
stand
aside
,
or
I
will
strike
thee
dead
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
be
wholly
in
my
power
,
"
cry
Demdike
with
a
disdainful
laugh
.
<EOS>
and
as
he
speak
he
press
the
large
sharp
bit
against
the
charger
's
mouth
,
and
back
him
quickly
to
the
very
edge
of
the
hill
,
the
side
of
which
here
slope
precipitously
down
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
would
have
utter
a
cry
,
but
surprise
and
terror
keep
him
silent
.
 
<EOS>
"
be
it
my
desire
to
injure
you
,
I
could
cast
you
down
the
mountain
-
side
to
certain
death
,
"
pursue
demdike
.
<EOS>
"
but
I
have
no
such
wish
.
<EOS>
on
the
contrary
,
I
will
serve
you
,
as
I
have
say
,
on
one
condition
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
thy
condition
would
imperil
my
soul
,
"
say
the
abbot
,
full
of
wrath
and
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thou
seekest
in
vain
to
terrify
me
into
compliance
.
<EOS>
_
Vade
retro
,
Sathanas
_
.
<EOS>
I
defy
thee
and
all
thy
work
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Demdike
laugh
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
thunder
of
the
Church
do
not
frighten
me
,
"
he
cry
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
but
,
look
,
"
he
add
,
"
you
doubt
my
word
when
I
tell
you
the
rise
be
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
the
beacon
fire
on
Boulsworth
Hill
and
on
the
Grange
of
Cliviger
be
extinguish
;
that
on
Padiham
Heights
be
expire
--
<EOS>
nay
,
it
be
out
;
and
ere
many
minute
<EOS>
all
these
mountain
watch
-
fire
will
have
disappear
like
lamp
at
the
close
of
a
feast
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
by
our
Lady
,
it
be
so
,
"
cry
the
abbot
,
in
increase
terror
.
<EOS>
"
what
new
jugglery
be
this
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
no
jugglery
,
I
tell
you
,
"
reply
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
water
of
the
Don
have
again
arise
;
the
insurgent
have
accept
the
king
's
pardon
,
have
desert
their
leader
,
and
disperse
.
<EOS>
there
will
be
no
rise
to
-
night
or
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
of
Jervaux
and
Salley
will
strive
to
capitulate
,
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
the
Pilgrimage
of
Grace
be
end
.
<EOS>
the
stake
for
which
thou
playedst
be
lose
.
<EOS>
thirty
year
hast
thou
govern
here
,
but
thy
rule
be
over
.
<EOS>
seventeen
abbot
have
there
be
of
Whalley
--
the
last
thou!--but
there
shall
be
none
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
the
Demon
in
person
that
speak
thus
to
me
,
"
cry
the
abbot
,
his
hair
bristle
on
his
head
,
and
a
cold
perspiration
burst
from
his
pore
.
 
<EOS>
"
no
matter
who
I
be
,
"
reply
the
other
;
"
I
have
say
I
will
aid
thee
on
one
condition
.
<EOS>
It
be
not
much
.
<EOS>
remove
thy
ban
from
my
wife
,
and
baptise
her
infant
daughter
,
and
I
be
content
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
ask
thee
for
this
service
,
slight
though
it
be
,
but
the
poor
soul
hath
set
her
mind
upon
it
.
<EOS>
wilt
thou
do
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
"
reply
the
abbot
,
shudder
;
"
I
will
not
baptise
a
daughter
of
Satan
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
sell
my
soul
to
the
power
of
darkness
.
<EOS>
I
adjure
thee
to
depart
from
me
,
and
tempt
me
no
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
vainly
thou
seekest
to
cast
me
off
,
"
rejoin
demdike
.
<EOS>
"
what
if
I
deliver
thine
adversary
into
thine
hand
,
and
revenge
thee
upon
them
?
<EOS>
even
now
there
be
a
party
of
armed
man
wait
at
the
foot
of
the
hill
to
seize
thee
and
thy
brother
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
show
thee
how
to
destroy
them
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
who
be
they
?
<EOS>
"
demand
the
abbot
,
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
"
Their
leader
be
John
Braddyll
and
Richard
Assheton
,
who
shall
divide
Whalley
Abbey
between
them
,
if
thou
stay
them
not
,
"
reply
Demdike
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hell
consume
them
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thy
speech
show
consent
,
"
rejoin
demdike
.
<EOS>
"
come
this
way
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
,
without
await
the
abbot
's
reply
,
he
drag
his
horse
towards
the
but
-
end
of
the
mountain
.
<EOS>
as
they
go
on
,
the
two
monk
,
who
have
be
fill
with
surprise
at
the
interview
,
though
they
do
not
dare
to
interrupt
it
,
advanced
towards
their
superior
,
and
look
earnestly
and
inquiringly
at
him
,
but
he
remain
silent
;
while
to
the
man
-
at
-
arm
and
the
herdsman
,
who
demand
whether
their
own
beacon
-
fire
should
be
extinguish
as
the
other
have
be
,
he
answer
moodily
in
the
negative
.
 
<EOS>
"
where
be
the
foe
you
speak
of
?
"
he
ask
with
some
uneasiness
,
as
Demdike
lead
his
horse
slowly
and
carefully
down
the
hill
-
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
see
anon
,
"
reply
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
be
take
me
to
the
spot
where
you
trace
the
magic
circle
,
"
cry
Paslew
in
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
from
its
unnaturally
green
hue
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
go
thither
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
mean
you
should
,
lord
abbot
,
"
reply
Demdike
,
halting
.
<EOS>
"
remain
on
this
firm
ground
.
<EOS>
nay
,
be
not
alarm
;
you
be
in
no
danger
.
<EOS>
now
bid
your
man
advance
,
and
prepare
their
weapon
.
"
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
would
have
demand
wherefore
,
but
at
a
glance
from
Demdike
he
comply
,
and
the
two
man
-
at
-
arm
,
and
the
herdsman
,
arrange
themselves
beside
him
,
while
father
Eastgate
and
Haydocke
,
who
have
get
upon
their
mule
,
take
up
a
position
behind
.
 
<EOS>
scarcely
be
they
thus
place
,
when
a
loud
shout
be
raise
below
,
and
a
band
of
armed
man
,
to
the
number
of
thirty
or
forty
,
leapt
the
stone
wall
,
and
begin
to
scale
the
hill
with
great
rapidity
.
<EOS>
They
come
up
a
deep
dry
channel
,
apparently
wear
in
the
hill
-
side
by
some
former
torrent
,
and
which
lead
directly
to
the
spot
where
Demdike
and
the
abbot
stand
.
<EOS>
the
beacon
-
fire
still
blaze
brightly
,
and
illuminate
the
whole
proceeding
,
show
that
these
man
,
from
their
accoutrement
,
be
royalist
soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
stir
not
,
as
you
value
your
life
,
"
say
the
wizard
to
Paslew
;
"
but
observe
what
shall
follow
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II.--THE
ERUPTION
.
  
<EOS>
Demdike
go
a
little
further
down
the
hill
,
stop
when
he
come
to
the
green
patch
.
<EOS>
He
then
plunge
his
staff
into
the
sod
at
the
first
point
where
he
have
cast
a
tuft
of
heather
,
and
with
such
force
that
it
sink
more
than
three
foot
.
<EOS>
the
next
moment
he
pluck
it
forth
,
as
if
with
a
great
effort
,
and
a
jet
of
black
water
spout
into
the
air
;
but
,
heedless
of
this
,
he
go
to
the
next
marked
spot
,
and
again
plunge
the
sharp
point
of
the
implement
into
the
ground
.
<EOS>
again
it
sink
to
the
same
depth
,
and
,
on
be
draw
out
,
a
second
black
jet
spring
forth
.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
the
hostile
party
continue
to
advance
up
the
dry
channel
before
mention
,
and
shout
on
behold
these
strange
preparation
,
but
they
do
not
relax
their
speed
.
<EOS>
once
more
the
staff
sink
into
the
ground
,
and
a
third
black
fountain
follow
its
extraction
.
<EOS>
by
this
time
,
the
royalist
soldier
be
close
at
hand
,
and
the
feature
of
their
two
leader
,
John
Braddyll
and
Richard
Assheton
,
could
be
plainly
distinguished
,
and
their
voice
hear
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Tis
he
!
'
<EOS>
tis
the
rebel
abbot
!
"
<EOS>
vociferate
Braddyll
,
press
forward
.
<EOS>
"
We
be
not
misinform
.
<EOS>
He
have
be
watch
by
the
beacon
.
<EOS>
the
devil
have
deliver
him
into
our
hand
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
ho
!
"
<EOS>
laugh
Demdike
.
 
<EOS>
"
abbot
no
longer--'tis
the
Earl
of
poverty
<EOS>
you
mean
,
"
respond
Assheton
.
<EOS>
"
the
villain
shall
be
gibbet
on
the
spot
where
he
have
fire
the
beacon
,
as
a
warning
to
all
traitor
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
ha
,
heretics!--ha
,
blasphemers!--I
can
at
least
avenge
myself
upon
you
,
"
cry
Paslew
,
strike
spur
into
his
charger
.
<EOS>
but
ere
he
could
execute
his
purpose
,
Demdike
have
spring
backward
,
and
,
catch
the
bridle
,
restrain
the
animal
by
a
powerful
effort
.
 
<EOS>
"
hold
!
"
<EOS>
he
cry
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
"
or
you
will
share
their
fate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
as
the
word
be
utter
,
a
dull
,
booming
,
subterranean
sound
be
hear
,
and
instantly
afterwards
,
with
a
crash
like
thunder
,
the
whole
of
the
green
circle
beneath
slip
off
,
and
from
a
yawning
rent
under
it
burst
forth
with
irresistible
fury
,
a
thick
inky
-
coloured
torrent
,
which
,
rise
almost
breast
high
,
fall
upon
the
devoted
royalist
soldier
,
who
be
advance
right
in
its
course
.
<EOS>
unable
to
avoid
the
watery
eruption
,
or
to
resist
its
fury
when
it
come
upon
them
,
they
be
instantly
sweep
from
their
foot
,
and
carry
down
the
channel
.
 
<EOS>
a
sight
of
horror
be
it
to
behold
the
sudden
rise
of
that
swarthy
stream
,
whose
water
,
tinge
by
the
ruddy
glare
of
the
beacon
-
fire
,
look
like
wave
of
blood
.
<EOS>
nor
less
fearful
be
it
to
hear
the
first
wild
despairing
cry
raise
by
the
victim
,
or
the
quickly
stifle
shriek
and
groan
that
follow
,
mix
with
the
deafening
roar
of
the
stream
,
and
the
crash
fall
of
the
stone
,
which
accompany
its
course
.
<EOS>
down
,
down
go
the
poor
wretch
,
now
utterly
overwhelm
by
the
torrent
,
now
regain
their
foot
only
to
utter
a
scream
,
and
then
be
sweep
off
.
<EOS>
here
a
miserable
struggler
,
whirl
onward
,
would
clutch
at
the
bank
and
try
to
scramble
forth
,
but
the
soft
turf
give
way
beneath
him
,
he
be
hurry
off
to
eternity
.
 
<EOS>
at
another
point
where
the
stream
encounter
some
trifling
opposition
,
some
two
or
three
manage
to
gain
a
footing
,
but
they
be
unable
to
extricate
themselves
.
<EOS>
the
vast
quantity
of
boggy
soil
bring
down
by
the
current
,
and
which
rapidly
collect
here
,
embed
them
and
hold
them
fast
,
so
that
the
momently
deepening
water
,
already
up
to
their
chin
,
threaten
speedy
immersion
.
<EOS>
other
be
stricken
down
by
great
masse
of
turf
,
or
huge
rocky
fragment
,
which
,
bound
from
point
to
point
with
the
torrent
,
bruise
or
crush
all
they
encounter
,
or
,
lodge
in
some
difficult
place
,
slightly
divert
the
course
of
the
torrent
,
and
render
it
yet
more
dangerous
.
 
<EOS>
on
one
of
these
stone
,
large
than
the
rest
,
which
have
be
stop
in
its
course
,
a
man
contrive
to
creep
,
and
with
difficulty
keep
his
post
amid
the
rage
flood
.
<EOS>
vainly
do
he
extend
his
hand
to
such
of
his
fellow
as
be
sweep
shriek
past
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
lend
them
aid
,
while
his
own
position
be
so
desperately
hazardous
that
he
do
not
dare
to
quit
it
.
<EOS>
to
leap
on
either
bank
be
impossible
,
and
to
breast
the
headlong
stream
certain
death
.
 
<EOS>
on
go
the
current
,
madly
,
furiously
,
as
if
rejoice
in
the
work
of
destruction
,
while
the
white
foam
of
its
eddy
present
a
fearful
contrast
to
the
prevail
blackness
of
the
surface
.
<EOS>
over
the
last
declivity
it
leap
,
hiss
,
foam
,
crash
like
an
avalanche
.
<EOS>
the
stone
wall
for
a
moment
oppose
its
force
,
but
fall
the
next
,
with
a
mighty
splash
,
carry
the
spray
far
and
wide
,
while
its
own
fragment
roll
onwards
with
the
stream
.
<EOS>
the
tree
of
the
orchard
be
uproot
in
an
instant
,
and
an
old
elm
fall
prostrate
.
<EOS>
the
outbuilding
of
a
cottage
be
invade
,
and
the
porker
and
cattle
,
divine
their
danger
,
squeal
and
bellow
in
affright
.
<EOS>
but
they
be
quickly
silence
.
<EOS>
the
resistless
foe
have
break
down
wall
and
door
,
and
bury
the
poor
creature
in
mud
and
rubbish
.
 
<EOS>
the
stream
next
invade
the
cottage
,
break
in
through
door
and
window
,
and
fill
all
the
low
part
of
the
tenement
,
in
a
few
minute
convert
it
into
a
heap
of
ruin
.
<EOS>
on
go
the
destroyer
,
tear
up
more
tree
,
level
more
house
,
and
fill
up
a
small
pool
,
till
the
latter
burst
its
bank
,
and
,
with
an
accession
to
its
force
,
pour
itself
into
a
mill
-
dam
.
<EOS>
here
its
water
be
stay
until
they
find
a
vent
underneath
,
and
the
action
of
the
stream
,
as
it
rush
downward
through
this
exit
,
form
a
great
eddy
above
,
in
which
swim
some
live
thing
,
cattle
and
sheep
from
the
fold
not
yet
drown
,
mix
with
furniture
from
the
cottage
,
and
amidst
them
the
body
of
some
of
the
unfortunate
man
-
at
-
arm
which
have
be
wash
hither
.
 
<EOS>
but
,
ha
!
<EOS>
another
thundering
crash
.
<EOS>
the
dam
have
burst
.
<EOS>
the
torrent
roar
and
rush
on
furiously
as
before
,
join
its
force
with
Pendle
Water
,
swell
up
the
river
,
and
devastate
the
country
far
and
wide.[1
]
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
and
his
companion
beheld
this
work
of
destruction
with
amazement
and
dread
.
<EOS>
blanch
terror
sit
in
their
cheek
,
and
the
blood
be
freeze
in
Paslew
's
vein
;
for
he
think
it
the
work
of
the
power
of
darkness
,
and
that
he
be
league
with
them
.
<EOS>
He
try
to
mutter
a
prayer
,
but
his
lip
refuse
their
office
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
move
,
but
his
limb
be
stiffen
and
paralysed
,
and
he
could
only
gaze
aghast
at
the
terrible
spectacle
.
 
<EOS>
amidst
it
all
he
hear
a
wild
burst
of
unearthly
laughter
,
proceeding
,
he
think
,
from
Demdike
,
and
it
fill
him
with
new
dread
.
<EOS>
but
he
could
not
check
the
sound
,
neither
could
he
stop
his
ear
,
though
he
would
fain
have
do
so
.
<EOS>
like
him
,
his
companion
be
petrify
and
speechless
with
fear
.
 
<EOS>
after
this
have
endure
for
some
time
,
though
still
the
black
torrent
rush
on
impetuously
as
ever
,
Demdike
turn
to
the
abbot
and
said,--
 
<EOS>
"
Your
vengeance
have
be
fully
gratify
.
<EOS>
You
will
now
baptise
my
child
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
never
,
never
,
accurse
be
!
"
shriek
the
abbot
.
"
<EOS>
Thou
mayst
sacrifice
her
at
thine
own
impious
rite
.
<EOS>
but
see
,
there
be
one
poor
wretch
yet
struggle
with
the
foam
torrent
.
<EOS>
I
may
save
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
that
be
John
Braddyll
,
thy
bad
enemy
,
"
reply
demdike
.
<EOS>
"
if
he
live
he
shall
possess
half
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
Thou
hadst
best
also
save
Richard
Assheton
,
who
yet
cling
to
the
great
stone
below
,
as
if
he
escape
he
shall
have
the
other
half
.
<EOS>
mark
him
,
and
make
haste
,
for
in
five
minute
both
shall
be
go
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
save
them
if
I
can
,
be
the
consequence
to
myself
what
it
may
,
"
reply
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
and
,
regardless
of
the
derisive
laughter
of
the
other
,
who
yell
in
his
ear
as
he
go
,
"
bess
shall
see
thee
hang
at
thy
own
door
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
dash
down
the
hill
to
the
spot
where
a
small
object
,
distinguishable
above
the
stream
,
show
that
some
one
still
keep
his
head
above
water
,
his
tall
stature
have
preserve
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
be
it
you
,
John
Braddyll
?
"
<EOS>
cry
the
abbot
,
as
he
ride
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
ay
,
"
reply
the
head
.
<EOS>
"
forgive
me
for
the
wrong
I
intend
you
,
and
deliver
me
from
this
great
peril
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
come
for
that
purpose
,
"
reply
the
abbot
,
dismount
,
and
disencumber
himself
of
his
heavy
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
the
two
herdsman
have
come
up
,
and
the
abbot
,
take
a
crook
from
one
of
them
,
clutch
hold
of
the
fellow
,
and
,
plunge
fearlessly
into
the
stream
,
extend
it
towards
the
drown
man
,
who
instantly
lift
up
his
hand
to
grasp
it
.
<EOS>
in
do
so
Braddyll
lose
his
balance
,
but
,
as
he
do
not
quit
his
hold
,
he
be
pluck
forth
from
the
tenacious
mud
by
the
combine
effort
of
the
abbot
and
his
assistant
,
and
with
some
difficulty
drag
ashore
.
 
<EOS>
"
now
for
the
other
,
"
cry
Paslew
,
as
he
place
Braddyll
in
safety
.
 
<EOS>
"
one
-
half
the
abbey
be
go
from
thee
,
"
shout
a
voice
in
his
ear
as
he
rush
on
.
 
<EOS>
presently
he
reach
the
rocky
fragment
on
which
Ralph
Assheton
rest
.
<EOS>
the
latter
be
in
great
danger
from
the
surging
torrent
,
and
the
stone
on
which
he
have
take
refuge
totter
at
its
base
,
and
threaten
to
roll
over
.
 
<EOS>
"
in
Heaven
's
name
,
help
me
,
lord
abbot
,
as
thou
thyself
shall
be
holpen
at
thy
need
!
"
<EOS>
shriek
Assheton
.
 
<EOS>
"
be
not
afraid
,
Richard
Assheton
,
"
reply
Paslew
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
deliver
thee
as
I
have
deliver
John
Braddyll
.
"
 
<EOS>
but
the
task
be
not
of
easy
accomplishment
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
make
his
preparation
as
before
;
grasp
the
hand
of
the
herdsman
and
hold
out
the
crook
to
Assheton
;
but
when
the
latter
catch
it
,
the
stream
swing
him
round
with
such
force
that
the
abbot
must
either
abandon
him
or
advance
further
into
the
water
.
<EOS>
bent
on
Assheton
's
preservation
,
he
adopt
the
latter
expedient
,
and
instantly
lose
his
foot
;
while
the
herdsman
,
unable
longer
to
hold
him
,
let
go
the
crook
,
and
the
abbot
and
Assheton
be
sweep
down
the
stream
together
.
 
<EOS>
down
--
down
they
go
,
destruction
apparently
await
them
;
but
the
abbot
,
though
sometimes
quite
under
the
water
,
and
bruise
by
the
rough
stone
and
gravel
with
which
he
come
in
contact
,
still
retain
his
self
-
possession
,
and
encourage
his
companion
to
hope
for
succour
.
<EOS>
in
this
way
they
be
bear
down
to
the
foot
of
the
hill
,
the
monks
,
the
herdsman
,
and
the
man
-
at
-
arm
have
give
them
up
as
lose
.
<EOS>
but
they
yet
live
--
yet
float
--
though
greatly
injure
,
and
almost
senseless
,
when
they
be
cast
into
a
pool
form
by
the
eddy
water
at
the
foot
of
the
hill
.
<EOS>
here
,
wholly
unable
to
assist
himself
,
Assheton
be
seize
by
a
black
hound
belong
to
a
tall
man
who
stand
on
the
bank
,
and
who
shout
to
Paslew
,
as
he
help
the
animal
to
bring
the
drown
man
ashore
,
"
the
other
half
of
the
abbey
be
go
from
thee
.
<EOS>
wilt
thou
baptise
my
child
if
I
send
my
dog
to
save
thee
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
never
!
"
reply
the
other
,
sink
as
he
speak
.
 
<EOS>
flash
of
fire
glance
in
the
abbot
's
eye
,
and
stunning
sound
seem
to
burst
his
ear
.
<EOS>
a
few
more
struggle
,
and
he
become
senseless
.
 
<EOS>
but
he
be
not
destine
to
die
thus
.
<EOS>
what
happen
afterwards
he
know
not
;
but
when
he
recover
full
consciousness
,
he
find
himself
stretch
,
with
ache
limb
and
throbbing
head
,
upon
a
couch
in
a
monastic
room
,
with
a
richly
-
paint
and
gild
ceiling
,
with
shield
at
the
corner
emblazon
with
the
three
luce
of
Whalley
,
and
with
panel
hang
with
tapestry
from
the
loom
of
flander
,
represent
diver
Scriptural
subject
.
 
<EOS>
"
have
I
be
dream
?
"
<EOS>
he
murmur
.
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
"
reply
a
tall
man
stand
by
his
bedside
;
"
thou
hast
be
save
from
one
death
to
suffer
another
more
ignominious
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
ha
!
"
cry
the
abbot
,
start
up
and
press
his
hand
to
his
temple
;
"
thou
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
ay
,
I
be
appoint
to
watch
thee
,
"
reply
Demdike
.
"
<EOS>
Thou
art
a
prisoner
in
thine
own
chamber
at
Whalley
.
<EOS>
all
have
befall
as
I
tell
thee
.
<EOS>
the
Earl
of
Derby
be
master
of
the
abbey
;
thy
adherent
be
disperse
;
and
thy
brother
be
drive
forth
.
<EOS>
thy
two
partner
in
rebellion
,
the
abbot
of
Jervaux
and
Salley
,
have
be
convey
to
Lancaster
Castle
,
whither
thou
wilt
go
as
soon
as
thou
canst
be
move
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
surrender
all
--
silver
and
gold
,
land
and
possession
--
to
the
king
,
if
I
may
die
in
peace
,
"
groan
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
not
need
,
"
rejoin
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
attaint
of
felony
,
thy
land
and
abbey
will
be
forfeit
to
the
crown
,
and
they
shall
be
sell
,
as
I
have
tell
thee
,
to
John
Braddyll
and
Richard
Assheton
,
who
will
be
ruler
here
in
thy
stead
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
I
have
perish
in
the
flood
!
"
groan
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
mayst
thou
wish
so
,
"
return
his
tormentor
;
"
but
thou
wert
not
destine
to
die
by
water
.
<EOS>
as
I
have
say
,
thou
shalt
be
hang
at
thy
own
door
,
and
my
wife
shall
witness
thy
end
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
who
art
thou
?
<EOS>
I
have
hear
thy
voice
before
,
"
cry
the
abbot
.
<EOS>
"
It
be
like
the
voice
of
one
whom
I
know
year
ago
,
and
thy
feature
be
like
his
--
though
change
--
greatly
change
.
<EOS>
who
art
thou
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
shalt
know
before
thou
diest
,
"
reply
the
other
,
with
a
look
of
gratified
vengeance
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
farewell
,
and
reflect
upon
thy
fate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
so
say
,
he
stride
towards
the
door
,
while
the
miserable
abbot
arise
,
and
march
with
uncertain
step
to
a
little
oratory
adjoining
,
which
he
himself
have
build
,
knelt
down
before
the
altar
,
and
strove
to
pray
.
    
<EOS>
chapter
III.--WHALLEY
ABBEY
.
  
<EOS>
a
sad
,
sad
change
hath
come
over
the
fair
Abbey
of
Whalley
.
<EOS>
It
knoweth
its
old
master
no
longer
.
<EOS>
for
upward
of
two
century
and
a
half
hath
<EOS>
the
"
Blessed
Place"[2
]
grow
in
beauty
and
rich
.
<EOS>
seventeen
abbot
have
exercise
unbounded
hospitality
within
it
,
but
now
they
be
all
go
,
save
one!--and
<EOS>
he
be
attaint
of
felony
and
treason
.
<EOS>
the
grave
monk
walketh
no
more
in
the
cloister
,
nor
seeketh
his
pallet
in
the
dormitory
.
<EOS>
vesper
or
matin
-
song
resound
not
as
of
old
within
the
fine
conventual
church
.
<EOS>
strip
be
the
altar
of
their
silver
crosse
,
and
the
shrine
of
their
votive
offering
and
saintly
relic
.
<EOS>
pyx
and
chalice
,
thuribule
and
vial
,
golden
-
head
pastoral
staff
,
and
mitre
emboss
with
pearl
,
candlestick
and
Christmas
ship
of
silver
;
salver
,
basin
,
and
ewer
--
<EOS>
all
be
go
--
the
splendid
sacristy
hath
be
despoil
.
 
<EOS>
a
sad
,
sad
change
hath
come
over
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
the
library
,
well
store
with
reverend
tome
,
have
be
pillage
,
and
their
content
cast
to
the
flame
;
and
thus
long
labour
manuscript
,
the
fruit
of
year
of
patient
industry
,
with
gloriously
illuminate
missal
,
be
irrecoverably
lose
.
<EOS>
the
large
infirmary
no
longer
receiveth
the
sick
;
in
the
locutory
sitteth
no
more
the
guest
.
<EOS>
no
longer
in
the
mighty
kitchen
be
prepare
the
prodigious
supply
of
meat
destine
for
the
support
of
the
poor
or
the
entertainment
of
the
traveller
.
<EOS>
no
kindly
porter
stand
at
the
gate
,
to
bid
the
stranger
enter
and
partake
of
the
munificent
abbot
's
hospitality
,
but
a
churlish
guard
bid
him
hie
away
,
and
menace
him
if
he
tarry
with
his
halbert
.
<EOS>
Closed
be
the
buttery
-
hatch
and
the
pantry
;
and
the
daily
dole
of
bread
hath
cease
.
<EOS>
close
,
also
,
to
the
brother
be
the
refectory
.
<EOS>
the
cellarer
's
office
be
end
.
<EOS>
the
strong
ale
which
he
brew
in
October
,
be
tap
in
March
by
roystere
trooper
.
<EOS>
the
rich
muscadel
and
malmsey
,
and
the
wine
of
Gascoigne
and
the
Rhine
,
be
no
longer
quaff
by
the
abbot
and
his
more
honoured
guest
,
but
drunk
to
his
destruction
by
his
foe
.
<EOS>
the
great
gallery
,
a
hundred
and
fifty
foot
in
length
,
the
pride
of
the
abbot
's
lodging
,
and
a
model
of
architecture
,
be
fill
not
with
white
-
robe
ecclesiastic
,
but
with
an
armed
earl
and
his
retainer
.
<EOS>
Neglected
be
the
little
oratory
dedicated
to
Our
Lady
of
Whalley
,
where
night
and
morn
the
abbot
use
to
pray
.
<EOS>
all
the
old
religious
and
hospitable
use
of
the
abbey
be
foregone
.
<EOS>
the
reverend
stillness
of
the
cloister
,
scarce
break
by
the
quiet
tread
of
the
monk
,
be
now
disturb
by
armed
heel
and
clank
of
sword
;
while
in
its
saintly
court
be
hear
the
ribald
song
,
the
profane
jest
,
and
the
angry
brawl
.
<EOS>
of
the
brother
,
only
those
tenant
the
cemetery
be
leave
.
<EOS>
all
else
be
go
,
drive
forth
,
as
vagabond
,
with
stripes
and
curse
,
to
seek
refuge
where
they
may
.
 
<EOS>
a
sad
,
sad
change
have
come
over
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
in
the
plenitude
of
its
pride
and
power
have
it
be
cast
down
,
desecrate
,
despoil
.
<EOS>
Its
treasure
be
carry
off
,
its
ornament
sell
,
its
granary
empty
,
its
possession
waste
,
its
storehouse
sack
,
its
cattle
slaughter
and
sell
.
<EOS>
but
,
though
strip
of
its
wealth
and
splendour
;
though
deprive
of
all
the
religious
grace
that
,
like
rich
incense
,
lend
an
odour
to
the
fane
,
its
external
beauty
be
yet
unimpaired
,
and
its
vast
proportion
undiminishe
.
 
<EOS>
a
stately
pile
be
Whalley
--
one
of
the
lovely
as
well
as
the
large
in
the
realm
.
<EOS>
carefully
have
it
be
preserve
by
its
reverend
ruler
,
and
where
reparation
or
addition
be
need
they
be
judiciously
make
.
<EOS>
thus
age
have
lend
it
beauty
,
by
mellow
its
freshness
and
tone
its
hue
,
while
no
decay
be
perceptible
.
<EOS>
without
a
struggle
have
it
yield
to
the
captor
,
so
that
no

of
its
wide

or

,

have

,
be
injure
.
 
<EOS>
never
have

look

,
when

change
have
be
work
,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

try
them
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
kneel
to
them
,
implore
them
,
but
their
heart
be
hard
as
flint
.
<EOS>
They
will
not
heed
me
.
<EOS>
They
will
not
disobey
the
abbot
's
cruel
injunction
,
though
he
be
their
superior
no
longer
.
<EOS>
but
I
shall
be
avenge
upon
him
--
terribly
avenged
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
leave
meh
,
theaw
wicked
woman
.
"
cry
Ashbead
;
"
ey
dunna
wish
to
ha
'
thee
near
meh
.
<EOS>
let
meh
dee
<EOS>
i
'
peace
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
wilt
not
die
,
I
tell
thee
,
Cuthbert
,
"
cry
Bess
;
"
Nicholas
hath
staunch
thy
wound
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
stawncht
it
,
seyst
to
?
"
<EOS>
cry
Ashbead
,
raise
.
<EOS>
"
Ey'st
never
owe
meh
loife
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
before
he
could
be
prevent
he
tear
off
the
bandage
,
and
the
blood
burst
forth
anew
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
not
my
fault
if
he
perish
now
,
"
observe
Demdike
,
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
"
help
him
--
help
him
!
"
<EOS>
implore
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
shanna
touch
meh
,
"
cry
Ashbead
,
struggle
and
increase
the
effusion
.
<EOS>
"
keep
him
off
,
ey
adjure
thee
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
Bess
,
"
he
add
,
sink
back
utterly
exhaust
by
the
effort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cuthbert
!
"
<EOS>
scream
Bess
,
terrify
by
his
look
,
"
Cuthbert
!
<EOS>
art
thou
really
die
?
<EOS>
look
at
me
,
speak
to
me
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
,
as
if
seize
by
a
sudden
idea
,
"
they
say
the
blessing
of
a
die
man
will
avail
.
<EOS>
bless
my
child
,
Cuthbert
,
bless
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
give
it
me
!
"
groan
the
forester
.
 
<EOS>
Bess
hold
the
infant
towards
him
;
but
before
he
could
place
his
hand
upon
it
all
power
forsook
him
,
and
he
fall
back
and
expire
.
 
<EOS>
"
lose
!
<EOS>
lose
!
<EOS>
for
ever
lose
!
"
cry
Bess
,
with
a
wild
shriek
.
 
<EOS>
at
this
moment
a
loud
blast
be
blow
from
the
gate
-
tower
,
and
a
trumpeter
call
out
,
 
<EOS>
"
the
abbot
and
the
two
other
prisoner
be
come
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
to
thy
foot
,
wench
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Demdike
,
imperiously
,
and
seize
the
bewilder
woman
by
the
arm
;
"
to
thy
foot
,
and
come
with
me
to
meet
him
!
"
    
CHAPTER
IV.--THE
MALEDICTION
.
  
<EOS>
the
captive
ecclesiastic
,
together
with
the
strong
escort
by
which
they
be
attend
,
under
the
command
of
John
Braddyll
,
the
high
sheriff
of
the
county
,
have
pass
the
previous
night
at
Whitewell
,
in
Bowland
Forest
;
and
the
abbot
,
before
set
out
on
his
final
journey
,
be
permit
to
spend
an
hour
in
prayer
in
a
little
chapel
on
an
adjoining
hill
,
overlook
a
most
picturesque
portion
of
the
forest
,
the
beauty
of
which
be
enhance
by
the
winding
of
the
Hodder
,
one
of
the
lovely
stream
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
His
devotion
perform
,
Paslew
,
attend
by
a
guard
,
slowly
descend
the
hill
,
and
gaze
his
last
on
scene
familiar
to
him
almost
from
infancy
.
<EOS>
noble
tree
,
which
now
look
like
old
friend
,
to
whom
he
be
bid
an
eternal
adieu
,
stand
around
him
.
<EOS>
beneath
them
,
at
the
end
of
a
glade
,
couch
a
herd
of
deer
,
which
start
off
at
sight
of
the
intruder
,
and
make
him
envy
their
freedom
and
fleetness
as
he
follow
them
in
thought
to
their
solitude
.
<EOS>
at
the
foot
of
a
steep
rock
run
the
Hodder
,
make
the
pleasant
music
of
other
day
as
it
dash
over
its
pebbly
bed
,
and
recalling
time
,
when
,
free
from
all
care
,
he
have
stray
by
its
wood
-
fringe
bank
,
to
listen
to
the
pleasant
sound
of
run
water
,
and
watch
the
shine
pebble
beneath
them
,
and
the
swift
trout
and
dainty
umber
glance
past
.
 
<EOS>
a
bitter
pang
be
it
to
part
with
scene
so
fair
,
and
the
abbot
speak
no
word
,
nor
even
look
up
,
until
,
pass
Little
Mitton
,
he
come
in
sight
of
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
then
,
collect
all
his
energy
,
he
prepare
for
the
shock
he
be
about
to
endure
.
<EOS>
but
nerve
as
he
be
,
his
firmness
be
sorely
try
when
he
behold
the
stately
pile
,
once
his
own
,
now
go
from
him
and
his
for
ever
.
<EOS>
He
give
one
fond
glance
towards
it
,
and
then
painfully
avert
his
gaze
,
recite
,
in
a
low
voice
,
this
supplication:--
     
"
_
Miserere
mei
,
Deus
,
<EOS>
secundum
magnam
misericordiam
tuam
.
<EOS>
Et
    
secundum
multitudinem
miserationum
tuarum
,
dele
iniquitatem
    
meam
.
<EOS>
amplius
lava
<EOS>
me
ab
iniquitate
meâ
<EOS>
,
et
à
peccato
meo
    
munda
me
.
<EOS>
_
"
 
<EOS>
but
other
thought
and
other
emotion
crowd
upon
him
,
when
he
behold
the
group
of
his
old
retainer
advance
to
meet
him
:
man
,
woman
,
and
child
pour
forth
loud
lamentation
,
prostrate
themselves
at
his
foot
,
and
deplore
his
doom
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
's
fortitude
have
a
severe
trial
here
,
and
the
tear
spring
to
his
eye
.
<EOS>
the
devotion
of
these
poor
people
touch
him
more
sharply
than
the
severity
of
his
adversary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
ye
!
<EOS>
bless
ye
!
<EOS>
my
child
,
"
he
cry
;
"
repine
not
for
me
,
for
I
bear
my
cross
with
resignation
.
<EOS>
It
be
for
me
to
bewail
your
lot
,
much
fearing
that
the
flock
I
have
so
long
and
so
zealously
tended
will
fall
into
the
hand
of
other
and
less
heedful
pastor
,
or
,
still
bad
,
of
devour
wolf
.
<EOS>
bless
ye
,
my
child
,
and
be
comfort
.
<EOS>
think
of
the
end
of
Abbot
Paslew
,
and
for
what
he
suffer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
think
that
he
be
a
traitor
to
the
king
,
and
take
up
arm
in
rebellion
against
him
,
"
cry
the
sheriff
,
ride
up
,
and
speak
in
a
loud
voice
;
"
and
that
for
his
heinous
offence
he
be
justly
condemn
to
death
.
"
 
<EOS>
murmur
arise
at
this
speech
,
but
they
be
instantly
check
by
the
escort
.
 
<EOS>
"
think
charitably
of
me
,
my
child
,
"
say
the
abbot
;
"
and
the
bless
Virgin
keep
you
steadfast
in
your
faith
.
<EOS>
Benedicite
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
be
silent
,
traitor
,
I
command
thee
,
"
cry
the
sheriff
,
strike
him
with
his
gauntlet
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
's
pale
check
burn
crimson
,
and
his
eye
flash
fire
,
but
he
control
himself
,
and
answer
meekly,--
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
didst
not
speak
in
such
wise
,
John
Braddyll
,
when
I
save
thee
from
the
flood
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
which
flood
thou
thyself
cause
to
burst
forth
by
devilish
art
,
"
rejoin
the
sheriff
.
<EOS>
"
I
owe
thee
little
for
the
service
.
<EOS>
if
for
naught
else
,
thou
deserv
death
for
thy
evil
doing
on
that
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
make
no
reply
,
for
Braddyll
's
allusion
conjure
up
a
sombre
train
of
thought
within
his
breast
,
awaken
apprehension
which
he
could
neither
account
for
,
nor
shake
off
.
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
the
cavalcade
slowly
approach
the
north
-
east
gateway
of
the
abbey
--
pass
through
crowd
of
kneel
and
sorrow
bystanders;--but
so
deeply
be
the
abbot
engross
by
the
one
dread
idea
that
possess
him
,
that
he
see
them
not
,
and
scarce
hear
their
woful
lamentation
.
<EOS>
all
at
once
the
cavalcade
stop
,
and
the
sheriff
ride
on
to
the
gate
,
in
the
opening
of
which
some
ceremony
be
observe
.
<EOS>
then
it
be
that
Paslew
raise
his
eye
,
and
beheld
stand
before
him
a
tall
man
,
with
a
woman
beside
him
bear
an
infant
in
her
arm
.
<EOS>
the
eye
of
the
pair
be
fix
upon
him
with
vindictive
exultation
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
avert
his
gaze
,
but
an
irresistible
fascination
withhold
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
seest
all
be
prepared
,
"
say
Demdike
,
come
close
up
the
mule
on
which
Paslew
be
mount
,
and
point
to
the
gigantic
gallow
,
loom
above
the
abbey
wall
;
"
wilt
them
now
accede
to
my
request
?
"
<EOS>
and
then
he
add
,
significantly--"on
the
same
term
as
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
understand
his
meaning
well
.
<EOS>
life
and
freedom
be
offer
him
by
a
being
,
whose
power
to
accomplish
his
promise
he
do
not
doubt
.
<EOS>
the
struggle
be
hard
;
but
he
resist
the
temptation
,
and
answer
firmly,--
 
<EOS>
"
no
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
then
die
the
felon
death
thou
meritest
,
"
cry
Bess
,
fiercely
;
"
and
I
will
glut
mine
eye
with
the
spectacle
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
incense
beyond
endurance
,
the
abbot
look
sternly
at
her
,
and
raise
his
hand
in
denunciation
.
<EOS>
the
action
and
the
look
be
so
appalling
,
that
the
affrighted
woman
would
have
flee
if
her
husband
have
not
restrain
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
by
the
holy
patriarch
and
prophet
;
by
the
prelate
and
confessor
;
by
the
doctor
of
the
church
;
by
the
holy
abbot
,
monk
,
and
eremite
,
who
dwell
in
solitude
,
in
mountain
,
and
in
cavern
;
by
the
holy
saint
and
martyr
,
who
suffer
torture
and
death
for
their
faith
,
I
curse
thee
,
witch
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Paslew
.
<EOS>
"
May
the
malediction
of
Heaven
and
all
its
host
alight
on
the
head
of
thy
<EOS>
infant--
"
 
"
oh
!
holy
abbot
,
"
shriek
Bess
,
break
from
her
husband
,
and
fling
herself
at
Paslew
's
foot
,
"
curse
me
,
if
thou
wilt
,
but
spare
my
innocent
child
.
<EOS>
save
it
,
and
we
will
save
thee
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
avoid
thee
,
wretched
and
impious
woman
,
"
rejoin
the
abbot
;
"
I
have
pronounce
the
dread
anathema
,
and
it
can
not
be
recall
.
<EOS>
look
at
the
dripping
garment
of
thy
child
.
<EOS>
in
blood
have
it
be
baptise
,
and
through
blood
-
stain
path
shall
its
course
be
take
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
ha
!
"
shriek
Bess
,
notice
for
the
first
time
the
ensanguine
condition
of
the
infant
's
attire
.
"
<EOS>
Cuthbert
's
blood
--
<EOS>
oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
listen
to
me
,
wicked
woman
,
"
pursue
the
abbot
,
as
if
fill
with
a
prophetic
spirit
.
"
<EOS>
Thy
child
's
life
shall
be
long
--
beyond
the
ordinary
term
of
woman
--
but
it
shall
be
a
life
of
woe
and
ill
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!
stay
him
--
stay
him
;
or
I
shall
die
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
but
the
wizard
could
not
speak
.
<EOS>
a
great
power
than
his
own
apparently
overmaster
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
child
shall
she
have
,
"
continue
the
abbot
,
"
and
child
's
child
,
but
they
shall
be
a
race
doom
and
accurse
--
a
brood
of
adder
,
that
the
world
shall
flee
from
and
crush
.
<EOS>
a
thing
accurse
,
and
shun
by
her
fellow
,
shall
thy
daughter
be
--
evil
reputed
and
evil
doing
.
<EOS>
no
hand
to
help
her
--
no
lip
to
bless
her
--
life
a
burden
;
and
death
--
long
,
long
in
come
--
find
her
in
a
dismal
dungeon
.
<EOS>
now
,
depart
from
me
,
and
trouble
me
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
Bess
make
a
motion
as
if
she
would
go
,
and
then
turn
,
partly
round
,
drop
heavily
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Demdike
catch
the
child
ere
<EOS>
she
fall
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
hast
kill
her
!
"
<EOS>
he
cry
to
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
"
a
strong
voice
than
mine
hath
spoken
,
if
it
be
so
,
"
rejoin
Paslew
.
"
<EOS>
_
Fuge
miserrime
,
fuge
malefice
,
quia
judex
adest
iratus
_
.
"
 
<EOS>
at
this
moment
the
trumpet
again
sound
,
and
the
cavalcade
be
put
in
motion
,
the
abbot
and
his
fellow
-
captive
pass
through
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
dismount
from
their
mule
within
the
court
,
before
the
chapter
-
house
,
the
captive
ecclesiastic
,
precede
by
the
sheriff
be
lead
to
the
principal
chamber
of
the
structure
,
where
the
Earl
of
Derby
await
them
,
seat
in
the
Gothic
carve
oak
chair
,
formerly
occupy
by
the
abbot
of
Whalley
on
the
occasion
of
conference
or
election
.
<EOS>
the
earl
be
surround
by
his
officer
,
and
the
chamber
be
fill
with
armed
man
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
slowly
advance
towards
the
earl
.
<EOS>
His
deportment
be
dignified
and
firm
,
even
majestic
.
<EOS>
the
exaltation
of
spirit
,
occasion
by
the
interview
with
Demdike
and
his
wife
,
have
pass
away
,
and
be
succeed
by
a
profound
calm
.
<EOS>
the
hue
of
his
cheek
be
livid
,
but
otherwise
he
seem
wholly
unmoved
.
 
<EOS>
the
ceremony
of
deliver
up
the
body
of
the
prisoner
to
the
earl
be
go
through
by
the
sheriff
,
and
their
sentence
be
then
read
aloud
by
a
clerk
.
<EOS>
after
this
the
earl
,
who
have
hitherto
remain
cover
,
take
off
his
cap
,
and
in
a
solemn
voice
spoke:--
 
"
John
Paslew
,
somewhile
Abbot
of
Whalley
,
but
now
an
attaint
and
condemn
felon
,
and
John
Eastgate
and
William
Haydocke
,
formerly
brother
of
the
same
monastery
,
and
confederate
with
him
in
crime
,
ye
have
hear
your
doom
.
<EOS>
to
-
morrow
you
shall
die
the
ignominious
death
of
traitor
;
but
the
king
in
his
mercy
,
have
regard
not
so
much
to
the
heinous
nature
of
your
offence
towards
his
sovereign
majesty
as
to
the
sacred
office
you
once
hold
,
and
of
which
you
have
be
shamefully
deprive
,
be
graciously
pleased
to
remit
that
part
of
your
sentence
,
whereby
ye
be
condemn
to
be
quarter
alive
,
willing
that
the
heart
which
conceive
so
much
malice
and
violence
against
him
should
cease
to
beat
within
your
own
bosom
,
and
that
the
arm
which
be
raise
in
rebellion
against
him
should
be
inter
in
one
common
grave
with
the
trunk
to
which
they
belong
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
God
save
the
high
and
puissant
king
,
Henry
the
Eighth
,
and
free
him
from
all
traitor
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
clerk
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
humbly
thank
his
majesty
for
his
clemency
,
"
say
the
abbot
,
amid
the
profound
silence
that
ensue
;
"
and
I
pray
you
,
my
good
lord
,
when
you
shall
write
to
the
king
concern
us
,
to
say
to
his
majesty
that
we
die
penitent
of
many
and
grave
offence
,
amongst
the
which
be
chiefly
that
of
have
take
up
arm
unlawfully
against
him
,
but
that
we
do
so
solely
with
the
view
of
free
his
highness
from
evil
counsellor
,
and
of
re
-
establish
our
holy
church
,
for
the
which
we
would
willingly
die
,
if
our
death
may
in
anywise
profit
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
amen
!
"
exclaim
Father
Eastgate
,
who
stand
with
his
hand
cross
upon
his
breast
,
close
behind
Paslew
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
abbot
hath
utter
my
sentiment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
hath
not
uttered
mine
,
"
cry
Father
Haydocke
.
<EOS>
"
I
ask
no
grace
from
the
bloody
Herodias
,
and
will
accept
none
.
<EOS>
what
I
have
do
I
would
do
again
,
be
the
past
to
return
--
<EOS>
nay
,
I
would
do
more
--
I
would
find
a
way
to
reach
the
tyrant
's
heart
,
and
thus
free
our
church
from
its
bad
enemy
,
and
the
land
from
a
ruthless
oppressor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
remove
him
,
"
say
the
earl
;
"
the
vile
traitor
shall
be
deal
with
as
he
merit
.
<EOS>
for
you
,
"
he
add
,
as
the
order
be
obey
,
and
address
the
other
prisoner
,
"
and
especially
you
,
John
Paslew
,
who
have
show
some
compunction
for
your
crime
,
and
to
prove
to
you
that
the
king
be
not
the
ruthless
tyrant
<EOS>
he
hath
be
just
represent
<EOS>
,
I
hereby
in
his
name
promise
you
any
boon
,
which
you
may
ask
consistently
with
your
situation
.
<EOS>
what
favour
would
you
have
show
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
reflect
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
thou
,
John
Eastgate
,
"
say
the
Earl
of
Derby
,
see
that
the
abbot
be
occupy
in
thought
.
 
<EOS>
"
if
I
may
proffer
a
request
,
my
lord
,
"
reply
the
monk
,
"
it
be
that
our
poor
distraught
brother
,
William
Haydocke
,
be
spare
the
quarter
block
.
<EOS>
He
mean
not
what
he
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
well
,
be
it
as
thou
wilt
,
"
reply
the
earl
,
bend
his
brow
,
"
though
he
ill
deserve
such
grace
.
<EOS>
now
,
John
Paslew
,
what
wouldst
thou
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
thus
address
,
the
abbot
look
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
make
the
same
request
as
my
brother
,
John
Eastgate
,
if
he
have
not
anticipate
me
,
my
lord
,
"
say
Paslew
;
"
<EOS>
but
since
his
petition
be
grant
,
I
would
,
on
my
own
part
,
entreat
that
mass
be
say
for
us
in
the
convent
church
.
<EOS>
many
of
the
brother
be
without
the
abbey
,
and
,
if
permit
,
will
assist
at
its
performance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
if
I
shall
not
incur
the
king
's
displeasure
in
assent
,
"
reply
the
Earl
of
Derby
,
after
a
little
reflection
;
"
but
I
will
hazard
it
.
<EOS>
mass
for
the
dead
shall
be
say
in
the
church
at
midnight
,
and
all
the
brother
who
choose
to
come
thither
shall
be
permit
to
assist
at
it
.
<EOS>
They
will
attend
,
I
doubt
not
,
for
it
will
be
the
last
time
the
rite
of
the
Romish
Church
will
be
perform
in
those
wall
.
<EOS>
They
shall
have
all
require
for
the
ceremonial
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
's
blessing
on
you
,
my
lord
,
"
say
the
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
"
but
first
pledge
me
your
sacred
word
,
"
say
the
earl
,
"
by
the
holy
office
you
once
hold
,
and
by
the
saint
in
whom
you
trust
,
that
this
concession
shall
not
be
make
the
mean
of
any
attempt
at
flight
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
swear
it
,
"
reply
the
abbot
,
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
I
also
swear
it
,
"
add
Father
Eastgate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
say
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
give
the
requisite
order
.
<EOS>
notice
of
the
celebration
of
mass
at
midnight
shall
be
proclaim
without
the
abbey
.
<EOS>
now
remove
the
prisoner
.
"
 
<EOS>
upon
this
the
captive
ecclesiastic
be
lead
forth
.
<EOS>
Father
Eastgate
be
take
to
a
strong
room
in
the
low
part
of
the
chapter
-
house
,
where
all
act
of
discipline
have
be
perform
by
the
monk
,
and
where
the
knot
lash
,
the
spike
girdle
,
and
the
hair
shirt
have
once
hang
;
while
the
abbot
be
convey
to
his
old
chamber
,
which
have
be
prepare
for
his
reception
,
and
there
leave
alone
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
v.--the
MIDNIGHT
MASS
.
  
<EOS>
dolefully
sound
the
All
Souls
'
bell
from
the
tower
of
the
convent
church
.
<EOS>
the
bell
be
one
of
five
,
and
have
obtain
the
name
because
it
be
toll
only
for
those
about
to
pass
away
from
life
.
<EOS>
now
it
ring
the
knell
of
three
soul
to
depart
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
brightly
illumine
be
the
fane
,
within
which
no
taper
hath
gleam
since
the
old
worship
cease
,
show
that
preparation
be
make
for
the
last
service
.
<EOS>
the
organ
,
dumb
so
long
,
breathe
a
low
prelude
.
<EOS>
Sad
be
it
to
hear
that
knell
--
sad
to
view
those
gloriously
-
dyed
pane
--
and
to
think
why
the
one
ring
and
the
other
be
light
up
.
 
<EOS>
word
have
go
forth
of
the
midnight
mass
,
all
the
eject
brethren
flock
to
the
abbey
.
<EOS>
some
have
toil
through
miry
and
scarce
passable
road
.
<EOS>
other
have
come
down
from
the
hill
,
and
ford
deep
stream
at
the
hazard
of
life
,
rather
than
go
round
by
the
far
-
off
bridge
,
and
arrive
too
late
.
<EOS>
other
,
who
conceive
themselves
in
peril
from
the
share
they
have
take
in
the
late
insurrection
,
quit
their
secure
retreat
,
and
expose
themselves
to
capture
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
a
snare
lay
for
them
,
but
they
run
the
risk
.
<EOS>
other
,
come
from
a
yet
great
distance
,
behold
the
illuminate
church
from
afar
,
and
catch
the
sound
of
the
bell
tolling
at
interval
,
hurry
on
,
and
reach
the
gate
breathless
and
wellnigh
exhausted
.
<EOS>
but
no
question
be
ask
.
<EOS>
all
who
present
themselves
in
ecclesiastical
habit
be
permit
to
enter
,
and
take
part
in
the
procession
form
in
the
cloister
,
or
proceed
at
once
to
the
church
,
if
they
prefer
it
.
 
<EOS>
dolefully
sound
the
bell
.
<EOS>
barefoote
brother
meet
together
,
sorrowfully
salute
each
other
,
and
form
in
a
long
line
in
the
great
area
of
the
cloister
.
<EOS>
at
their
head
be
six
monk
bear
tall
light
candle
.
<EOS>
after
them
come
the
quirister
,
and
then
one
carry
the
Host
,
between
the
incense
-
bearer
.
<EOS>
next
come
a
youth
hold
the
bell
.
<EOS>
next
be
place
the
dignitary
of
the
church
,
the
prior
rank
first
,
and
the
other
stand
two
and
two
accord
to
their
degree
.
<EOS>
near
the
entrance
of
the
refectory
,
which
occupy
the
whole
south
side
of
the
quadrangle
,
stand
a
band
of
halberdier
,
whose
torch
cast
a
ruddy
glare
on
the
opposite
tower
and
buttress
of
the
convent
church
,
reveal
the
statue
not
yet
pluck
from
their
niche
,
the
crosse
on
the
pinnacle
,
and
the
gilt
image
of
Saint
Gregory
de
Northbury
,
still
hold
its
place
over
the
porch
.
<EOS>
another
band
be
station
near
the
mouth
of
the
vaulted
passage
,
under
the
chapter
-
house
and
vestry
,
whose
grey
,
irregular
wall
,
pierce
by
numberless
richly
ornament
window
,
and
surmount
by
small
turret
,
form
a
beautiful
boundary
on
the
right
;
while
a
third
party
be
plant
on
the
left
,
in
the
open
space
,
beneath
the
dormitory
,
the
torchlight
flash
ruddily
upon
the
hoary
pillar
and
groin
arch
sustain
the
vast
structure
above
them
.
 
<EOS>
dolefully
sound
the
bell
.
<EOS>
and
the
ghostly
procession
thrice
track
the
four
ambulatory
of
the
cloister
,
solemnly
chant
a
requiem
for
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
dolefully
sound
the
bell
.
<EOS>
and
at
its
summon
all
the
old
retainer
of
the
abbot
press
to
the
gate
,
and
sue
for
admittance
,
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
They
,
therefore
,
mount
the
neighbouring
hill
command
the
abbey
,
and
as
the
solemn
sound
float
faintly
by
,
and
glimpse
be
catch
of
the
white
-
robe
brother
glide
along
the
cloister
,
and
render
phantom
-
like
by
the
torchlight
,
the
beholder
half
imagine
it
must
be
a
company
of
sprite
,
and
that
the
depart
monk
have
be
permit
for
an
hour
to
assume
their
old
form
,
and
revisit
their
old
haunt
.
 
<EOS>
dolefully
sound
the
bell
.
<EOS>
and
two
bier
,
cover
with
pall
,
be
bear
slowly
towards
the
church
,
follow
by
a
tall
monk
.
 
<EOS>
the
clock
be
on
the
stroke
of
twelve
.
<EOS>
the
procession
have
draw
up
within
the
court
in
front
of
the
abbot
's
lodging
,
the
prisoner
be
bring
forth
,
and
at
sight
of
the
abbot
the
whole
of
the
monk
fall
on
their
knee
.
<EOS>
a
touching
sight
be
it
to
see
those
reverend
man
prostrate
before
their
ancient
superior,--he
condemn
to
die
,
and
they
deprive
of
their
monastic
home,--and
<EOS>
the
officer
have
not
the
heart
to
interfere
.
<EOS>
deeply
affected
,
Paslew
advance
to
the
prior
,
and
raise
him
,
affectionately
embrace
him
.
<EOS>
after
this
,
he
address
some
word
of
comfort
to
the
other
,
who
arise
as
he
enjoin
them
,
and
at
a
signal
from
the
officer
,
the
procession
set
out
for
the
church
,
singe
the
"
_
Placebo
_
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
abbot
and
his
fellow
captive
bring
up
the
rear
,
with
a
guard
on
either
side
of
them
.
<EOS>
all
Souls
'
bell
toll
dolefully
the
while
.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
an
officer
enter
the
great
hall
,
where
the
Earl
of
Derby
be
feast
with
his
retainer
,
and
inform
him
that
the
hour
appoint
for
the
ceremonial
be
close
at
hand
.
<EOS>
the
earl
arise
and
go
to
the
church
attend
by
Braddyll
and
Assheton
.
<EOS>
He
enter
by
the
western
porch
,
and
,
proceed
to
the
choir
,
seat
himself
in
the
magnificently
-
carve
stall
formerly
use
by
Paslew
,
and
place
where
it
stand
,
a
hundred
year
before
,
by
John
Eccles
,
ninth
abbot
.
 
<EOS>
Midnight
strike
.
<EOS>
the
great
door
of
the
church
swung
open
,
and
the
organ
peal
forth
the
"
_
De
profundis
_
.
<EOS>
"
the
aisle
be
fill
with
armed
man
,
but
a
clear
space
be
leave
for
the
procession
,
which
presently
enter
in
the
same
order
as
before
,
and
move
slowly
along
the
transept
.
<EOS>
those
who
come
first
think
it
a
dream
,
so
strange
be
it
to
find
themselves
once
again
in
the
old
accustomed
church
.
<EOS>
the
good
prior
melt
into
tear
.
 
<EOS>
at
length
the
abbot
come
.
<EOS>
to
him
the
whole
scene
appear
like
a
vision
.
<EOS>
the
light
stream
from
the
altar
--
the
incense
load
the
air
--
the
deep
diapason
roll
overhead
--
the
well
-
know
face
of
the
brother
--
the
familiar
aspect
of
the
sacred
edifice
--
all
these
fill
him
with
emotion
too
painful
almost
for
endurance
.
<EOS>
It
be
the
last
time
he
should
visit
this
holy
place
--
the
last
time
he
should
hear
those
solemn
sound
--
the
last
time
he
should
behold
those
familiar
object
--
ay
,
the
last
!
<EOS>
death
could
have
no
pang
like
this
!
<EOS>
and
with
heart
wellnigh
bursting
,
and
limb
scarcely
serve
their
office
,
he
totter
on
.
 
<EOS>
another
trial
await
him
,
and
one
for
which
he
be
wholly
unprepared
.
<EOS>
as
he
draw
near
the
chancel
,
he
look
down
an
opening
on
the
right
,
which
seem
purposely
preserve
by
the
guard
.
<EOS>
why
be
those
taper
burn
in
the
side
chapel
?
<EOS>
what
be
within
it
?
<EOS>
He
look
again
,
and
beheld
two
uncovered
bier
.
<EOS>
on
one
lay
the
body
of
a
woman
.
<EOS>

.

appal

CHAPTER
vi.--teter

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

character
harmonise
with
my
own
.
<EOS>
how
I
win
her
matter
not
,
but
she
cast

of
Ashbead
,
and

.
<EOS>
My
wild

suit
her
;
and
she

with

,

,
and

not
from

meeting
I

.
<EOS>
Ill

quickly
attend

,
and
she

.
<EOS>
Her

close
her

upon

,
and

who
would
have
go

to

,

.
<EOS>
Bess
heed
this

.
<EOS>
She
be

to
repay
the
world
be
contumely
with
like

,
but
when
her
child
be
bear

.
<EOS>
She
wish
to

.
<EOS>
then
it
be
,
"
pursue

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

to

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
alas
!
alas
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

"

.

,

your

to

,

have

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

!
"
<EOS>

;
"

.
<EOS>
Can

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
speak

"
 
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
to

!
"
<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII.--THE
abbey
MILL
.
  
<EOS>

.

sound
reach
him
,
he
snatch
a

from
one
of
the
arquebussier
and
hold

to
the
river
's

.
<EOS>
but

could
see
neither
hound
nor

.
 
<EOS>
"
strange
!
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"

can
not

.
<EOS>

be

.
<EOS>

I

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

far

,
so

,

until

,

behold

struggle
in

,

that

be
his
dog
make

.
 
<EOS>
"
ah
recreant
!
<EOS>
thou
hast
let

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

,

,

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
viii.--the
EXECUTIONER
.
  
<EOS>
Dawn
come
at
last
,
after
a
long
and
weary
night
to
many
within
and
without
the
abbey
.
<EOS>
every
thing
betoken
a
dismal
day
.
<EOS>
the
atmosphere
be
damp
,
and
oppressive
to
the
spirit
,
while
the
raw
cold
sensibly
affect
the
frame
.
<EOS>
all
astir
be
fill
with
gloom
and
despondency
,
and
secretly
breathe
a
wish
that
,
the
tragical
business
of
the
day
be
end
.
<EOS>
the
vast
range
of
Pendle
be
obscure
by
cloud
,
and
ere
long
the
vapour
descend
into
the
valley
,
and
rain
begin
to
fall
;
at
first
slightly
,
but
afterwards
in
heavy
continuous
shower
.
<EOS>
Melancholy
be
the
aspect
of
the
abbey
,
and
it
require
no
stretch
of
imagination
to
fancy
that
the
old
structure
be
deplore
the
fate
of
its
former
ruler
.
<EOS>
to
those
impressed
with
the
idea
--
and
many
there
be
who
be
so
--
<EOS>
the
very
stone
of
the
convent
church
seem
dissolve
into
tear
.
<EOS>
the
statue
of
the
saint
appear
to
weep
,
and
the
great
statue
of
Saint
Gregory
de
Northbury
over
the
porch
seem
bow
down
with
grief
.
<EOS>
the
grotesquely
carve
head
on
the
spout
grin
horribly
at
the
abbot
's
destroyer
,
and
spout
forth
cascade
of
water
,
as
if
with
the
intent
of
drown
them
.
<EOS>
so
deluging
and
incessant
be
the
shower
,
that
it
seem
,
indeed
,
as
if
the
abbey
would
be
flood
.
<EOS>
all
the
inequality
of
ground
within
the
great
quadrangle
of
the
cloister
look
like
pond
,
and
the
various
water
-
spout
from
the
dormitory
,
the
refectory
,
and
the
chapter
-
house
,
continue
to
jet
forth
stream
into
the
court
below
,
the
ambulatory
be
soon
fill
ankle
-
deep
,
and
even
the
low
apartment
,
on
which
they
open
,
invade
.
 
<EOS>
surcharge
with
moisture
,
the
royal
banner
on
the
gate
droop
and
cling
to
the
staff
,
as
if
it
too
share
in
the
general
depression
,
or
as
if
the
sovereign
authority
it
represent
have
give
way
.
<EOS>
the
countenance
and
deportment
of
the
man
harmonize
with
the
weather
;
they
move
about
gloomily
and
despondently
,
their
bright
accoutrement
sully
with
the
wet
,
and
their
buskin
clog
with
mire
.
<EOS>
a
forlorn
sight
<EOS>
it
be
to
watch
the
shivering
sentinel
on
the
wall
;
and
yet
more
forlorn
to
see
the
group
of
the
abbot
's
old
retainer
gather
without
,
wrap
in
their
blue
woollen
cloak
,
patiently
endure
the
drench
shower
,
and
await
the
last
awful
scene
.
<EOS>
but
the
sad
sight
of
all
be
on
the
hill
,
already
describe
,
call
the
Holehouses
.
<EOS>
here
two
other
less
gibbet
have
be
erect
during
the
night
,
one
on
either
hand
of
the
lofty
instrument
of
justice
,
and
the
carpenter
be
yet
employ
in
finish
their
work
,
have
be
delay
by
the
badness
of
the
weather
.
<EOS>
half
drown
by
the
torrent
that
fall
upon
them
,
the
poor
fellow
be
protect
from
interference
with
their
disagreeable
occupation
by
half
a
dozen
well
-
mount
and
well
-
arm
trooper
,
and
by
as
many
halberdier
;
and
this
company
,
completely
expose
to
the
weather
,
suffer
severely
from
wet
and
cold
.
<EOS>
the
rain
beat
against
the
gallow
,
run
down
its
tall
naked
post
,
and
collect
in
pool
at
its
foot
.
<EOS>
attract
by
some
strange
instinct
,
which
seem
to
give
them
a
knowledge
of
the
object
of
these
terrible
preparation
,
two
raven
wheel
scream
round
the
fatal
tree
,
and
at
length
one
of
them
settle
on
the
cross
-
beam
,
and
could
with
difficulty
be
dislodge
by
the
shout
of
the
man
,
when
it
fly
away
,
croak
hoarsely
.
<EOS>
up
this
gentle
hill
,
ordinarily
so
soft
and
beautiful
,
but
now
abhorrent
as
a
Golgotha
,
in
the
eye
of
the
beholder
,
group
of
rustic
and
monk
have
climb
over
ground
render
slippery
with
moisture
,
and
have
gather
round
the
paling
encircle
the
terrible
apparatus
,
look
the
image
of
despair
and
woe
.
 
<EOS>
even
those
within
the
abbey
,
and
shelter
from
the
storm
,
share
the
all
-
pervading
despondency
.
<EOS>
the
refectory
look
dull
and
comfortless
,
and
the
log
on
the
hearth
hiss
and
sputter
,
and
would
not
burn
.
<EOS>
green
wood
have
be
bring
instead
of
dry
fuel
by
the
drowsy
henchman
.
<EOS>
the
viand
on
the
board
provoke
not
the
appetite
,
and
the
man
empty
their
cup
of
ale
,
yawn
and
stretch
their
arm
,
as
if
they
would
fain
sleep
an
hour
or
two
long
.
<EOS>
the
sense
of
discomfort
,
be
heighten
by
the
entrance
of
those
whose
term
of
watch
have
be
relieve
,
and
who
cast
their
dripping
cloak
on
the
floor
,
while
two
or
three
savage
dog
,
steam
with
moisture
,
stretch
their
huge
length
before
the
sullen
fire
,
and
dispute
all
approach
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
within
the
great
hall
be
already
gather
the
retainer
of
the
Earl
of
Derby
,
but
the
nobleman
himself
have
not
appear
.
<EOS>
have
pass
the
great
part
of
the
night
in
conference
with
one
person
or
another
,
and
the
abbot
's
flight
have
cause
him
much
disquietude
,
though
he
do
not
hear
of
it
till
the
fugitive
be
recover
;
the
earl
would
not
seek
his
couch
until
within
an
hour
of
daybreak
,
and
his
attendant
,
consider
the
state
of
the
weather
,
and
that
it
yet
want
full
two
hour
to
the
time
appoint
for
the
execution
,
do
not
think
it
needful
to
disturb
him
.
<EOS>
Braddyll
and
Assheton
,
however
,
be
up
and
ready
;
but
,
despite
their
firmness
of
nerve
,
they
yield
like
the
rest
to
the
depressing
influence
of
the
weather
,
and
begin
to
have
some
misgiving
as
to
their
own
share
in
the
tragedy
about
to
be
enact
.
<EOS>
the
various
gentleman
in
attendance
pace
to
and
fro
within
the
hall
,
hold
but
slight
converse
together
,
anxiously
count
the
minute
,
for
the
time
appear
to
pass
on
with
unwonted
slowness
,
and
ever
and
anon
glance
through
the
diamond
pane
of
the
window
at
the
rain
pour
down
steadily
without
,
and
come
back
again
hopeless
of
amendment
in
the
weather
.
 
<EOS>
if
such
be
the
disheartening
influence
of
the
day
on
those
who
have
nothing
to
apprehend
,
what
must
its
effect
have
be
on
the
poor
captive
!
<EOS>
woful
indeed
.
<EOS>
the
two
monk
suffer
a
complete
prostration
of
spirit
.
<EOS>
all
the
resolution
which
Father
Haydocke
have
display
in
his
interview
with
the
Earl
of
Derby
,
fail
him
now
,
and
he
yield
to
the
agony
of
despair
.
<EOS>
Father
Eastgate
be
in
little
well
condition
,
and
give
vent
to
unavaile
lamentation
,
instead
of
pay
heed
to
the
consolatory
discourse
of
the
monk
who
have
be
permit
to
visit
him
.
 
<EOS>
the
abbot
be
better
sustain
.
<EOS>
though
greatly
enfeeble
by
the
occurrence
of
the
night
,
yet
in
proportion
as
his
bodily
strength
decrease
,
his
mental
energy
rally
.
<EOS>
since
the
confession
of
his
secret
offence
,
and
the
conviction
he
have
obtain
that
his
suppose
victim
still
live
,
a
weight
seem
take
from
his
breast
,
and
he
have
no
longer
any
dread
of
death
.
<EOS>
rather
he
look
to
the
speedy
termination
of
existence
with
hopeful
pleasure
.
<EOS>
He
prepare
himself
as
decently
as
the
mean
afford
him
permit
for
his
last
appearance
before
the
world
,
but
refuse
all
refreshment
except
a
cup
of
water
,
and
be
leave
to
himself
be
pray
fervently
,
when
a
man
be

into

cell
.
<EOS>
think

be
the
executioner
come
to

,
he

,
and
to

beheld
Hal
o
'
Nabs
.
<EOS>
the

of
the
rustic
be
pale
,
but

be
determine
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
here
,
my
son
,
"
cry
Paslew
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
escape
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
ey'm
<EOS>
i
'
nah
dawnger
,
feyther
abbut
,
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ey'n
getten

fo

,

.
<EOS>
Mey

easy
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

!
"

.

.
"
 
<EOS>

yo'n

weel

-
and
-

<EOS>
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dunnah

<EOS>

;

o

.
"
 
<EOS>
Paslew

,

step

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
not

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

o
'

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
what

,

?
"
<EOS>

,
notice

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
God
's

!
<EOS>
if

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
nothing

,

,
"

"
 
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
out

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

!
"

,

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
death
!
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"

;

,

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
ey

,
"

Hal
,
inwardly

at

.
<EOS>
but

fall
when

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

;
"
he

in
make

.
<EOS>
so

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"

,
"

?
<EOS>
bring

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
but
Hal
be
go
.
<EOS>

's

,

,

-

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"
reply

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
ay
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

be

,

rather

.
<EOS>
what

's

be
,

,
I

,
but

hath

;

,
I

shall

,

shall
be
fully
carry

,

law
satisfy
.
<EOS>
Your
lordship
can

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

on

of

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
the

,

.
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
"

make
.
"
 
<EOS>
and

bow
,

with

,
the

sit
down
with
his

to
break

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IX.--WISWALL
HALL
.
  
<EOS>
shortly
before
ten
o'clock
a
numerous
cortège
,
consist
of
a
troop
of
horse
in
their
full
equipment
,
a
band
of
archer
with
their
bow
over
their
shoulder
,
and
a
long
train
of
barefoot
monk
,
who
have
be
permit
to
attend
,
set
out
from
the
abbey
.
<EOS>
behind
them
come
a
varlet
with
a
paper
mitre
on
his
head
,
and
a
lathen
crosier
in
his
hand
,
cover
with
a
surcoat
,
on
which
be
emblazon
,
but
tear
and
reverse
,
the
arm
of
Paslew
;
argent
,
a
fess
between
three
mullet
,
sable
,
pierce
of
the
field
,
a
crescent
for
difference
.
<EOS>
after
him
come
another
varlet
bear
a
banner
,
on
which
be
paint
a
grotesque
figure
in
a
half
-
military
,
half
-
monastic
garb
,
represent
the
"
Earl
of
poverty
,
"
with
this
distich
beneath
it:--
           
Priest
and
warrior
--
rich
and
poor
,
          
He
shall
be
hang
at
his
own
door
.
 
<EOS>
Next
follow
a
tumbrel
,
draw
by
two
horse
,
in
which
sit
the
abbot
alone
,
the
two
other
prisoner
be
keep
back
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
then
come
Demdike
,
in
a
leathern
jerkin
and
blood
-
red
hose
,
fit
closely
to
his
sinewy
limb
,
and
wrap
in
a
houppeland
of
the
same
colour
as
the
hose
,
with
a
coil
of
rope
round
his
neck
.
<EOS>
He
walk
between
two
ill
-
favour
personage
habit
in
black
,
whom
he
have
choose
as
assistant
.
<EOS>
a
band
of
halberdier
bring
up
the
rear
.
<EOS>
the
procession
move
slowly
along,--the
passing
-
bell
tolling
each
minute
,
and
a
muffled
drum
sound
hollowly
at
interval
.
 
<EOS>
shortly
before
the
procession
start
the
rain
cease
,
but
the
air
feel
damp
and
chill
,
and
the
road
be
inundate
.
<EOS>
pass
out
at
the
north
-
eastern
gateway
,
the
gloomy
train
skirt
the
south
side
of
the
convent
church
,
and
go
on
in
the
direction
of
the
village
of
Whalley
.
<EOS>
when
near
the
east
end
of
the
holy
edifice
,
the
abbot
beheld
two
coffin
borne
along
,
and
,
<EOS>
on
inquiry
,
learn
that
they
contain
the
body
of
Bess
Demdike
and
Cuthbert
Ashbead
,
who
be
about
to
be
inter
in
the
cemetery
.
<EOS>
at
this
moment
his
eye
for
the
first
time
encounter
that
of
his
implacable
foe
,
and
he
then
discover
that
he
be
to
serve
as
his
executioner
.
 
<EOS>
at
first
Paslew
feel
much
trouble
at
this
thought
,
but
the
feeling
quickly
pass
away
.
<EOS>
on
reach
Whalley
,
every
door
be
find
closed
,
and
every
window
shut
;
so
that
the
spectacle
be
lose
upon
the
inhabitant
;
and
after
a
brief
halt
,
the
cavalcade
get
out
for
Wiswall
Hall
.
 
<EOS>
Sprung
from
an
ancient
family
reside
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Whalley
<EOS>
,
Abbot
Paslew
be
the
second
son
of
Francis
Paslew
of
Wiswall
Hall
,
a
great
gloomy
stone
mansion
,
situate
at
the
foot
of
the
south
-
western
side
of
Pendle
Hill
,
where
his
brother
Francis
still
reside
.
<EOS>
of
a
cold
and
cautious
character
,
Francis
Paslew
,
second
of
the
name
,
hold
aloof
from
the
insurrection
,
and
when
his
brother
be
arrest
he
wholly
abandon
him
.
<EOS>
still
the
owner
of
Wiswall
have
not
altogether
escape
suspicion
,
and
it
be
probably
as
much
with
the
view
of
degrade
him
as
of
add
to
the
abbot
's
punishment
,
that
the
latter
be
take
to
the
hall
on
the
morning
of
his
execution
.
<EOS>
be
this
as
it
may
,
the
cortège
toil
thither
through
road
bad
in
the
good
of
season
,
but
now
,
since
the
heavy
rain
,
scarcely
passable
;
and
it
arrive
there
in
about
half
an
hour
,
and
draw
up
on
the
broad
green
lawn
.
<EOS>
window
and
door
of
the
hall
be
closed
;
<EOS>
no
smoke
issue
from
the
heavy
pile
of
chimney
;
and
to
all
outward
seem
the
place
be
utterly
desert
.
<EOS>
in
answer
to
inquiry
,
it
appear
that
Francis
Paslew
have
depart
for
Northumberland
on
the
previous
day
,
take
all
his
household
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
in
early
year
,
a
quarrel
have
occur
between
the
haughty
abbot
and
the
churlish
Francis
,
the
brother
rarely
meet
,
whence
it
chance
that
John
Paslew
have
seldom
visit
the
place
of
his
birth
of
late
,
though
lie
so
near
to
the
abbey
,
and
,
indeed
,
form
part
of
its
ancient
dependency
.
<EOS>
It
be
sad
to
view
it
now
;
and
yet
<EOS>
the
house
,
gloomy
as
it
be
,
recall
season
with
which
,
though
they
may
awaken
regret
,
no
guilty
association
be
connect
.
<EOS>
Dark
be
the
hall
,
and
desolate
,
but
on
the
fine
old
tree
around
it
the
rook
be
settle
,
and
their
loud
cawing
please
him
,
and
excited
gentle
emotion
.
<EOS>
for
a
few
moment
he
grow
young
again
,
and
forget
why
he
be
there
.
<EOS>
fondly
survey
the
house
,
the
terrace
garden
,
in
which
,
as
a
boy
,
he
have

,

,

have

;

of
Pendle
,
spring

behind
the
mansion
,
and
up

have

.
<EOS>
the

of
memory
be

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

"

"

.
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
to

be
fully
avenge
,
"
he
say
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
Abbot
Paslew
,
also
,
"
cry
a
voice
above
him
.
 
<EOS>
Demdike
look
up
,
but
the
look
be
his
last
,
for
the
ponderous
statue
of
Saint
Gregory
de
Northbury
,
launch
from
its
pedestal
,
fall
upon
his
head
,
and
crush
him
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
a
mangled
and
breathless
mass
be
take
from
beneath
the
image
,
and
the
hand
and
visage
of
Paslew
be
find
spot
with
blood
dash
from
the
gory
carcass
.
<EOS>
the
author
of
the
wizard
's
destruction
be
suspect
,
but
never
find
,
nor
be
it
positively
know
who
have
do
the
deed
till
year
after
,
when
Hal
o
'
Nabs
,
who
meanwhile
have
marry
pretty
Dorothy
Croft
,
and
have
be
bless
by
numerous
offspring
in
the
union
,
make
his
last
confession
,
and
then
he
exhibit
no
remarkable
or
become
penitence
for
the
act
,
neither
be
he
refuse
absolution
.
 
<EOS>
thus
it
come
to
pass
that
the
abbot
and
his
enemy
perish
together
.
<EOS>
the
mutilated
remain
of
the
wizard
be
place
in
a
shell
,
and
huddle
into
the
grave
where
his
wife
have
that
morning
be
lay
.
<EOS>
but
no
prayer
be
say
over
him
.
<EOS>
and
the
superstitious
believe
that
the
body
be
carry
off
that
very
night
by
the
Fiend
,
and
take
to
a
witch
's
sabbath
in
the
ruined
tower
on
Rimington
Moor
.
<EOS>
certain
it
be
,
that
the
unhallowed
grave
be
disturb
.
<EOS>
the
body
of
Paslew
be
decently
inter
in
the
north
aisle
of
the
parish
church
of
Whalley
,
beneath
a
stone
with
a
gothic
cross
sculpture
upon
it
,
and
bear
the
piteous
inscription:--"_miserere
mei
_
.
"
 
<EOS>
but
in
the
belief
of
the
vulgar
the
abbot
do
not
rest
tranquilly
.
<EOS>
for
many
year
afterwards
a
white
-
robe
monastic
figure
be
see
to
flit
along
the
cloister
,
pass
out
at
the
gate
,
and
disappear
with
a
wail
cry
over
the
Holehouses
.
<EOS>
and
the
same
ghostly
figure
be
often
see
to
glide
through
the
corridor
in
the
abbot
's
lodging
,
and
vanish
at
the
door
of
the
chamber
lead
to
the
little
oratory
.
<EOS>
thus
Whalley
Abbey
be
suppose
to
be
haunt
,
and
few
like
to
wander
through
its
desert
cloister
,
or
ruin
church
,
after
dark
.
<EOS>
the
abbot
's
tragical
end
be
thus
recorded:--
            
<EOS>
Johannes
Paslew
:
Capitali
Effectus
Supplicio
.
          
<EOS>
12º
Mensis
Martii
,
1537
.
 
<EOS>
as
to
the
infant
,
upon
whom
the
abbot
's
malediction
fall
,
it
be
reserve
for
the
dark
destiny
shadow
forth
in
the
dread
anathema
he
have
utter
:
to
the
development
of
which
the
tragic
drama
about
to
follow

,
and
to

of
Abbot

form
