.
<EOS>
thus
far
the
veil
of
the
Future
may
be
draw
aside
.
<EOS>
that
infant
and
her
progeny
become
the
LANCASHIRE
witches
.
  
<EOS>
end
of
the
INTRODUCTION
.
    
<EOS>
the
LANCASHIRE
WITCHES
.
 
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
the
FIRST
.
 
<EOS>
Alizon
Device
.
    
<EOS>
chapter
i.--the
MAY
QUEEN
.
  
<EOS>
on
a
May
-
day
in
the
early
part
of
the
seventeenth
century
,
and
a
most
lovely
May
-
day
,
too
,
admirably
adapt
to
usher
in
the
merry
month
of
the
year
,
and
seemingly
make
expressly
for
the
occasion
,
a
wake
be
hold
at
Whalley
,
to
which
all
the
neighbour
country
folk
resort
,
and
indeed
many
of
the
gentry
as
well
,
for
in
the
good
old
time
,
when
England
be
still
merry
England
,
a
wake
have
attraction
for
all
class
alike
,
and
especially
in
Lancashire
;
for
,
with
pride
I
speak
it
,
there
be
no
lad
who
,
in
run
,
vaulting
,
wrestling
,
dancing
,
or
in
any
other
manly
exercise
,
could
compare
with
the
Lancashire
lad
.
<EOS>
in
archery
,
above
all
,
none
could
match
them
;
for
be
not
their
ancestor
the
stout
bowman
and
billman
whose
cloth
-
yard
shaft
,
and
trenchant
weapon
,
win
the
day
at
Flodden
?
<EOS>
and
be
they
not
true
son
of
their
father
?
<EOS>
and
then
,
I
speak
it
with
yet
great
pride
<EOS>
,
there
be
few
,
if
any
,
lass
who
could
compare
in
comeliness
with
the
rosy
-
cheek
,
dark
-
haired
,
bright
-
eyed
lass
of
Lancashire
.
 
<EOS>
assemblage
of
this
kind
,
therefore
,
where
the
good
specimen
of
either
sex
be
to
be
meet
with
,
be
sure
to
be
well
attend
,
and
in
spite
of
an
enactment
pass
in
the
precede
reign
of
Elizabeth
,
prohibit
"
piping
,
playing
,
bear
-
baiting
,
and
bull
-
baiting
on
the
Sabbath
-
day
,
or
on
any
other
day
,
and
also
superstitious
ringing
of
bell
,
wake
,
and
common
feast
,
"
they
be
not
only
not
interfere
with
,
but
rather
encourage
by
the
high
order
.
<EOS>
indeed
,
it
be
well
know
that
the
reign
monarch
,
James
the
First
,
incline
the
other
way
,
and
,
desirous
of
check
the
grow
spirit
of
Puritanism
throughout
the
kingdom
,
have
openly
express
himself
in
favour
of
honest
recreation
after
evening
prayer
and
upon
holiday
;
and
,
furthermore
,
have
declare
that
he
like
well
the
spirit
of
his
good
subject
in
Lancashire
,
and
would
not
see
them
punish
for
indulge
in
lawful
exercise
,
but
that
ere
long
he
would
pay
them
a
visit
in
one
of
his
progress
,
and
judge
for
himself
,
and
if
he
find
all
thing
as
they
have
be
represent
to
him
,
he
would
grant
them
still
further
licence
.
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
this
expression
of
the
royal
opinion
remove
every
restriction
,
and
old
sport
and
pastime
,
May
-
game
,
Whitsun
-
ale
,
and
morris
-
dance
,
with
rush
-
bearing
,
bell
-
ringing
,
wake
,
and
feast
,
be
as
much
practise
as
before
the
passing
of
the
obnoxious
enactment
of
Elizabeth
.
<EOS>
the
Puritans
and
Precisians
discountenance
them
,
it
be
true
,
as
much
as
ever
,
and
would
have
put
them
down
,
if
they
could
,
as
savouring
of
papistry
and
idolatry
,
and
some
rigid
divine
thunder
against
them
from
the
pulpit
;
but
with
the
king
and
the
authority
in
their
favour
,
the
people
little
heed
these
denunciation
against
them
,
and
abstain
not
from
any
"
honest
recreation
"
whenever
a
holiday
occur
.
 
<EOS>
if
Lancashire
be
famous
for
wake
,
the
wake
of
Whalley
be
famous
even
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
the
man
of
the
district
be
in
general
a
hardy
,
handsome
race
,
of
the
genuine
Saxon
breed
,
and
passionately
fond
of
all
kind
of
pastime
,
and
the
woman
have
their
full
share
of
the
beauty
indigenous
to
the
soil
.
<EOS>
besides
,
it
be
a
secluded
spot
,
in
the
heart
of
a
wild
mountainous
region
,
and
though
occasionally
visit
by
traveller
journey
northward
,
or
by
other
come
from
the
opposite
direction
,
retain
a
primitive
simplicity
of
manner
,
and
a
great
partiality
for
old
custom
and
habit
.
 
<EOS>
the
natural
beauty
of
the
place
,
contrast
with
the
dreary
region
around
it
,
and
heighten
by
the
picturesque
ruin
of
the
ancient
abbey
,
part
of
which
,
namely
,
the
old
abbot
's
lodging
,
have
be
convert
into
a
residence
by
the
assheton
,
and
be
now
occupy
by
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
,
while
the
other
be
leave
to
the
ravage
of
time
,
make
it
always
an
object
of
attraction
to
those
reside
near
it
;
but
when
on
the
May
-
day
in
question
,
there
be
not
only
to
be
a
wake
,
but
<EOS>
a
May
-
pole
set
on
the
green
,
and
a
rush
-
bearing
with
morris
-
dancer
besides
,
together
with
Whitsun
-
ale
at
the
abbey
,
crowd
flock
to
Whalley
from
Wiswall
,
Cold
Coates
,
and
Clithero
,
from
Ribchester
and
Blackburn
,
from
Padiham
and
Pendle
,
and
even
from
place
more
remote
.
<EOS>
not
only
be
John
Lawe
's
of
the
Dragon
full
,
but
the
Chequers
,
and
the
Swan
also
,
and
the
roadside
alehouse
to
boot
.
<EOS>
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
have
several
guest
at
the
abbey
,
and
other
be
expect
in
the
course
of
the
day
,
while
Doctor
Ormerod
have
friend
stay
with
him
at
the
vicarage
.
 
<EOS>
soon
after
midnight
,
on
the
morning
of
the
festival
,
many
young
person
of
the
village
,
of
both
sex
,
have
arise
,
and
,
to
the
sound
of
horn
,
have
repair
to
the
neighbouring
wood
,
and
there
gather
a
vast
stock
of
green
bough
and
flower
branch
of
the
sweetly
-
perfume
hawthorn
,
wild
rose
,
and
honeysuckle
,
with
basket
of
violet
,
cowslip
,
primrose
,
blue
-
bell
,
and
other
wild
flower
,
and
return
in
the
same
order
they
go
forth
,
fashion
the
branch
into
green
bower
within
the
churchyard
,
or
round
about
the
May
-
pole
set
up
on
the
green
,
and
decorate
them
afterwards
with
garland
and
crown
of
flower
.
<EOS>
this
morning
ceremonial
ought
to
have
be
perform
without
wet
the
foot
:
<EOS>
but
though
some
pain
be
take
in
the
matter
,
few
could
achieve
the
difficult
task
,
except
those
carry
over
the
dewy
grass
by
their
lusty
swain
.
<EOS>
on
the
day
before
the
rush
have
be
gather
,
and
the
rush
cart
pile
,
shape
,
trim
,
and
adorn
by
those
experience
in
the
task
,
(
and
it
be
one
require
both
taste
and

,
as
will
be
see
when
the
cart
itself
shall
come
forth
,
)
while
other
have
borrow
for
its

,
from
the
abbey
and
elsewhere
,
silver

,

-

,

,

,
brooch
,
watch
,
chain
,
and

,
so
as
to
make
an
impose
show
.
 
<EOS>
Day
be
usher
in
by
a
merry
peal
of
bell
from
the
tower
of
the
old
parish
church
,
and
the
ringer
practise
all
kind
of
joyous
change
during
the
morning
,
and
fire
many
a
clanging
volley
.
<EOS>
the
whole
village
be
early
astir
;
and
as
these
be
time
when
good
hour
be
keep
;
and
as
early
rise
be
a
famous
sharpener
of
the
appetite
,
especially
when
attend
with
exercise
,
so
an
hour
before
noon
the
rustic
one
and
all
sit
down
to
dinner
,
the
stranger
be
entertain
by
their
friend
,
and
if
they
have
no
friend
,
throw
themselves
upon
the
general
hospitality
.
<EOS>
the
alehouse
be
reserve
for
tipple
at
a
later
hour
,
for
it
be
then
customary
for
both
gentleman
and
commoner
,
male
as
well
as
female
,
as
will
be
more
fully
show
hereafter
,
to
take
their
meal
at
home
,
and
repair
afterwards
to
house
of
public
entertainment
for
wine
or
other
liquor
.
<EOS>
private
chamber
be
,
of
course
,
reserve
for
the
gentry
;
but
not
unfrequently
the
squire
and
his
friend
would
take
their
bottle
with
the
other
guest
.
<EOS>
such
be
the
invariable
practice
in
the
northern
county
in
the
reign
of
James
the
First
.
 
<EOS>
soon
after
mid
-
day
,
and
when
the
bell
begin
to
peal
merrily
again
(
for
even
ringer
must
recruit
themselves
)
,
at
a
small
cottage
in
the
outskirt
of
the
village
,
and
close
to
the
Calder
,
whose
water
sweep
past
the
trimly
keep
garden
attach
to
it
,
two
young
girl
be
employ
in
attire
a
third
,
who
be
to
represent
Maid
Marian
,
or
Queen
of
May
,
in
the
pageant
then
about
to
ensue
.
<EOS>
and
,
certainly
,
by
sovereign
and
prescriptive
right
of
beauty
,
no
one
better
deserve
the
high
title
and
distinction
confer
upon
her
than
this
fair
girl
.
<EOS>
lovelier
maiden
in
the
whole
county
,
and
however
high
her
degree
,
than
this
rustic
damsel
<EOS>
,
it
be
impossible
to
find
;
and
though
the
becoming
and
fanciful
costume
in
which
she
be
deck
could
not
heighten
her
natural
charm
,
it
certainly
display
them
to
advantage
.
<EOS>
upon
her
smooth
and
beautiful
brow
sit
a
gilt
crown
,
while
her
dark
and
luxuriant
hair
,
cover
behind
with
a
scarlet
coif
,
embroider
with
gold
;
and
tie
with
yellow
,
white
,
and
crimson
riband
,
but
otherwise
wholly
unconfirmed
,
sweep
down
almost
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
slight
and
fragile
,
her
figure
be
of
such
just
proportion
that
every
movement
and
gesture
have
an
indescribable
charm
.
<EOS>
the
most
courtly
dame
may
have
envy
her
fine
and
taper
finger
,
and
fancy
she
could
improve
them
by
protect
them
against
the
sun
,
or
by
render
them
snowy
white
with
paste
or
cosmetic
,
but
this
be
questionable
;
nothing
certainly
could
improve
the
small
foot
and
finely
-
turn
ankle
,
so
well
display
in
the
red
hose
and
smart
little
yellow
buskin
,
fringe
with
gold
.
<EOS>
a
stomacher
of
scarlet
cloth
,
braid
with
yellow
lace
in
cross
bar
,
confine
her
slender
waist
.
<EOS>
Her
robe
be
of
carnation
-
colour
silk
,
with
wide
sleeve
,
and
the
gold
-
fringe
skirt
descend
only
a
little
below
the
knee
,
like
the
dress
of
a
modern
swiss
peasant
,
so
as
to
reveal
the
exquisite
symmetry
of
her
limb
.
<EOS>
over
all
she
wear
a
surcoat
of
azure
silk
,
line
with
white
,
and
edge
with
gold
.
<EOS>
in
her
left
hand
she
hold
a
red
pink
as
an
emblem
of
the
season
.
<EOS>
so
enchant
be
her
appearance
altogether
,
so
fresh
the
character
of
her
beauty
,
so
bright
the
bloom
that
dye
her
lovely
check
,
that
she
may
have
be
take
for
a
personification
of
May
herself
.
<EOS>
She
be
indeed
in
the
very
May
of
life
--

;

,

.

<EOS>
this

,

,

.
<EOS>
have

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

's

,

;

,

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II.--THE
BLACK
CAT
and
the
WHITE
dove
.
  
<EOS>
little
Jennet
watch
her

's

with
a
look
in
which
there
be
far
more
of
envy
than
sympathy
,
and
,
when
her
mother
take
her
hand
to
lead

forth
,
she
would
not
go
,
but
say
she
do
not
care
for
any
such
idle
sight
,
go
back

to
the
inner
room
.
<EOS>
when
there
,

,
she
could
not

peep
through

window
,
and
see
Susan
and
Nancy
join
the
revel

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
ey
wish
it
would
rain
an
spile
their
finery
,
"
she
say
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
an
yet
,

?
<EOS>
truth

.
"

,

.

.

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
ah
,
Tib
,
"

,
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

one
'

"

,

"
tib
--

!
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

Protty

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
onny

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

!

<EOS>
again

be

,

,

.
<EOS>
the
child
be
a

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
strange
!
 
<EOS>
"
tib
,
"

,
pat

,
"
thou
hasna

<EOS>
--
how

?
"
 
<EOS>

the

,

that

blood
come
.
<EOS>
the

girl
be

,

,

,

,

strike
the

.
<EOS>
but
start

,

,
and

,
the
cat
assume
such

formidable
appearance
,
that
she
do
not
dare
to
touch
him
,
and
she
then
perceive
that
some
drop
of
blood
stain
her
white
sleeve
,
give
the
spot
a
certain
resemblance
to
the
letter
J.
and
D.
,
her
own
initial
.
 
<EOS>
at
this
moment
,
when
she
be
about
to
scream
for
help
,
though
she
know
no
one
be
in
the
house
,
all
have
go
away
with
the
May
-
day
reveller
,
a
small
white
dove
fly
in
at
the
open
window
,
and
skim
round
the
room
,
alight
near
her
.
<EOS>
no
sooner
have
the
cat
catch
sight
of
this
beautiful
bird
,
than
instead
of
prepare
to
pounce
upon
it
,
as
may
have
be
expect
,
he
instantly
abandon
his
fierce
attitude
,
and
,
utter
a
sort
of
howl
,
spring
up
the
chimney
as
before
.
<EOS>
but
the
child
scarcely
observe
this
,
her
attention
be
direct
towards
the
bird
,
whose
extreme
beauty
delight
her
.
<EOS>
It
seem
quite
tame
too
,
and
allow
itself
to
be
touch
,
and
even
draw
towards
her
,
without
an
effort
to
escape
.
<EOS>
never
,
surely
,
be
see
so
beautiful
a
bird
--
with
such
milkwhite
feather
,
such
red
leg
,
and
such
pretty
yellow
eye
,
with
crimson
circle
round
them
!
<EOS>
so
think
the
little
girl
,
as
she
gaze
at
it
,
and
press
it
to
her
bosom
.
<EOS>
in
do
this
,
gentle
and
good
thought
come
upon
her
,
and
she
reflect
what
a
nice
present
this
pretty
bird
would
make
to
her
sister
Alizon
on
her
return
from
the
merry
-
making
,
and
how
pleased
she
should
feel
to
give
it
to
her
.
<EOS>
and
then
she
think
of
Alizon
's
constant
kindness
to
her
,
and
half
reproach
herself
with
the
poor
return
she
make
for
it
,
wonder
she
could
entertain
any
feeling
of
envy
towards
one
so
good
and
amiable
.
<EOS>
all
this
while
the
dove
nestle
in
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
while
thus
ponder
,
the
little
girl
feel
an
unaccountable
drowsiness
steal
over
her
,
and
presently
afterwards
drop
asleep
,
when
she
have
a
very
strange
dream
.
<EOS>
It
seem
to
her
that
there
be
a
contest
go
on
between
two
spirit
,
a
good
one
and
a
bad,--the
bad
one
be
represent
by
the
great
black
cat
,
and
the
good
spirit
by
the
white
dove
.
<EOS>
what
they
be
strive
about
she
could
not
exactly
tell
,
but
she
feel
that
the
conflict
have
some
relation
to
herself
.
<EOS>
the
dove
at
first
appear
to
have
but
a
poor
chance
against
the
claws
of
its
sable
adversary
,
but
the
sharp
talon
of
the
latter
make
no
impression
upon
the
white
plumage
of
the
bird
,
which
now
shine
like
silver
armour
,
and
in
the
end
the
cat
flee
,
yell
as
it
dart
off--"Thou
art
victorious
now
,
but
her
soul
shall
yet
be
mine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
something
awaken
the
little
sleeper
at
the
same
moment
,
and
she
feel
very
much
terrified
at
her
dream
,
as
she
could
not
help
think
her
own
soul
may
be
the
one
in
jeopardy
,
and
her
first
impulse
be
to
see
whether
the
white
dove
be
safe
.
<EOS>
yes
,
there
it
be
still
nestle
in
her
bosom
,
with
its
head
under
its
wing
.
 
<EOS>
just
then
she
be
startle
at
hear
her
own
name
pronounce
by
a
hoarse
voice
,
and
,
look
up
,
she
behold
a
tall
young
man
stand
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
He
have
a
somewhat
gipsy
look
,
have
a
dark
olive
complexion
,
and
fine
black
eye
,
though
set
strangely
in
his
head
,
like
those
of
Jennet
and
her
mother
,
coal
black
hair
,
and
very
prominent
feature
,
of
a
sullen
and
almost
savage
cast
.
<EOS>
His
figure
be
gaunt
but
very
muscular
,
his
arm
be
extremely
long
and
<EOS>
his
hand
unusually
large
and
bony
--
personal
advantage
which
make
him
a
formidable
antagonist
in
any
rustic
encounter
,
and
in
such
he
be
frequently
engage
,
<EOS>
be
of
a
very
irascible
temper
,
and
turbulent
disposition
.
<EOS>
He
be
clothe
in
a
holiday
suit
of
dark
-
green
serge
,
which
fit
him
well
,
and
carry
a
nosegay
in
one
hand
,
and
a
stout
blackthorn

in
the
other
.
<EOS>
this
young
man
be
James
Device
,
son
of
Elizabeth
,
and
some
four
or
five
year
old
than
Alizon
.
<EOS>
He
do
not
live
with
his
mother
in
Whalley
,
but
in
Pendle
Forest
,
near
his
old
relative
,
Mother
Demdike
,
and
have
come
over
that
morning
to
attend
the
wake
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whot
be
ye
abowt
,
Jennet
?
"
<EOS>
inquire
James
Device
,
in
tone
naturally
hoarse
and
deep
,
and
which
he
take
as
little
pain
to

,
as
he
do
to
polish
his
manner
,
which
be
more
than
ordinarily
rude
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Whot
be
ye
abowt
,
ey
sey
,
wench
?
<EOS>
"

,
"
why
dunna
ye

to

'

to

the

-

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

.

.

,

,

.

<EOS>

"
Green

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

to

.
<EOS>
People

,

,

be

,
so

,

.

<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.

,

.

.

.

.

.

.

,

,

,

.

"

,

,

.

.

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

!
"

,

,
and

at

mark
.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
on
quit
the
cottage
,
the
May
-
day
reveller
have
proceed
slowly
towards
the
green
,
increase
the
number
of
their
follower
at
each
little
tenement
they
pass
,
and
be
welcome
every
where
with
shout
and
cheer
.
<EOS>
the
hobby
-
horse
curvet
and
caper
;
the
Fool
fleer
at
the
girl
,
and
flout
the
man
,
jest
with
every
one
,
and
when
fail
in
a
point
rap
the
knuckle
of
his
auditor
;
Friar
Tuck
chuck
the
pretty
girl
under
the
chin
,
in
defiance
of
their
sweetheart
,
and
steal
a
kiss
from
every
buxom
dame
that
stand
in
his
way
,
and
then
snap
his
finger
,
or
make
a
broad
grimace
at
the
husband
;
the
piper
play
,
and
the
taborer
rattle
his
tambourine
;
the
morris
-
dancer
toss
their
kerchief
aloft
;
and
the
bell
of
the
rush
-
cart
jingle
merrily
;
the
man
on
the
top
be
on
a
level
with
the
roof
of
the
cottage
,
and
the
summit
of
the
haystack
they
pass
,
but
in
spite
of
their
exalted
position
jest
with
the
crowd
below
.
<EOS>
but
in
spite
of
these
multiply
attraction
,
and
in
spite
of
the
gambol
of
Fool
and
Horse
,
though
the
latter
elicit
prodigious
laughter
,
the
main
attention
be
fix
on
the
May
Queen
,
who
trip
lightly
along
by
the
side
of
her
faithful
squire
,
Robin
Hood
,
follow
by
the
three
bold
forester
of
Sherwood
,
and
her
usher
.
 
<EOS>
in
this
way
they
reach
the
green
,
where
already
a
large
crowd
be
collect
to
see
them
,
and
where
in
the
midst
of
it
,
and
above
the
head
of
the
assemblage
,
rise
the
lofty
May
-
pole
,
with
all
its
flowery
garland
glitter
in
the
sunshine
,
and
its
riband
flutter
in
the
breeze
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
be
it
to
see
those
cheerful
group
,
compose
of
happy
rustic
,
youth
in
their
holiday
attire
,
and
maidens
neatly
habit
too
,
and
fresh
and
bright
as
the
day
itself
.
<EOS>
summer
sunshine
sparkle
in
their
eye
,
and
weather
and
circumstance
as
well
as
genial
nature
dispose
them
to
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
every
lass
above
eighteen
have
her
sweetheart
,
and
old
couple
nod
and
smile
at
each
other
when
any
tender
speech
,
broadly
convey
but
tenderly
conceive
,
reach
their
ear
,
and
say
it
recall
the
day
of
their
youth
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
be
it
to
hear
such
honest
laughter
,
and
such
good
homely
jest
.
 
<EOS>
Laugh
on
,
my
merry
lad
,
you
be
make
of
good
old
english
stuff
,
loyal
to
church
and
king
,
and
while
you
,
and
such
as
you
,
last
,
our
land
will
be
in
no
danger
from
foreign
foe
!
<EOS>
laugh
on
,
and
praise
your
sweetheart
how
you
will
.
<EOS>
laugh
on
,
and
blessing
on
your
honest
heart
!
 
<EOS>
the
frolic
train
have
just
reach
the
precinct
of
the
green
,
when
the
usher
wave
his
wand
aloft
,
call
a
momentary
halt
,
announce
that
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
and
the
gentry
be
come
forth
from
the
Abbey
gate
to
meet
them
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
III.--THE
ASSHETONS
.
  
<EOS>
between
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
of
the
Abbey
and
the
inhabitant
of
Whalley
,
many
of
whom
be
his
tenant
,
he
be
joint
lord
of
the
manor
with
John
Braddyll
of
Portfield
,
the
good
possible
feeling
subsist
;
for
though
somewhat
austere
in
manner
,
and
tincture
with
Puritanism
,
the
worthy
knight
be
sufficiently
shrewd
,
or
,
more
correctly
speak
,
<EOS>
sufficiently
liberal
-
minded
,
to
be
tolerant
of
the
opinion
of
other
,
and
be
moreover
sincere
in
his
own
religious
view
,
no
man
could
call
him
in
question
for
them
;
besides
which
,
he
be
very
hospitable
to
his
friend
,
very
bountiful
to
the
poor
,
a
good
landlord
,
and
a
humane
man
.
<EOS>
His
very
austerity
of
manner
,
temper
by
stately
courtesy
,
add
to
the
respect
he
inspire
,
especially
as
he
could
now
and
then
relax
into
gaiety
,
and
,
when
he
do
so
,
his
smile
be
account
singularly
sweet
.
<EOS>
but
in
general
he
be
grave
and
formal
;
stiff
in
attire
,
and
stiff
in
gait
;
cold
and
punctilious
in
manner
,
precise
in
speech
,
and
exact
in
due
respect
from
both
high
and
low
,
which
be
seldom
,
if
ever
,
refuse
him
.
<EOS>
amongst
Sir
Ralph
's
other
good
quality
,
for
such
it
be
esteem
by
his
friend
and
retainer
,
and
they
be
,
of
course
,
the
good
judge
,
be
a
strong
love
of
the
chase
,
and
perhaps
he
indulge
a
little
too
freely
in
the
sport
of
the
field
,
for
a
gentleman
of
a
character
so
staid
and
decorous
;
but
his
popularity
be
far
from
be
diminish
by
the
circumstance
;
neither
do
he
suffer
the
rude
and
boisterous
companionship
into
which
he
be
bring
by
indulgence
in
this
his
favourite
pursuit
in
any
way
to
affect
him
.
<EOS>
though
still
young
,
Sir
Ralph
be
prematurely
grey
,
and
this
,
combine
with
the
sad
severity
of
his
aspect
,
give
him
the
air
of
one
considerably
past
the
middle
term
of
life
,
though
this
appearance
be
contradict
again
by
the
youthful
fire
of
his
eagle
eye
.
<EOS>
His
feature
be
handsome
and
strongly

<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV.--ALICE
NUTTER
.
  
<EOS>
the
quarrel
between
Nicholas
Assheton
and
Sir
Thomas
Metcalfe
have
already
be
make
known
to
Sir
Ralph
by
the
officious
Master
Potts
,
and
though
it
occasion
the
knight
much

;
as
interfere
with
the
amicable

he
hope
to
effect
with
Sir
Thomas
for
his
relative
the
Robinsons
,
still
he
feel
sure
that
he
have
sufficient
influence
with
his
hot
-
headed

,
the
squire
,
to
prevent
the
dispute
from
be
carry
further
,
and
he
only
wait
the
conclusion
of
the
sport
on

green
,
to
take

to
task
.
<EOS>
what
be
the
knight
's
surprise
and
annoyance
,
therefore
,
to
find
that

new

have
spring
up
,
and
,

of

,
he
lay
it

at

door
of
the

Nicholas
.
<EOS>
indeed
,

imagine
that

be
personally

in

,
and
full

,
fly
to

scene

;
but
before

,
the

,
which
,
as
have
be
see
,
be

,
be
fully

,
and
<EOS>
he
only

to

.
<EOS>
It

not
Sir

's
way
to
vent

in

,
but

know
in

,
from

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

,
not

.
<EOS>
"
You
be
ever
brawl
like

.
<EOS>
independently
of
the
ill

set
to

,

.
<EOS>
if

be

,

,

,

to

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

;
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;
"
he

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

"

,

,

.

"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.

"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
no

"

;
"
the

have

,
too

,
perhaps
for

,

,

,

<EOS>

find

.
<EOS>
"
 
"

care
,

,
"

,
notice

be

,

,
"
there

.
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>

,

,
"
he

,
in

,
"

be

,

.
<EOS>
perchance
,
it
be

that
make

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
this
be
mean
to

,
but

turn
,

,
"

;
"

from

to

strong

.
<EOS>
but
it
be
good
not
to
appear

secure.--ah
,
Sir
Ralph
,
"
he
add
,
come
forward
,
"
I
be
right
,
you
see
,
in
my

.
<EOS>
I
be
a
man
of
peace
,
and
strive
to
prevent

and

.
<EOS>
Quarrel
if
you
please
--
and
unfortunately
man
be
prone
to
anger
--
but
always
settle
your
dispute
in
a
court
of
law
;
always
in
a
court
of
law
,
Sir
Ralph
.
<EOS>
that
be
the
only
arena
where
a
sensible
man
should
ever
fight
.
<EOS>
take
good
advice
,
fee
your
counsel
well
,
and
the
chance
be
ten
to
one
in
your
favour
.
<EOS>
that
be
what
I
say
to
my
worthy
and
singular
good
client
,
Sir
Thomas
;
but
he
be
somewhat
headstrong
and
vehement
,
and
will
not
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
be
for
settle
matter
by
the
sword
,
for
make
forcible
entry
and
detainer
,
and
oust
the
tenant
in
possession
,
whereby
he
would
render
himself
liable
to
arrest
,
fine
,
ransom
,
and
forfeiture
;
instead
of
proceed
cautiously
and
decorously
as
the
law
direct
,
and
as
I
advise
,
Sir
Ralph
,
by
writ
of
_
ejectione
firmæ
_
or
action
of
trespass
,
the
which
would
assuredly
establish
his
title
,
and
restore
him
the
house
and
land
.
<EOS>
or
he
may
proceed
by
writ
of
right
,
which
perhaps
,
in
his
case
,
consider
the
long
absence
of
possession
,
and
the
doubt
suppose
to
perplex
the
title
--
though
I
myself
have
no
doubt
about
it
--
would
be
the
most
efficacious
.
<EOS>
these
be
your
only
true
weapon
,
Sir
Ralph
--
your
writ
of
entry
,
assise
,
and
right
--
your
plea
of
novel
disseisin
,
post
-
disseisin
,
and
re
-
disseisin
--
your
remitter
,
your
præcipe
,
your
pone
,
and
your
recordari
faciase
.
<EOS>
these
be
the

<EOS>
CHAPTER
V.--MOTHER
CHATTOX
.
  
<EOS>
not

,

,

.
<EOS>
a

,

,

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VI.--THE
ORDEAL
by
SWIMMING
.
  
<EOS>
bind
hand
and
foot
in
the
painful

before
describe
,

and

handle

all

,

be

be

,

,

rag

have

.
<EOS>
Nance

,
it
have
be
say
,
be

;
but

be

.
<EOS>

.

.

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII.--THE
ruined
conventual
CHURCH
.
  
<EOS>
beneath
a
wild

-

,

in
the

,
and

that

rival

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

(

.
 
<EOS>
Pleasant

stand
,

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
rear

<EOS>
Would

!

,

<EOS>
CHAPTER

REVELATION
.
  
<EOS>
on

,

'

.
<EOS>
in

<EOS>
CHAPTER
x.--the
NOCTURNAL

.
  
<EOS>
on

.

may
have
be
strike
by

,

,

what
be
pass

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
undefined

,

<EOS>

appal

,

,

,
be

?
<EOS>
mother

,

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
them
--
they
be
here
!
"
<EOS>
cry

,
rush

.
 
<EOS>
"

you
have
find

,

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!
what

have

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

this

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
see

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
She
have
bewitch

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
poor
thing
!
<EOS>
she
ramble
,
"
observe

Nutter
to
Adam
Whitworth
,

,

,

;
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
the
order

.
<EOS>

be

,

,

<EOS>
"
She
have
bewitch
me
!
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
a

'

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

ramble

,

attend

.
<EOS>
I

not

dream
.
<EOS>
come
to

house
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
,

,

,

.

<EOS>
Pendle

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
I.--FLINT
.
  
<EOS>
a
lovely
morning
succeed
the
strange
and
terrible
night
.
<EOS>
brightly
shine
the
sun
upon
the
fair
Calder
as
it
wind
along
the
green
mead
above
the
bridge
,
as
it
rush
rejoicingly
over
the
weir
,
and
pursue
its
rapid
course
through
the
broad
plain
below
the
Abbey
.
<EOS>
a
few
white
vapour
hang
upon
the
summit
of
Whalley
Nab
,
but
the
warm
ray
tinge

with
gold
,
and
tip
with
fire
the
tree
-
top
that
pierce
through
them
,
augur
their
speedy
dispersion
.
<EOS>
so
beautiful
,
so
tranquil
,
look
the
old
monastic
fane
,
that
none
would
have
deem
its
midnight
rest
have
be
break
by
the
impious
rite
of
a
foul
troop
.
<EOS>
the
choir
,
where
the
unearthly
scream
and
the
demon
laughter
have
resound
,
be
now
vocal
with
the
melody
of
the
blackbird
,
the
thrush
,
and
other
songster
of
the
grove
.
<EOS>
bell
of
dew
glitter
upon
the
bush
root
in
the
wall
,
and
upon
the
ivy
-
grow
pillar
;
and
gem
the
countless
spider
'
webs
stretch
from
bough
to
bough
,
show
they
be
all
unbroken
.
<EOS>
no
trace
be
visible
on
the
sod
where
the
unhallowed
crew
have
dance
their
round
;
nor
be
any
ashe
leave
where
the
fire
have
burn
and
the
caldron
have
bubble
.
<EOS>
the
brass
-
cover
tomb
of
the
abbot
in
the
presbytery
look
as
if
a
century
have
pass
over
them
without
disturbance
;
while
the
grave
in
the
cloister
cemetery
,
obliterate
,
and
only
to
be
detect
when
a
broken
coffin
or
a
mouldering
bone
be
turn
up
by
the
tiller
of
the
ground
,
preserve
their
wonte
appearance
.
<EOS>
the
face
of
nature
have
receive
neither
impress
nor
injury
from
the
fantastic
freak
and
necromantic
exhibition
of
the
witch
.
<EOS>
every
thing
look
as
it
be
leave
overnight
;
and
the
only
footprint
to
be
detect
be
those
of
the
two
girl
,
and
of
the
party
who
come
in
quest
of
them
.
<EOS>
all
else
have
pass
by
like
a
vision
or
a
dream
.
<EOS>
the
rook
caw
loudly
in
the
neighbouring
tree
,
as
if
discuss
the
question
of
breakfast
,
and
the
jackdaw
wheel
merrily
round
the
tall
spire
,
which
spring
from
the
eastern
end
of
the
fane
.
 
<EOS>
brightly
shine
the
sun
upon
the
noble
timber
embower
the
mansion
of
the
assheton
;
upon
the
ancient
gateway
,
in
the
upper
chamber
of
which
<EOS>
Ned
Huddlestone
,
the
porter
,
and
the
burly
representative
of
Friar
Tuck
,
be
rub
his
sleepy
eye
,
preparatory
to
habit

in
his
ordinary
attire
;
and
upon
the
wide
court
-
yard
,
across
which
Nicholas
be
walk
in
the
direction
of
the
stable
.
<EOS>
notwithstanding
his
excess
overnight
,
the
squire
be
astir
,
as
he
have
declare

should
be
,
before

;
and
a

into
the

have

limb
and
cure

rack

,
while

ale

.
<EOS>
still
,

modern
parlance
,

rather
"
seedy
,
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

Sir

,

bad
still
,

.

,

.

,

.

,

"
 
<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II.--READ
HALL
.
  
<EOS>
the
road
take
by
the
party
on
quit
Whalley
lead
up
the
side
of
a
hill
,
which
,
break
into
picturesque
inequality
,
and
partially
clothe
with
tree
,
slope
down
to
the
very
brink
of
the
Calder
.
<EOS>
wind
round
the
broad
green
plain
,
heretofore
describe
,
with
the
lovely
knoll
in
the
midst
of
it
,
and
which
form
,
with
the
woody
hill
encircle
it
,
a
perfect
amphitheatre
,
the
river
be
ever
an
object
of
beauty
--
<EOS>
sometimes
lose
beneath
over
-
hang
bough
or
high
bank
,
anon
burst
forth
where
least
expect
,
now
rush
swiftly
over
its
shallow
and
rocky
bed
,
now
subside
into
a
smooth
full
current
.
<EOS>
the
Abbey
and
the
village
be
screen
from
view
by
the
low
part
of
the
hill
which
the
horseman
be
scale
;
but
the
old
bridge
and
a
few
cottage
at
the
foot
of
Whalley
Nab
,
with
their
thin
blue
smoke
mount
into
the
pure
morning
air
,
give
life
and
interest
to
the
picture
.
<EOS>
hence
,
from
base
to
summit
,
Whalley
Nab
stand
reveal
,
and
the
verdant
lawn
open
out
amidst
the
wood
feather
its
height
,
be
fully
discernible
.
<EOS>
place
by
Nature
as
the
guardian
of
this
fair
valley
,
the
lofty
eminence
well
become
the
post
assign
to
it
.
<EOS>
none
of
the
belt
of
hill
connect
with
it
be
so
well
wooded
as
their
leader
,
nor
so
beautiful
in
form
;

<EOS>
for
a
quarter
of
a
mile
the
ground
have
be
tolerably
level
,
and
the
sod
firm
;
but
they
now
approach
a
swamp
,
and
,
in
his
eagerness
,
Nicholas
do
not
take
sufficient
precaution
,
and
get
involve
in
it
before
he
be
aware
.
<EOS>
Richard
be
more
fortunate
,
have
keep
on
the
right
,
where
the
ground
be
hard
.
<EOS>
see
Nicholas
struggle
out
of
the
marshy
soil
,
he
would
have
stay
for
him
;
but
the
latter
bade
him
go
on
,
say
he
would
soon
be
up
with
him
,
and
he
make
good
his
word
.
<EOS>
shortly
after
this
their
course
be
intercept
by
a
brook
,
and
both
horse
have
clear
it
excellently
,
they
keep
well
together
again
for
a
short
time
,
when
they
near
a
deep
dyke
which
lie
between
them
and
the
clump
of
tree
.
<EOS>
on
descry
it
,
Richard
point
out
a
course
to
the
left
,
but
Nicholas
hold
on
,
unheede
the
caution
.
<EOS>
fully
expect
to
see
him
break
his
neck
,
for
the
dyke
be
of
formidable
width
,
Richard
watch
him
with
apprehension
,
but
the
squire
give
him
a
re
-
assuring
nod
,
and
go
on
.
<EOS>
neither
horse
nor
man
falter
,
though
failure
would
have
be
certain
destruction
to
both
.
<EOS>
the
wide
trench
now
yawn
before
them
--
they
be
upon
its
edge
,
and
without
trust
himself
to
measure
it
with
his
eye
,
Nicholas
clap
spur
into
Robin
's
side
.
<EOS>
the
brave
horse
spring
forward
and
land
him
safely
on
the
opposite
bank
.
<EOS>
halloo
cheerily
,
as
soon
as
he
could
check
his
courser
the
squire
wheel
round
,
and
ride
back
to
look
at
the
dyke
he
have
cross
.
<EOS>
Its
width
be
terrific
,
and
fairly
astound
him
.
<EOS>
Robin
snort
loudly
,
as
if
proud
of
his
achievement
,
and
show
some
disposition
to
return
,
but
the
squire
be
quite
content
with
what
he
have
do
.
<EOS>
the
exploit
afterwards
become
a
theme
of
wonder
throughout
the
country
,
and
the
spot
be
long
afterwards
point
out
as
"
Squire
Nicholas
's
Leap
"
;
but
there
be
not
another
horseman
find
dare
enough
to
repeat
the
experiment
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
have
to
make
a
considerable
circuit
to
join
his
cousin
,
and
,
while
he
be
go
round
,
Nicholas
look
out
for
the
other
.
<EOS>
in
the
distance
,
he
could
see
Roger
Nowell
ride
leisurely
on
,
follow
by
Sparshot
and
a
couple
of
groom
,
who
have
come
with
their
master
from
the
hall
;
while
midway
,
to
his
surprise
,
he
perceive
Flint
gallop
without
a
rider
.
<EOS>
a
close
examination
show
the
squire
what
have
happen
.
<EOS>
like
himself
,
Master
Potts
have
incautiously
approach
the
swamp
,
and
,
get
entangle
in
it
,
be
throw
,
head
foremost
,
into
the
slough
;
out
of
which
he
be
now
flounder
,
cover
from
head
to
foot
with
inky
-
coloured
slime
.
<EOS>
as
soon
as
they
be
aware
of
the
accident
,
the
two
groom
push
forward
,
and
one
of
them
gallop
after
Flint
,
whom
he
succeed
at
last
in
catching
;
while
the
other
,
with
difficulty
preserve
his
countenance
at
the
woful
plight
of
the
attorney
,
who
look
as
black
as
a
negro
,
point
out
a
cottage
in
the
hollow
which
belong
to
one
of
the
keeper
,
and
offer
to
conduct
him
thither
.
<EOS>
Potts
gladly
assent
,
and
soon
gain
the
little
tenement
,
where
he
be
be
wash
and
rub
down
by
a
couple
of
stout
wench
when
the
rest
of
the
party
come
up
.
<EOS>
It
be
impossible
to
help
laugh
at
him
,
but
Potts
take
the
merriment
in
good
part
;
and
,
to
show
he
be
not
dishearten
by
the
misadventure
,
as
soon
as
circumstance
would
permit
he
mount
the
unlucky
pony
,
and
the
cavalcade
set
forward
again
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
III.--THE
BOGGART
's
GLEN
.
  
<EOS>
the
manor
of
Read
,
it
have
be
say
,
be
skirt
by
a
deep
woody
ravine
of
three
or
four
mile
in
length
,
extend
from
the
little
village
of
Sabden
,
in
Pendle
Forest
,
to
within
a
short
distance
of
Whalley
;
and
through
this
gully
flow
a
stream
which
,
take
its
rise
near
Barley
,
at
the
foot
of
Pendle
Hill
,
add
its
water
to
those
of
the
Calder
at
a
place
call
Cock
Bridge
.
<EOS>
in
summer
,
or
in
dry
season
,
this
stream
proceed
quietly
enough
,
and
leave
the
great
part
of
its
stony
bed
unoccupied
;
but
in
winter
,
or
after
continuous
rain
,
it
assume
all
the
character
of
a
mountain
torrent
,
and
sweep
every
thing
before
it
.
<EOS>
a
narrow
bridle
road
lead
through
the
ravine
to
Sabden
,
and
along
it
,
after
quit
the
park
,
the
cavalcade
proceed
,
head
by
Nicholas
.
 
<EOS>
the
little
river
dance
merrily
past
them
,
singe
as
it
go
,
the
sunshine
sparkle
on
its
bright
clear
water
,
and
glitter
on
the
pebble
beneath
them
.
<EOS>
now
the
stream
would
chafe
and
foam
against
some
large
impediment
to
its
course
;
now
it
would
dash
down
some
rocky
height
,
and
form
a
beautiful
cascade
;
then
it
would
hurry
on
for
some
time
with
little
interruption
,
till
stay
by
a
projecting
bank
it
would
form
a
small
deep
basin
,
where
,
beneath
the
far
-
cast
shadow
of
an
overhanging
oak
,
or
under
its
huge
twist
and
denuded
root
,
the
angler
may
be
sure
of
find
the
speckle
trout
,
the
dainty
greyling
,
or
their
mutual
enemy
,
the
voracious
jack
.
<EOS>
the
ravine
be
well
wooded
throughout
,
and
in
many
part
singularly
beautiful
,
from
the
disposition
of
the
timber
on
its
bank
,
as
well
as
from
the
varied
form
and
character
of
the
tree
.
<EOS>
here
may
be
see
an
acclivity
cover
with
wave
birch
,
or
a
top
crown
with
a
mountain
ash
--
there
,
on
a
smooth
expanse
of
greensward
,
stand
a
range
of
noble
elm
,
whose
mighty
arm
stretch
completely
across
the
ravine
.
<EOS>
further
on
,
there
be
chestnut
and
walnut
tree
;
willow
,
with
hoary
stem
and
silver
leave
,
almost
encroach
upon
the
stream
;
larche
upon
the
height
;
and
here
and
there
,
upon
some
sandy
eminence
,
a
spread
beech
-
tree
.
<EOS>
for
the
most
part
the
bottom
of
the
glen
be
overgrow
with
brushwood
,
and
,
where
its
side
be
too
abrupt
to
admit
the
growth
of
large
tree
,
they
be
mat
with
woodbine
and
bramble
.
<EOS>
out
of
these
would
sometimes
start
a
sharp
pinnacle
,
or
fantastically
-
form
crag
,
add
greatly
to
the
picturesque
beauty
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
on
such
point
be
not
unfrequently
find
perch
a
hawk
,
a
falcon
,
or
some
large
bird
of
prey
;
for
the
gully
,
with
its
brake
and
thicket
,
be
a
favourite
haunt
of
the
feather
tribe
.
<EOS>
the
holly
,
of
which
there
be
plenty
,
with
their
green
prickly
leave
and
scarlet
berry
,
afford
shelter
and
support
to
the
blackbird
;
the
thorn
be
frequent
by
the
thrush
;
and
numberless
less
songster
fill
every
other
tree
.
<EOS>
in
the
covert
there
be
pheasant
and
partridge
in
abundance
,
and
snipe
and
wild
-
fowl
resort
to
the
river
in
winter
.
<EOS>
thither
also
,
at
all
season
,
repair
the
stately
heron
,
to
devour
the
finny
race
;
and
thither
come
,
on
like
errand
,
the
splendidly
-
plume
kingfisher
.
<EOS>
the
magpie
chatter
,
the
jay
scream
and
fly
deep
into
the
wood
as
the
horseman
approach
,
and
the
shy
bittern
hide
herself
amid
the
rush
.
<EOS>
occasionally
,
too
,
be
hear
the
deep
ominous
croaking
of
a
raven
.
 
<EOS>
[
illustration
:
POTTS
after
be
throw
from
his
horse
.
]
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
the
glen
have
be
remarkable
for
its
softness
and
beauty
,
but
it
now
begin
to
assume
a
savage
and
sombre
character
.
<EOS>
the
bank
draw
closer
together
,
and
become
rugged
and
precipitous
;
while
the
tree
meet
overhead
,
and
,
intermingle
their
branch
,
form
a
canopy
impervious
to
the
sun
's
ray
.
<EOS>
the
stream
be
likewise
contract
in
its
bed
,
and
its
current
,
which
,
owe
to
the
gloom
,
look
black
as
ink
,
flow
swiftly
on
,
as
if
anxious
to
escape
to
lively
scene
.
<EOS>
a
large
raven
,
which
have
attend
the
horseman
all
the
way
,
now
alight
near
them
,
and
croak
ominously
.
 
<EOS>
this
part
of
the
glen
be
in
very
ill
repute
,
and
be
never
traverse
,
even
at
noonday
,
without
apprehension
.
<EOS>
Its
wild
and
savage
aspect
,
its
horrent
precipice
,
its
shaggy
wood
,
its
strangely
-
shape
rock
and
tenebrous
depth
,
where
every
imperfectly
-
see
object
appear
doubly
frightful
--
all
combine
to
invest
it
with
mystery
and
terror
.
<EOS>
no
one
willingly
linger
here
,
but
hurry
on
,
afraid
of
the
sound
of
his
own
footstep
.
<EOS>
no
one
dare
to
gaze
at
the
rock
,
lest
he
should
see
some
hideous
hobgoblin
peer
out
of
their
fissure
.
<EOS>
no
one
glance
at
the
water
,
for
fear
some
terrible
kelpy
,
with
twine
snake
for
hair
and
scaly
hide
,
should
issue
from
it
and
drag
him
down
to
devour
him
with
his
shark
-
like
tooth
.
<EOS>
among
the
common
folk
,
this
part
of
the
ravine
be
know
as
"
the
boggart
's
glen
"
,
and
be
suppose
to
be
haunt
by
mischievous
being
,
who
make
the
unfortunate
wanderer
their
sport
.
 
<EOS>
for
the
last
half
-
mile
the
road
have
be
so
narrow
and
intricate
in
its
winding
,
that
the
party
be
oblige
to
proceed
singly
;
but
this
do
not
prevent
conversation
;
and
Nicholas
,
throw
the
bridle
over
Robin
's
neck
,
leave
the
surefoote
animal
to
pursue
his
course
unguided
,
while
he
himself
,
lean
back
,
chat
with
Roger
Nowell
.
<EOS>
at
the
entrance
of
the
gloomy
gorge
above
describe
,
Robin
come
to
a
stand
,
and
refuse
to
move
at
a
jerk
from
his
master
,
the
latter
raise
himself
,
and
look
forward
to
see
what
could
be
the
cause
of
the
stoppage
.
<EOS>
no
impediment
be
visible
,
but
the
animal
obstinately
refuse
to
go
on
,
though
urge
both
by
word
and
spur
.
<EOS>
this
stoppage
necessarily
delay
the
rest
of
the
cavalcade
.
 
<EOS>
well
aware
of
the
ill
reputation
of
the
place
,
when
Simon
Sparshot
and
the
groom
find
that
Robin
would
not
go
on
,
they
declare
he
must
see
the
boggart
,
and
urge
the
squire
to
turn
back
,
or
some
mischief
would
befall
him
.
<EOS>
but
Nicholas
,
though
not
without
misgiving
,
do
not
like
to
yield
thus
,
especially
when
urge
on
by
Roger
Nowell
.
<EOS>
indeed
,
the
party
could
not
get
out
of
the
ravine
without
go
back
nearly
a
mile
,
while
Sabden
be
only
half
that
distance
from
them
.
<EOS>
what
be
to
be
do
?
<EOS>
Robin
still
continue
obstinate
,
and
for
the
first
time
pay
no
attention
to
his
master
's
command
.
<EOS>
the
poor
animal
be
evidently
a
prey
to
violent
terror
,
and
snort
and
rear
,
while
his
limb
be
bathe
in
cold
sweat
.
 
<EOS>
dismounting
,
and
leave
him
in
charge
of
Roger
Nowell
,
Nicholas
walk
on
by
himself
to
see
if
he
could
discover
any
cause
for
the
horse
's
alarm
;
and
he
have
not
advance
far
,
when
his
eye
rest
upon
a
blast
oak
form
a
conspicuous
object
on
a
crag
before
him
,
on
a
scathed
branch
of
which
sit
the
raven
.
 
<EOS>
Croak
!
<EOS>
croak
!
<EOS>
croak
!
 
<EOS>
"
accurse
bird
,
it
be
thou
who
hast
frighten
my
horse
,
"
cry
Nicholas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
I
have
a
crossbow
or
an
arquebuss
to
stop
thy
croaking
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
as
he
pick
up
a
stone
to
cast
at
the
raven
,
a
crash
noise
be
hear
among
the
bush
high
up
on
the
rock
,
and
the
next
moment
a
huge
fragment
dislodge
from
the
cliff
roll
down
and
would
have
crush
him
,
if
he
have
not
nimbly
avoid
it
.
 
<EOS>
Croak
!
<EOS>
croak
!
<EOS>
croak
!
 
<EOS>
Nicholas
almost
fancy
hoarse
laughter
be
mingle
with
the
cry
of
the
bird
.
 
<EOS>
the
raven
nod
its
head
and
expand
its
wing
,
and
the
squire
,
whose
recent
experience
have
prepare
him
for
any
wonder
,
fully
expect
to
hear
it
speak
,
but
it
only
croak
loudly
and

,
or
if
it
laugh
,
the
sound
be
like
the
creaking
of
rusty
hinge
.
 
<EOS>
Nicholas
do
not
like
it
at
all
,
and
he
resolve
to
go
back
;
but
ere
he
could
do
so
,
he
be
startle
by
a
buffet
on
the
ear
,
and
turn
angrily
round
to
see
who
have
deal
it
<EOS>
,
he
could
distinguish
no
one
,
but
at
the
same

receive
a
second
buffet
on
the
other
ear
.
 
<EOS>
the
raven
croak
merrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
I
could
wring
thy
neck
,
accurse
bird
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
enraged
squire
.
 
<EOS>
Scarcely
be
the
vindictive
wish
utter
than
a
shower
of
blow
fall
upon
him
,
and
kick
from
unseen
foot
be
apply
to
his
person
.
 
<EOS>
all
the
while
the
raven
croak
merrily
,
and
flap
his
big
black
wing
.
 
<EOS>
infuriate
by
the
attack
,
the
squire
hit
right
and
leave
manfully
,
and
dash
out
his
foot
in
every

;
but
his
blow
and
kick
only
meet
the
empty
air
,
while
those
of
his
unseen
antagonist
tell
upon
his
own
person
with
increase
effect
.
 
<EOS>
the
spectacle
seem
to
afford
infinite
amusement
to
the
raven
.
<EOS>
the
mischievous
bird
almost
crow
with
glee
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
no
standing
it
any
longer
.
<EOS>
so
,
amid
a
perfect
hurricane
of
blow
and
kick
,
and
with
the
infernal
voice
of
the
raven
ringing
in
his
ear
,
the
squire
take
to
his

.
<EOS>
on
reach
his
companion
he
find
they
have
not
fare
much
well
than
himself
.
<EOS>
the
two
groom
be
belabour
each

;
and
Master
Potts
be
exercise
his
hunting
-
whip
on
the
broad
shoulder
of
Sparshot
,
who
in
return
be
make

with
the

of
a
stout
ash
-
plant
.
<EOS>
assail
in
the
same
manner
as
the
squire
,
and
naturally
attribute

attack
to
their
near

,
they
wait
for

,
but
fall
upon

.
<EOS>

and

,
and
in

for

;
but

be

,

,

be

hobgoblin
<EOS>
,

,
but

the
blow

,

.
 
<EOS>

have

Robin
,

,

;

,
of

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
as

gully
expand
,
and
the

find

through
the
tree
,
and
shine
upon
the
river
<EOS>
,

;

.
<EOS>
not

,

;
as

who
be

smart

,

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
a
blight
seem
to
have
fall
upon

place
.
<EOS>
Roger
Nowell
,
who
have
visit

,

eye
,

.
<EOS>
His

as

--
the

be
all
bewitch
.
<EOS>
here
a
child
be
ill
of

sickness
,
toss

in

,
and

,

could

.
<EOS>

be

,

pine

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
a

be

,

,

,

,

,

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
sometimes

,

<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV.--THE
reeve
of
the
forest
.
  
<EOS>
the
surprise
of
the
party
be
by
no
means
diminish
when
the
stranger
speak
.
<EOS>
His
voice
exactly
resemble
the
sharp
crack
tone
of
the
attorney
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
crave
pardon
for
the
freedom
I
have
take
in
stop
you
,
good
master
,
"
he
say
,
doff

,
and

;
"
<EOS>
but
,
be
aware
of
your
errand
,
I
be
come
to
attend
you
on
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
and
who
be
you
,
fellow
,

thus
volunteer

?
"
demand
Roger
Nowell
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
one
of
the
reeve
of
the
forest
of
Blackburnshire
,
worshipful

,
"
reply

stranger
,
"
and

,
at

of
the
boundary
of
her

,
have
be

Mrs.
Nutter
,
as
I

to

matter

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
indeed
!
"
exclaim

,
"
but
how
know
you
we
be

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mistress
Nutter
send
me

last

,
"
reply

reeve
,
"
that
Master
Nicholas

and

,

Lee
for

of
ascertain

mark
,
mere
,
and
boundary

her
property
,
early

,
and
desire

.
<EOS>
accordingly
I
station

on
yon

ground
to
look

you
,
and
have

on

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
exclaim
Roger
Nowell
,
"
and
you

the
forest
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
live
at

past
the
foot
of
Mistress
Nutter
's
residence
.
 
<EOS>
descend
the
hill
,
and
pass
through
the
thicket
,
the
party
come
within
a
short
distance
of
Goldshaw
Booth
,
when
they
be
meet
by
a
cowherd
,
who
,
with
look
of
great
alarm
,
tell
them
that
John
Law
,
the
pedlar
,
have
fall
down
in
a
fit
in
the
clough
,
and
would
perish
if
they
do

to

.
<EOS>
as
the
poor
man
in
question
be
well
know
both
to
Nicholas
and
Roger
Nowell
,
they
immediately

to
go
to
his

,
and
accompany
the
cowherd
along
a
by
-
road
which
lead
through
the

to
the
village
.
<EOS>
They
have
not
go
far
when
they
hear
loud
groan
,
and
presently
afterwards
find
the
unfortunate
pedlar
lie
on
his
back
,
and
writhe
in
agony
.
<EOS>
He
be
a
large
,
powerfully
-
build
man
,
of
middle
age
,
and
have
be
in
the
full
enjoyment
of
health
and

,
so
that
his

be
the
more

.
<EOS>
His
face
be
greatly
disfigure
,
the

and
neck
draw
awry
<EOS>
,

left

pull
down
,

the

of

same
side

.
 
<EOS>
"
why
,
John
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

have
have
a

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nah
--
nah
--
squoire
,
"

,

,
"
it

neaw
nat'ral

--

.
<EOS>
"
 
"

!
"

,

,

.
"
another

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
John
Law
o
'

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

,

,

,

,

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
V.--BESS
<EOS>
be
<EOS>
o
'
th
'
booth
.
  
<EOS>
Bess
be
o
'
th
'
Booth
--
for
so
the
little
hostel
at
Goldshaw
be
call
,
after
its
mistress
Bess
Whitaker
--
be
far
more
comfortable
and
commodious
than
its
unpretende
exterior
seem
to
warrant
.
<EOS>
stouter
and
bright
ale
be
not
to
be
drunk
in
Lancashire
than
Bess
brew
;
nor
be
better
sherris
or
clary
to
be
find
,
go
where
you
would
,
than
in
her
cellar
.
<EOS>
the
traveller
cross
those
dreary
waste
,
and
ride
from
Burnley
to
Clithero
,
or
from
Colne
to
Whalley
,
as
the
case
may
be
,
may
well
halt
at
Bess
's
,
and
be
sure
of
a
roast
fowl
for
dinner
,
with
the
addition
,
perhaps
,
of
some
trout
from
Pendle
Water
,
or
,
if
the
season
permit
,
a
heath
-
cock
or
a
pheasant
;
or
,
if
he
tarry
there
for
the
night
,
he
be
equally
sure
of
a
good
supper
and
fair
linen
.
<EOS>
It
have
already
be
mention
,
that
at
this
period
it
be
the
custom
of
all
class
in
the
northern
county
,
man
and
woman
,
to
resort
to
the
alehouse
to
drink
,
and
the
hostel
at
Goldshaw
be
the
general
rendezvous
of
the
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
for
those
who
could
afford
it
Bess
would
brew
incomparable
sack
;
but
if
a
guest
call
for
wine
,
and
she
like
not
his
look
,
she
would
flatly
tell
him
her
ale
be
good
enough
for
him
,
and
if
it
please
him
not
he
should
have
nothing
.
<EOS>
submission
always
follow
in
such
case
,
for
there
be
no
disputing
with
Bess
.
<EOS>
neither
would
she
permit
the
frequenter
of
the
hostel
to
sit
later
than
she
choose
,
and
would
clear
the
house
in
a
way
equally
characteristic
and
effectual
.
<EOS>
at
a
certain
hour
,
and
that
by
no
mean
a
late
one
,
she
would
take
down
a
large
horsewhip
,
which
hang
on
a
convenient
peg
in
the
principal
room
,
and
after
bluntly
order
her
guest
to
go
home
,
if
any
resistance
be
offer
,
she
would
lay
the
whip
across
their
shoulder
,
and
forcibly
eject
them
from
the
premise
;
but
,
as
her
determined
character
be
well
know
,
this
violence
be
seldom
necessary
.
<EOS>
in
strength
Bess
be
a
match
for
any
man
,
and
assistance
from
her
cowherd
--
for
she
be
a
farmer
as
well
as
hostess
<EOS>
--
be
at
hand
if
require
.
<EOS>
as
will
be
surmise
from
the
above
,
Bess
be
large
and
masculine
-
look
,
but
well
-
proportion
nevertheless
,
and
possess
a
certain
coarse
kind
of
beauty
,
which
in
early
year

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VI.--THE
TEMPTATION
.
  
<EOS>
shortly

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

"

.

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII.--THE
PERAMBULATION
of
the
boundary
.
  
<EOS>
the
lane
along
which
Richard
Assheton
gallop
in

of
Mother
Chattox
,
make
so
many
turn
,
and
be
,

,
so

hem
in
by
high

,
that

could
sec
nothing

,
and

in

;
but

by

,

urge

to

,
fancy

should
soon

.
<EOS>
in

,

,
he
be

.
<EOS>

that
have

on

,

;
and
on
quit

,

,

of
witch

.
 
<EOS>

,

be
about

,
when
a

come

,

.
<EOS>
the

induce

.
<EOS>
on
near

,
the

,

seem

;
and

be
so

by

's

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

dry

,
<EOS>

at

;

,

,

at

,

cheer

.
 
<EOS>
old

be
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

have

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
all

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
much

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
earth

<EOS>

<EOS>
CHAPTER

.

<EOS>
chapter
IX.--HOW
ROUGH
LEE
be
DEFENDED
by

.
  
<EOS>

,

,
head
by
Potts
,
scale
the
wall
,
which
,
though
of
considerable
height
,
present
no
very
serious
obstacle
in
the
way
of
active
assailant
.
<EOS>
elevate
on
the
shoulder
of
Sparshot
,
Potts
be
soon
on
the
summit
of
the
wall
,
and
be
about
to
drop
into
the
garden
,
when
he
hear
a
sound
that
cause

to
suspend
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
what
be
you
about
to
do
,
cousin
Nicholas
?
"
inquire
Richard
,
as
the
word
of
assault
be
give
by
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
let
loose
Mistress
Nutter
's
stag
-
hound
upon
them
,
"
reply

squire
.
<EOS>
"
They
be
keep
in

by
a

station
behind
yon
yew
-
tree
hedge
,
who
only
await
my
signal
to
let
them
slip
;
and
by
my
faith
it
be
time
he
have
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
as
he
speak
,
he
apply
a
dog
-

to
his
lip
,
and
,
blow
a

,
it
be
immediately
answer
by
a

,
and
half
a
dozen
hound
,
rough
-

,
of

and

,
resemble
in
make
,

,
and

,
the

-

bound
towards

.
 
<EOS>
"
aha
!
"
exclaim
Nicholas
,
clap

to

:
"
we
could
have
disperse
the
whole
rout
with
these
assistant
.
<EOS>
Hyke
,
tristam!--hyke
,
Hubert
!
<EOS>
upon
them!--upon
them
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
be
the
savage

of

that
have
catch

the
alarmed

,
and

.
<EOS>
but

be
no

.
<EOS>
Sparshot
's
broad
shoulder
be
want

foot
upon
,
and
while
he
be

of

wall
in

to
raise

of
it
unaided
,

's

meet

,
while

be

,

.
<EOS>
a

proclaim

's

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

make

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

--

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

--

--

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
the

be

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
lean

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
CHAPTER
X.--ROGER
NOWELL
and
his
DOUBLE
.
  
<EOS>
the
magistrate
be
usher
by
the
lady
into
a
small
chamber
,
open
out
of
the
entrance
-
hall
,
which
,
in
consequence
of
have
only
one
small
narrow
window
,
with
a
clip
yew
-
tree
before
it
,
be
extremely
dark
and
gloomy
.
<EOS>
the
wall
be
cover
with
sombre
tapestry
,
and
on
enter
,
Mistress
Nutter
not
only
carefully
close
the
door
,
but
draw
the
arra
before
it
,
so
as
to
prevent
the
possibility
of
their
conversation
be
hear
outside
.
<EOS>
these
precaution
take
,
she
motion
the
magistrate
to
a
chair
,
and
seat
herself
opposite
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
can
now
deal
unreservedly
with
each
other
,
Master
Nowell
,
"
she
say
,
fix
her
eye
steadily
upon
him
;
"
and
,
as
our
discourse
can
not
be
overhear
and
repeat
,
may
use
perfect
freedom
of
speech
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
glad
of
it
,
"
reply
Nowell
,
"
because
it
will
save
circumlocution
,
which
I
dislike
;
and
therefore
,
before
proceed
further
,
I
must
tell
you
,
directly
and
distinctly
,
that
if
there
be
aught
of
witchcraft
in
what
you
be
about
to
propose
to
me
,
I
will
have
nought
to
do
with
it
,
and
our
conference
may
as
well
never
begin
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
then
you
really
believe
me
to
be
a
witch
?
"
say
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
reply
Nowell
,
unflinchingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
since
you
believe
this
,
you
must
also
believe
that
I
have
absolute
power
over
you
,
"
rejoin
Mistress
Nutter
,
"
and
may
strike
you
with
sickness
,
cripple
you
,
or
kill
you
if
I
think
fit
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
that
,
"
return
Nowell
.
<EOS>
"
there
be
limit
even
to
the
power
of
evil
being
;
and
your
charm
and
enchantment
,
however
strong
and
baneful
,
may
be
wholly
inoperative
against
a
magistrate
in
the

.
<EOS>
if

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

wrap

.

"

.
    
<EOS>
chapter
XII.--THE
MYSTERIES
of
MALKIN
TOWER
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
a
subterranean
chamber
;
gloomy
,
and
of
vast
extent
;
the
roof
low
,
and
support
by
nine
ponderous
stone
column
,
to
which
ring
and
rusty
chain
be
attach
,
still
retain
the
moulder
bone
of
those
they
have
hold
captive
in
life
.
<EOS>
amongst
other
be
a
gigantic
skeleton
,
quite
entire
,
with
an
iron
girdle
round
the
middle
.
<EOS>
fragment
of
mortality
be
elsewhere
scatter
about
,
show
the
number
who
have
perish
in
the
place
.
<EOS>
on
either
side
be
cell
close
by
massive
door
,
secure
by
bolt
and
lock
.
<EOS>
at
one
end
be
three
immense
coffer
make
of
oak
,
hoop
with
iron
,
and
fasten
by
large
padlock
.
<EOS>
near
them
stand
a
large
armoury
,
likewise
of
oak
,
and
sculpture
with
the
ensign
of
Whalley
Abbey
,
prove
it
have
once
belong
to
that
establishment
.
<EOS>
probably
it
have
be
carry
off
by
some
robber
band
.
<EOS>
at
the
opposite
end
of
the
vault
be
two
niche
,
each
occupy
by
a
rough
-
hew
statue
--
the
one
represent
a
warlike
figure
,
with
a
visage
of
extraordinary
ferocity
,
and
the
other
an
anchoress
,
in
her
hood
and
wimple
,
with
a
rosary
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
on
the
ground
beneath
lie
a
plain
flag
,
cover
the
mortal
remain
of
the
wicked
pair
,
and
proclaim
them
to
be
Isole
de
Heton
and
Blackburn
,
the
freebooter
.
<EOS>
the
pillar
be
range
in
three
line
,
so
as
to
form
,
with
the
arch
above
them
,
a
series
of
short
passage
,
in
the
midst
of
which
stand
an
altar
,
and
near
it
a
large
caldron
.
<EOS>
in
front
,
elevate
on
a
block
of
granite
,
be
a
marvellous
piece
of
sculpture
,
work
in
jet
,
and
represent
a
demon
seat
on
a
throne
.
<EOS>
the
visage
be
human
,
but
the
beard
that
of
a
goat
,
while
the
foot
and
low
limb
be
like
those
of
the
same
animal
.
<EOS>
two
curled
horn
grow
behind
the
ear
,
and
a
third
,
shape
like
a
conch
,
spring
from
the
centre
of
the
forehead
,
from
which
burst
a
blue
flame
,
throw
a
ghastly
light
on
the
object
surround
it
.
 
<EOS>
the
only
discernible
approach
to
the
vault
be
a
steep
narrow
stone
staircase
,
close
at
the
top
by
a
heavy
trapdoor
.
<EOS>
other
outlet
apparently
there
be
none
.
<EOS>
some
little
air
be
admit
to
this
foul
abode
through
flue
contrive
in
the
wall
,
the
entrance
to
which
be
grate
,
but
the
light
of
day
never
come
there
.
<EOS>
the
flame
,
however
,

<EOS>
CHAPTER
xiii.--the
two
familiar
.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

JUDGMENT

!
<EOS>

--

!
<EOS>
hell
,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
miserable

--

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
enormity
of

commit
,

!
<EOS>
look

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
no!--the

,

,

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

that
I
could
undeceive
her
--
could
warn

of
the
snare
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
what
be

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
 
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
in

.
"
<EOS>
a

--

--
ho
!

!
"
 
<EOS>

I

"

.
<EOS>
the

have

.
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
it

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>
thou

,

.

,

.

.

<EOS>
oh
!

<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
that
I

.

"
 
<EOS>
"
and

?

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

;

.

.

,

<EOS>
CHAPTER
XIV.--HOW
ROUGH
LEE
be
again
BESIEGED
.
  
<EOS>
Parson
Holden
,
it
will
be
remember
,
leave
Rough
Lee
,
charge
by
Potts
with
a
message
to
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
,
inform
him
of
his
detention
and
that
of
Roger
Nowell
,
by
Mistress
Nutter
,
and
implore
him
to
come
to
their
assistance
without
delay
.
<EOS>
congratulate
himself
on
his
escape
,
but
apprehensive
of
pursuit
,
the
worthy
rector
,
who
,
as
a
keen
huntsman
,
be
extremely
well
mount
,
make
the
good
of
his
way
,
and
have
already
pass
the
gloomy
gorge
through
which
Pendle
Water
sweep
,
have
climb
the
hill
beyond
it
,
and
be
cross
the
moor
now
alone
lie
between
him
and
Goldshaw
,
when
he
hear
a
shout
behind
him
,
and
,
turn
at
the
sound
,
beheld
Blackadder
and
another
mount
serve
-
man
issue
from
a
thicket
,
and
spur
furiously
after
him
.
<EOS>
rely
upon
the
speed
of
his
horse
,
he
disregard
their
cry
,
and
accelerate
his
pace
;
but
,
in
spite
of
this
,
his
pursuer
gain
upon
him
rapidly
.
 
<EOS>
while
debate
the
question
of
resistance
or
surrender
,
the
rector
descry
Bess
Whitaker
come
towards
him
from
the
opposite
direction
--
a
circumstance
that
greatly
rejoice
him
;
for
,
aware
of
her
strength
and
courage
,
he
feel
sure
he
could
place
as
much
dependence
upon
her
in
this
emergency
as
on
any
man
in
the
county
.
<EOS>
Bess
be
ride
a
stout
,
rough
-
look
nag
,
apparently
well
able
to
sustain
her
weight
,
and
carry
the
redoubtable
horsewhip
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
other
hand
,
Holden
have
be
recognise
by
Bess
,
who
come
up
just
as
he
be
overtaken
and
seize
by
his
assailant
,
one
of
whom
catch
hold
of
his
cassock
,
and
tear
it
from
his
back
,
while
the
other
,
seize
hold
of
his
bridle
,
endeavour
,
in
spite
of
his
effort
to
the
contrary
,
to
turn
his
horse
round
.
<EOS>
many
oath
,
threat
,
and
blow
be
exchange
during
the
scuffle
,
which
no
doubt
would
have
terminate
in
the
rector
's
defeat
,
and
his
compulsory
return
to
Rough
Lee
,
have
it
not
be
for
the
opportune
arrival
of
Bess
,
who
,
swear
as
lustily
as
the
serving
-
man
,
and
brandish
the
horsewhip
,
dash
into
the
scene
of
action
,
and

that
have
occur
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Thomas
Metcalfe
remain
closet
with
the
prisoner
for
a
few
minute
,
and
then
come
forth
,
issue
order
that
all
should
get
ready
to
start
for
Rough
Lee
without
delay
;
whereupon
each
man
empty
his
flagon
,
pocket
the
dice
he
have
be
cog
,
push
aside
the
shuffle
-
board
,
leave
the
loggat
on
the
clay
floor
of
the
barn
,
and
,
grasp
his
weapon
--
halbert
or
caliver
,
as
it
may
be
--
prepared
to
attend
his
leader
.
<EOS>
Sir
Thomas
do
not
relate
,
even
to
the
alsatian
captain
,
what
have
pass
between
him
and
Blackadder
;
but
it
do
not
appear
that
he
place
entire
confidence
in
the
latter
;
for
though
he
cause
his
hand
to
be
unbound
,
and
allow
him
in
consideration
of
his
wounded
state
to
ride
,
he
secretly
direct
Gauntlet
and
Storks
to
keep
near
him
,
and
shoot
him
through
the
head
if
he
attempt
to
escape
.
<EOS>
both
these
personage
be
provide
with
horse
as
well
as
their
leader
,
but
all
the
rest
of
the
party
be
on
foot
.
<EOS>
Metcalfe
make
some
inquiry
after
the
rector
,
but
find
he
be
go
,
he
do
not
concern
himself
further
about
him
.
<EOS>
before
start
,
the
knight
,
who
,
with
all
his
recklessness
,
have
a
certain
sense
of
honesty
,
call
the
girl
who
have
be
leave
in
charge
of
the
hostel
by
Bess
,
and
give
her
a
sum
amply
sufficient
to
cover
all
the
excess
of
his
man
,
add
a
handsome
gratuity
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
the
first
part
of
the
journey
be
accomplish
without
mischance
,
and
the
party
bade
fair
to
arrive
at
the
end
of
it
in
safety
;
but
as
they
enter
the
gorge
,
at
the
extremity
of
which
Rough
Lee
be
situate
,
a
terrific
storm
burst
upon
them
,
compel
them
to
seek
shelter
in
the
mill
,
from
which
they
be
luckily
not
far
distant
at
the
time
.
<EOS>
the
house
be
completely
desert
,
but
they
be
well
able
to
shift
for
themselves
,
and
not
over
scrupulous
in
the
manner
of
do
so
;
and
as
the
remain
of
the
funeral
feast
be
not
remove
from
the
table
,
some
of
the
company
sit
down
to
them
,
while
other
find
their
way
to
the
cellar
.
 
<EOS>
the
storm
be
of
long
continuance
,
much
longer
than
be
agreeable
to
Sir
Thomas
,
and
he
pace
the
room
to
and
fro
impatiently
,
ever
and
anon
walk
to
the
window
or
door
,
to
see
whether
it
have
in
any
degree
abate
,
and
be
constantly
doom
to
disappointment
.
<EOS>
instead
of
diminish
,
it
increase
in
violence
,
and
it
be
now
impossible
to
quit
the
house
with
safety
.
<EOS>
the
lightning
blaze
,
the
thunder
rattle
among
the
overhang
rock
,
and
the
swollen
stream
of
Pendle
Water
roar
at
their
foot
.
<EOS>
Blackadder
be
leave
under
the
care
of
the
two
Alsatians
,
but
while
they
have
shield
their
eye
from
the
glare
of
the
lightning
,
he
throw
open
the
window
,
and
,
spring
through
it
,
make
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
in
such
a
storm
it
be
in
vain
to
follow
him
,
even
if
they
have
dare
to
attempt
it
.
 
<EOS>
in
vain
Sir
Thomas
Metcalfe
fume
and
fret
--
in
vain
he
heap
curse
upon
the
bully
for
their
negligence
--
<EOS>
in
vain
he
hurl
menace
after
the
fugitive
:
the
former
pay
little
heed
to
his
imprecation
,
and
the
latter
be
beyond
his
reach
.
<EOS>
the
notion
begin
to
gain
ground
amongst
the
rest
of
the
troop
that
the
storm
be
the
work
of
witchcraft
,
and
occasion
general
consternation
.
<EOS>
even
the
knight
's
anger
yield
to
superstitious
fear
,
and
as
a
terrific
explosion
shake
the
rafter
overhead
,
and
threaten
to
bring
them
down
upon
him
,
he
fall
on
his
knee
,
and
essay
,
with
unaccustomed
lip
,
to
murmur
a

.
<EOS>
but
he
be
interrupt
;
for
amid
the
deep

succeed
the
awful
crash
,
a
mocking
laugh
be
hear
,
and
the
villainous
countenance
of
Blackadder
,
render
doubly

by
the
white

,
be
see
at
the
casement
.
<EOS>
the
sight
restore
Sir
Thomas
at
once
.
<EOS>
draw
his
sword
he
fly
to
the
window
,
but
before
he
could
reach
it
Blackadder
be
go
.
<EOS>
the
next
flash
show
what
have
befall
him
.
<EOS>
in
step
backwards
,
he
tumble
into
the
mill
-
race
;
and
the
current
,
increase
in
depth
and
force
by
the

rain
,
instantly
sweep

away
.
 
<EOS>
half
an

after
this
,
the
violence
of
the
storm
have
perceptibly

,
and
Sir
Thomas
and
his
companion
begin
to
hope
that
their
speedy

be
at
hand
.
<EOS>
latterly
the
knight
have
abandon
all

of
attack
Rough
Lee
,
but
with
the
prospect
of
fair
weather
his

return
,
and
he
once
more
resolve
to

.
<EOS>
He
be
move
about
among
his

,
strive
to
dispel

,
and
persuade
them
that
the
temp
be
only
the
result
of
natural
cause
,
when
the
door
be
suddenly
throw
open
,
give
entrance
to
Bess
Whitaker
,
who
bear
the
miller
in

.
<EOS>
She
stare
on
see
the
party
assemble
,
and
knit
her

,
but
say
nothing
till
she
have
deposit
Baldwyn
in

,
when
she
observe
to
Sir

,
that
he
seem
to
have
little

in
take

of
a

in
its
owner
's

.
<EOS>
the
knight
excuse
himself
for
the
intrusion
by
say
,
he
have
be
compel
by
the
storm
to
take

there
with

--
a

readily
admit
by
Baldwyn
,
who
be
now
able
to

;
and
the

next
explain
that
he
have
be
to
Rough
Lee
,
and
after
many

,
into
the

of
which
he
do
not

,
have
be
bring
away
by

,
who
have

.
<EOS>
that

he
now
feel
would
be
a

unless

;
and
Bess
,
on
be

appeal

,
affirm

to

would

to

from

.
<EOS>
while

be

discourse
,
Old
Mitton
,
who
it
appear
have
follow

,
arrive
wellnigh
exhaust
,
and
Baldwyn
go
in
search
of
some

for

.
 
<EOS>
by
this

the
storm
have
sufficiently
clear
off
to
allow
the
other
to
take

;
and
though
the
miller
and
Bess
would
fain
have
dissuade
the

from

,
he
be
not
to
be
turn
aside
,
but
,
bid
his
man
attend
him
,
set

.
<EOS>
the
rain
have
cease
,
but
it
be
still
very
dark
.
<EOS>
under
cover
of
the
gloom
,
however
,
they
think
they
could
approach
the
house
unobserve
,
and
obtain
an
entrance
before
Mistress
Nutter
could
be
aware
of

.
<EOS>
in
this

they
pursue
their
way
in
silence
,
and
soon
stand
before
the
gate
.
<EOS>
these
be
fasten
,
but
as
no

appear
to
be
on

watch
,
Sir
Thomas
,
in

low

,
order
some
of
his
man
to

the
wall
,
with
the

of
follow

;
but
scarcely
have

above
the

of
the

than

arquebuss
be
see
,
and
the
man
jump
backwards
,
luckily

bullet
that
whistle

.
<EOS>
an
alarm
be
then
instantly
give
,
voice
be

in

,
mingle

of

.
<EOS>
a
bell
be
ring
from
the
upper
part
of
the

,
and

appear
at

window
.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
some
of
the
man
,
less

than
their

,
contrive
to
scramble
over
the
wall
,
and
be
soon
engage
hand

with

on

.
<EOS>
but
not
alone
have

to
contend
with

like

.
<EOS>
the

-

,
which
have
do
so

during
the
first

upon

house
by
Roger

,
rage

like
so
many
lion
,
rend

,
and
seize

.
<EOS>
to
free

from
these
formidable

be
their
first

,
and
by
dint

thrust
from
pike
,

from
sword
,
and
ball
from
caliver
,
they
succeed
in
slaughter

them
,
and
drive

other
,
badly

,
and

,
away
.
<EOS>
in
do
this
,
however
,
they
themselves
have
sustain
considerable
injury
.
<EOS>
three
of
their
number
be
lie
on

ground
,
in
no
condition
,
from
their
broken
head
,
or
shatter

,
for
renew
the

.
 
<EOS>
thus
,
so
far
as
the
siege
have
go
,
success
seem
to
declare
itself
rather
for
the

than
the

,
when

be
give
to

,
by

of

,
and

of
Sir
Thomas
Metcalfe
and

rest

.
<EOS>
the
knight
be
closely
follow
by
the
alsatian
captain
,
who
,
with

in

,
and
slash

in

,
declare
they
would
make
mince

of
any

oppose

.
<EOS>
Sir
Thomas
be
equally
truculent
in
expression
and
ferocious
in
tone
,
and
as
the
whole
party
lay
about

right
and
leave
,
they
speedily
route
the
defender
of
the
garden
,
and
drive
them
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
flush
by
their
success
,
the
besieger
shout

,
and
Sir
Thomas
roar
out
,
that
ere
many
minute
Nowell
and
Potts
should
be
set
free
,
and

Nutter
capture
.
<EOS>
but
before
he
could
reach
the
main

,
Nicholas
Assheton
,
well
armed
,
and
attend
by
some
dozen
man
,
present

at

.
<EOS>
these
be
instantly
join
by
the
retreat
party
,
and
the
whole
offer
a

of
opponent
,
quite

to

.
<EOS>
two
or
three
of
the
man
near
Nicholas
carry
torch
,
and
their
light
reveal
the
number
on
both

.
 
<EOS>
"
what
!
<EOS>
be
it
you
,
Sir
Thomas
Metcalfe
?
<EOS>
"
cry
the
squire
.
<EOS>
"
do
you
commit
such
outrage
as
this
--
do
you
break
into
habitation
like
a
robber
,
rifle
them
,
and
murder
their
inmate
?
<EOS>
explain
yourself
,
sir
,
or
I
will
treat
you
as
I
would
a
common
plunderer
;
shoot
you
through
the
head
,
or
hang
you
to
the
first
tree
if
I
take
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Zounds
and
fury
!
"
rejoin
Metcalfe
.
<EOS>
"
do
you
dare
to
liken
me
to
a
common
robber
and
murderer
?
<EOS>
take
care
<EOS>
you
do
not
experience
the
same
fate
as
that
with
which
you
threaten
me
,
with
this
difference
only
,
that
the
hangman
--
the
common
hangman
of
Lancaster
--
shall
serve
your
turn
.
<EOS>
I
be
come
hither
to
arrest
a
notorious
witch
,
and
to
release
two
gentleman
who
be
unlawfully
detain
prisoner
by
her
;
and
if

up

,

produce

two
individual
in
question
,
Master
Roger
Nowell
and
Master
Potts
,
I
will
force
my
way
into
the
house
,
and
all
injury
do
to
those
who
oppose
me
will
rest
on
your
head
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
the
two
gentleman
you
have
name
be
perfectly
safe
and
contented
in
their
quarter
,
"
reply
Nicholas
;
"
and
as

foul
and

have
throw
out
against

,
I
cast

back

.
<EOS>
Your
purpose
in
come
hither
be
to
redress

.
<EOS>
how
be
it
you
have
such
a
rout
with

?
<EOS>
how
be
it
I
behold
two
notorious

by

--
man
who
have
stand
in

,
and

for

?
<EOS>
You
can
not

,
and
their
oath
and
threat
go
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
now
tell

,
Sir

,
if

withdraw

man
,
and
quit

,

will

to

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will

,
"
cry

,
infuriate

last

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
follow

into

house
,
and
spare
none
who
oppose

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
be
not
in
yet
,
"
cry
Nicholas
.
 
<EOS>
and
as
he
speak
a
row
of
pike
bristle
around
him
,
hold
the
knight
at
bay
,
while
a
hook
be
fix
in
the
doublet
of
each
of
the
alsatian
captain
,
and
they
be
pluck

and
drag
into

house
.
<EOS>
this
do
,
Nicholas
and
his
man
quickly
retreat
,
and
the
door
be
close
and
bar
upon
the
enraged
and
discomfited
knight
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XV.--THE
PHANTOM
MONK
.
  
<EOS>
many
hour
have
pass
by
,
and
night
have
come
on
--
a
night
profoundly
dark
.
<EOS>
Richard
be
still
lie
where
he
have
fall
at
the
foot
of
Malkin
Tower
;
for
though
he
have
regain
his
sensibility
,
he
be
so
bruise
and
shake
as
to
be
wholly
unable
to
move
.
<EOS>
His
limb
,
stiffened
and
powerless
,
refuse
their
office
,
and
,
after
each
unsuccessful
effort
,
he
sink
back
with
a
groan
.
 
<EOS>
His
sole
hope
be
that
Mistress
Nutter
,
alarm
by
his
prolonged
absence
,
may
come
to
her
daughter
's
assistance
,
and
so
discover
his
forlorn
situation
;
but
as
time
fly
by
,
and
nothing
occur
,
he
give
himself
up
for
lose
.
 
<EOS>

CHAPTER

<EOS>

<EOS>

that
weigh
in
every
breast
,
the
melancholy
troop
pursue
its
way
to
Whalley
.
  
<EOS>
end
of
the
SECOND
BOOK
.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
the
THIRD
.
 
<EOS>
Hoghton
tower
    
CHAPTER
I.--DOWNHAM
MANOR
-
HOUSE
.
  
<EOS>
on
a
lovely
morning
,
about
the
middle
of
July
,
in
the
same
year
as
the
event
previously
narrate
,
Nicholas
Assheton
,
always
astir
with
the
lark
,
issue
from
his
own
dwelling
,
and
saunter
across
the
smooth
lawn
in
front
of
it
.
<EOS>
the
green
eminence
on
which
he
stand
be
shelter
on
the
right
by
a
grove
of
sycamore
,
form
the
boundary
of
the
park
,
and
slope
down
into
a
valley
thread
by
a
small
clear
stream
,
whose
murmuring
,
as
it
dance
over
its
pebbly
bed
,
distinctly
reach
his
ear
in
the
stillness
of
early
day
.
<EOS>
on
the
left
,
partly
in
the
valley
,
and
partly
on
the
side
of
the
acclivity
on
which
the
hall
be
situate
,
nestle
the
little
village
whose
inhabitant
own
Nicholas
as
lord
;
and
,
to
judge
from
their
habitation
,
they
have
reason
to
rejoice
in
their
master
;
for
certainly
there
be
a
cheerful
air
about
Downham
which
the
neighbouring
hamlet
,
especially
those
in
Pendle
Forest
,
sadly
want
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
left
of
the
mansion
,
and
only
separate
from
it
by
the
garden
wall
,
stand
the
church
,
a
venerable
structure
,
date
back
to
a
period
more
remote
even
than
Whalley
Abbey
.
<EOS>
from
the
churchyard
a
view
,
almost
similar
to
that
enjoy
by
the
squire
,
be
obtain
,
though
partially
interrupt
by
the
thick
rounded
foliage
of
a
large
tree
grow
beneath
it
;
and
many
a
traveller
who
come
that
way
linger
within
the
hallowed
precinct
to
contemplate
the
prospect
.
<EOS>
at
the
foot
of
the
hill
be
a
small
stone
bridge
cross
the
stream
.
 
<EOS>
across
the
road
,
and
scarce
thirty
pace
from
the
church
-
gate
,
stand
a
little
alehouse
,
whose
comfortable
fireside
nook
and
good
liquor
be
not
disdain
by
the
squire
.
<EOS>
in
fact
,
to
his
shame
be
it
speak
,
he
be
quite
as
often
to
be
find
there
of
an
evening
as
at
the
hall
.
<EOS>
this
have
more
particularly
be
the
case
since
the
house
be
tenant
by
Richard
Baldwyn
,
who
have
give
up
the
mill
at
Rough
Lee
,
and
take
to
wife
Bess
Whitaker
of
Goldshaw
Booth
,
have
remove
with
her
to
Downham
,
where
he
now
flourish
under
the
special
protection
of
the
squire
.
<EOS>
Bess
have
lose
none
of
her
old
habit
of
command
,
and
it
must
be
confess
that
poor
Richard
play
a
very
secondary
part
in
the
establishment
.
<EOS>
Nicholas
,
as
may
be
suppose
,
be
permit
considerable
licence
by
her
,
but
even
he
have
limit
,
which
she
take
good
care
he
should
not
exceed
.
 
<EOS>
the
Downham
domain
be
well
cultivate
;
the
line
of
demarcation
between
them
and
the
heathy
waste
adjoin
,
be
clearly
trace
out
,
and
you
have
only
to
follow
the
course
of
the
brook
to
see
at
a
glance
where
the
purlieu
of
the
forest
end
,
and
where
Nicholas
Assheton
's
property
commence
:
the
one
be
a
dreary
moor
,
with
here
<EOS>
and
there
a
thicket
upon
it
,
but
more
frequently
a
dangerous
morass
,
cover
with
sulphur
-
colour
mos
;
and
the
other
consisting
of
green
meadow
,
border
in
most
instance
by
magnificent

.
<EOS>
the
contrast
,
however
,
be
not
without
its
charm
;
and
while

sterile
waste
set
off
the
fair

field
around
them
,
and
enhance
their
beauty
,
they
offer
a
wide
,
uninterrupted
expanse
,
over
which
the
eye
could
range
at
will
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
further
side
of
the
valley
,
and
immediately
opposite
the
lawn
whereon
<EOS>
Nicholas
stand
,
the
ground
gradually
arise
,
until

,
which
here
assume

most

,
constitute
the
grand

of

scene
.
<EOS>
nowhere
could
the
lordly
eminence
be
see
to
the
same
advantage
as
from
this
point
,
and
Nicholas
contemplate
it
with
feeling
of
rapture
,
which
no
familiarity
could
diminish
.
<EOS>
the
sun
shine
brightly
upon
its
rounded

,
and
upon
its
seamy
side
,
reveal
all
its
rift
and
ridge
;
add
depth
of
tint
to
its
dusky

,
lay
bare
in
place
by
the
winter

;
lend
new
beauty
to
its
purple
heath
,
and
make
its
grey
sod
glow
as
with
fire
.
<EOS>
so
exhilarating
be
the
prospect
,
that
Nicholas
feel
half
tempt
to
cross
the
valley
and
scale
the
hill
before
break
his
fast
;
but
other
feeling
check
him
,
and
he
turn
towards
the
right
.
<EOS>
here
,
beyond
a
paddock
and
some

,
lie

park
,
small
in
extent
,
but
beautifully
diversify
,
<EOS>
well
stock
with
deer
,
and
boast
much
noble
timber
.
<EOS>
in
the
midst
be
an
exquisite
knoll
,
which
,
besides
command
a
fine
view
of
Pendle

,
Downham
,
and
all

adjacent

,
bring
within

,
on

,
the
ancient

of
Clithero
and
the
height

Whalley
;
and
,

,
the
lovely

vale
through

Ribble

.
<EOS>
this
,

,
be
a

with

,
and
he
have

of
walk

it
,
when

be
arrest
by
a
person
who
come

,
and
who
shout

,
hoarsely

,
to
stay
.
 
<EOS>
the
new
-
comer
be
a
man
of
middle
age
,
with

skin
almost
as

as
a

's
,

,

,

,
that
they

.
<EOS>
He
possess

burly
frame
,
square
,

somewhat

,
though

.
<EOS>
in

,

,

resemble

;

.
<EOS>
the

,

,

,

--

,

,
even

have
be
desire
--
be
name
Lawrence
Fogg
,
an
entire
stranger
to
the
country
,
whom
Nicholas
have
pick
up
at

,
and

for

week
'

,
and
have
never
be
able

.
 
<EOS>
Lawrence
Fogg
like
his
quarter
immensely
,
and

;

,

,

not

understand
,
he
soon

,

,

.
<EOS>
Nicholas
be

,
who

--

,

--
<EOS>
diet

-

,

-

--
enter

,

--
<EOS>
shoot

-

,

,

.
<EOS>
such

,

,

,

,

's

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

find

,

;

,

,

,

small
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

?
'

,

<EOS>

the

junction

and

,

.
<EOS>
little

be

,

inquire
,
in
a
half
-
menace
tone
,
what
he
mean
to
do
with
him
?
 
<EOS>
"
what
do

you
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
will

,
lad
.
<EOS>
I

at
once
to
Whalley
to

;
and
,

,

to

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
an
yo
winna
rescue

by
the
way
<EOS>
,
os
yo
ha
dun
a

notorious
witch
an

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
Tak
heed

yo

,

.
<EOS>
if
ey

aw
,

,

,
ey'n

.
<EOS>
if

,

.
<EOS>
Wan
o
'

ge
<EOS>
wi

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>

"

"

.

.

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

;
"

.
<EOS>

,

.

"
 
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,
"

.

"

,

.
<EOS>
Harkee
,

,

,

.

,

,

?
"

,

.
<EOS>

?
"

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

,

Assheton
upon

,

--

,

--

,

.
<EOS>
I

by
Todmorden
,

Cliviger
.
<EOS>
You
may
as

,

Ralph
will
be
glad
of

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
as

,

's
ill

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
,

,
find

show

,

,

,

to
him
respect
Fogg
,
who
be
not
what
he
represent

;
but
Nicholas
treat

with

;
and
the

mainly
interest
in

,
who
appear

incense

Jem
's

,
cut

by

,

,

's

,
effectually
check

.
 
<EOS>
Fogg
then
order

to
bring

;
but
as
Jem
obstinately

,

be

of
take

on

,
and

in
this

to

stable
,
where
he
be
place
on
a
horse
,
as
direct
by

squire
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II.--THE
PENITENT
's
retreat
.
  
<EOS>
Nicholas
and
Sherborne
return
by
a
different
road
from
that
take
by
the
other
,
and
loiter
so
much
by
the
way
that
they
do
not
arrive
at
the
manor
-
house
until
the
prisoner
and
his
escort
have
set
out
.
<EOS>
probably
this
be
design
,
as
Nicholas
seem
relieved
when
he
learn
they
be
go
.
<EOS>
have
enter
the
house
with
his
brother
-
in
-
law
,
and
conduct
him
to
an
apartment
open
out
of
the
hall
,
usually
occupy
by
Mistress
Assheton
,
and
where
,
in
fact
,
they
find
that
amiable
lady
employ
at
her
embroidery
,
he
leave
Sherborne
with
her
,
and
,
make
some
excuse
for
his
own
hasty
retreat
,
betook
himself
to
another
part
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
mount
the
principal
staircase
,
which
be
of
dark
oak
,
with
richly
-
carve
railing
,
he
turn
into
a
gallery
communicate
with
the
sleep
apartment
,
and
,
after
proceed
more
than
half
-
way
down
it
,
halt
before
a
door
,
which
he
unlock
,
and
enter
a
spacious
but
evidently
disuse
chamber
,
hang
round
with
fade
tapestry
,
and
contain
a
large
gloomy
-
look
bedstead
.
<EOS>
secure
the
door
carefully
after
him
,
Nicholas
raise
the
hanging
in
one
corner
of
the
room
,
and
press
against
a
spring
,
a
slide
panel
fly
open
.
<EOS>
a
screen
be
place
within
,
so
as
to
hide
from
view
the
inmate
of
the
secret
chamber
,
and
Nicholas
,
have
cough
slightly
,
to
announce
his
presence
,
and
receive
an
answer
in
a
low
,
melancholy
female
voice
,
step
through
the
aperture
,
and
stand
within
a
small
closet
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
tenant
by
a
lady
,
whose
feature
and
figure
bear
the
strong
mark
of
affliction
.
<EOS>
Her
person
be
so
attenuate
that
she
look
little
more
than
a
skeleton
--
<EOS>
her
finger
be
long
and
thin
--
her
cheek
hollow
and
deathly
pale
--
<EOS>
her
eye
lustreless
and
deep
sink
in
their
socket
--
and
her
hair
,
once
jetty
as
the
raven
's
wing
,
prematurely
blanch
.
<EOS>
such
be
the
profound
gloom
stamp
upon
her
countenance
,
that
it
be
impossible
to
look
upon
her
without
compassion
;
while
,
in
spite
of
her
wo
-

look
,
there
be
a
noble
character
about
her
that
elevate
the
feeling
into
deep
interest
,
blend
with
respect
.
<EOS>
She
be

beside
a
small
desk
,
with
an
open
Bible
lay
upon
it
,
which
she
be
intently
study
when
the
squire
appear
.
 
<EOS>
"
here
be
a
terrible
text
for
you
,
Nicholas
,
"
she
say
,
regard
him
,

.
<EOS>
"
listen
to
it
,
and
judge
of
its
effect
on
me
.
<EOS>
thus
it
be
write
in
Deuteronomy:--'There
<EOS>
shall
not
be
find
among
you
any
one
that
maketh

son
or

daughter
to
pass

,
or
that
useth

,
or
an
observer

,
or
an

,
or
a
witch
.
'
<EOS>
a
witch
,
Nicholas
--
do
you
mark

word
?
<EOS>
and
yet
more

be
the
next
verse
<EOS>
,
wherein

be
said;--'or
a

,
or
a

with
familiar
spirit
,
or

,
or

.
'
<EOS>
and
then

against
such
offender
in

all
that
do
these
thing
<EOS>
be

Lord
:
and

,

.
'
<EOS>
again
,

,
that
'
the

face

such
,
to

.
'
<EOS>
and
in
Exodus
,

law
be
expressly

SHALT
not

to

.
'
<EOS>
there
be
no

,

.
<EOS>
by

she
must

,
and
human

must
;
carry

.
<EOS>
Nicholas
,
I
be
one
of
the
offender
thus

,
thus

.
<EOS>
I
have
practise
witchcraft
,
consult
with
familiar
spirit
,
and
do
other
abomination
in
the
sight
of
Heaven
;
and
I
ought
to
pay
the
full
penalty
of
my
offence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
do
not
,
I
beseech
you
,
madam
,
"
reply
the
squire
,
"
continue
to
take
this
view
of
your
case
.
<EOS>
however
you
have
sin
,
you
have
make
amend
by
the
depth
and
sincerity
of
your
repentance
.
<EOS>
Your
day
and
night
--
for
you
allow
yourself
only
such
rest
as
nature
force
on
you
,
and
take
even
that
most
unwillingly
--
be
pass
in
constant
prayer
.
<EOS>
Your
abstinence
be
severe
than
any
anchoress
ever
practise
,
for
I
be
sure
for
the
last
month
you
have
not
take
as
much
food
altogether
as
I
consume
in
a
day
;
while
,
not
content
with
this
,
you
perform
act
of
penance
that
afflict
me
beyond
measure
to
think
upon
,
and
which
I
have
strive
in
vain
to
induce
you
to
forego
.
<EOS>
there
will
be
no
occasion
to
deliver
yourself
up
to
justice
,
madam
;
for
,
if
you
go
on
thus
,
and
do
not
deal
with
yourself
a
little
more
mildly
,
your
account
with
this
world
will
be
speedily
settle
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
and
I
should
rejoice
to
think
so
,
Nicholas
,
"
reply
Mistress
Nutter
,
"
if
I
have
any
hope
in
the
world
to
come
.
<EOS>
but
,
alas
!
<EOS>
I
have
none
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
by
any
act
of
penitence
and
contrition
,
expiate
my
offence
.
<EOS>
My
soul
be
darken
by
despair
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
ought
to
give
myself
up
--
that
Heaven
and
man
alike
require
my
life
,
and
I
can
not
reconcile
myself
to
avoid
my
just
doom
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
the
Evil
One
who
put
these
thought
into
your
head
,
"
reply
Nicholas
,
"
and
who
fill
your
heart
with
prompting
of
despair
,
that
he
may
again
obtain
the
mastery
over
it
.
<EOS>
but
take
a
calm
and
more
consolatory
view
of
your
condition
.
<EOS>
human
justice
may
require
a
public
sacrifice
as
an
example
,
but
Heaven
,
will
be
satisfied
with
contrition
in
secret
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
so
,
"
reply
the
lady
,
vainly
strive
to
draw
comfort
from
his
word
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
oh
,
Nicholas
!
<EOS>
you
do
not
know
the
temptation
I
be
expose
to
in
this
chamber
--
<EOS>
the
difficulty
I
experience
in
keep
my
thought
fix
on
one
object
--
the
distraction
I
undergo
--
the
mental
obscuration
--
the
fainting
of
spirit
--
the
bodily
prostration
--
the
terror
,
the
inconceivable
terror
,
that
assail
me
.
<EOS>
sometimes
I
wish
my
spirit
would
flee
away
,
and
be
at
rest
.
<EOS>
rest
!
<EOS>
there
be
none
for
me
--
none
in
the
grave
--
none
beyond
the
grave
--
and
therefore
I
be
afraid
of
death
,
and
still
more
of
the
judgment
after
death
!
<EOS>
Man
may
inflict
all
the
torture
he
could
devise
upon
this
poor
frame
.
<EOS>
I
would
bear
them
all
with
patience
,
with
delight
,
if
I
think
they
would
purchase
me
immunity
hereafter
!
<EOS>
but
with
the
dread
conviction
,
the
almost
certainty
,
that
it
will
be
otherwise
<EOS>
,
I
can
only
look
to
the
final
consummation
with
despair
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
again
I
tell
you
these
suggestion
be
evil
,
"
say
Nicholas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
Son
of
God
,
who
sacrifice
himself
for
man
,
and
by
whose
atonement
all
mankind
hope
for
salvation
,
have
assure
us
that
the
great
sinner
who
repent
shall
be
forgive
,
and
,
indeed
,
be
more
acceptable
in
the
eye
of
Heaven
than
him
who
have
never
err
.
<EOS>
far
be
it
from
me
to
attempt
to
exculpate
you
in
your
own
eye
,
or
extenuate
your
former
criminality
.
<EOS>
You
have
sin
deeply
,
so
deeply
that
you
may
well
shrink
aghast
from
the
contemplation
of
your
past
life
--
may
well
recoil
in
abhorrence
from

--

may

.
<EOS>

--
<EOS>

.

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
CHAPTER
III.--MIDDLETON
HALL
.
  
<EOS>
Middleton
Hall
,
the
residence
of
Sir
Richard
Assheton
,
be
a
large
quadrangular
structure
,
build
entirely
of
timber
,
and
paint
externally
in
black
and
white
checker
-
work
,
fanciful
and
varied
in
design
,
in
the
style
peculiar
to
the
well
class
of
Tudor
house
in
South
Lancashire
and
Cheshire
.
<EOS>
surround
by
a
deep
moat
,
supply
by
a
neighbour
stream
,
and
cross
by
four
drawbridge
,
each
face
by
a
gateway
,
this
vast
pile
of
building
be
divide
into
two
spacious
court
,
one
of
which
contain
the
stable
,
barn
,
and
office
,
while
the
other
be
reserve
for
the
family
and
the
guest
by
whom
the
hospitable
mansion
be
almost
constantly
crowd
.
<EOS>
in
the
last
-
mention
part
of
the
house
be
a
great
gallery
,
with
deeply
embaye
window
fill
with
paint
glass
,
a
floor
of

,
wall
of
the
same
dark
lustrous
material
,
hang
with
portrait
of
stiff

,
some
in
ruff
and

,
and
some
in
a

of
an
early
period
among
whom
be
Margaret
Barton
,
who
bring
the
manor
of
Middleton
into
the
family
;
frown
warrior
,
begin
with
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
,
knight
-

of
England
in
the

IV
.
,
and
surname
"
the
black
of
Assheton
-
under

line
,
"
the

of

house
,
and

of
Margaret
Barton
before
mention
,
and

with
Sir
Richard
Assheton
,
grandfather
of

present

,

of

;
grave

,

--
a

run
through

,
and
show
they

to
one
line
--
a

,

of

or

,
and
black
and
shine
as

,

.
<EOS>
here
,

,
above

,

be
long

look

,

;
while
,

,
correspond

lead

all

,

,

,

,
like

some
"
tall
ammiral
,
"
be
think
from
this

,
as
well

from
its
form
,
to
resemble
"
a
ship

.
"
<EOS>
the
low
beam
be

and

,

.
<EOS>
as

,
