<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
a

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
on

,

person

,

--

,

;

.
<EOS>
profound

,

--
while

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They
be

in
deep

,
show

be
interested
;
and
,

,
many
an

be
heave

Richard
Assheton
,
while
a

,
more

,
dim

of
his
sister
's
eye
,
and
her
hand
seek
by
its

to
re
-
assure

.
 
<EOS>
They
be
talk
of
Alizon
,
of
her
peculiar
and
distressing

,
and
of
the
young
man
's
hopeless

.
<EOS>
She
be
the

,
for

's

be
in

into

's
willing

;
but
new
cause

have
be
give

,

have

,

James
Device
's

,

.
<EOS>
the

have
only

,
have

--

be
,
firstly
,

--

,

.
<EOS>
with

Richard

,
and
he

,

,
to
the
second
,
provide

.
<EOS>
Nicholas
try
to
rally

on

,

all
would

,

be

;
but

be

,
and

be
soon

.
<EOS>
the

would
fain

have
see
Alizon
,

,
understand

always

,

.
<EOS>
Richard
urge

,

,

,
as

;
but

score

be

--
and

secure

large

he
have
obtain
beneath

doublet
,
he

,
Robin
,
who
seem

he
have

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
Richard
watch

cross

drawbridge
,
and

road
towards
Rochdale
,
and
,

hand
with

,

and

sister
.
 
<EOS>
Dorothy
be
easily
persuade
to
take
a

in
the
garden
with
her
brother
,
and
during

he
confide

her
all
he
have
hear

.
<EOS>
Her
alarm
at
Jem
Device
's
threat
be
much
great
than
his
own
;
and
,
though

entertain

to

,
and

,
still
,

Alizon
's

,

dread

,
and
more

.
<EOS>
Alizon

<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV.--THE
gorge
of
CLIVIGER
.
  
<EOS>
the
sun
have
already
set
as
Nicholas
Assheton
reach
Todmorden
,
then
a
very
small
village
indeed
,
and
alight
at
a
little
inn
near
the
church
,
find
the
ale
so
good
,
and
so
many
boon
companion
assemble
to
discuss
it
,
that
he
would
fain
have
tarry
with
them
for
an
hour
or
so
;
but
prudence
,
for
once
,
get
the
well
of
inclination
,
and
suggest
that
he
have
fifteen
or
sixteen
mile
still
to
ride
,
over
a
rough
and
lonely
road
,
part
of
which
lie
through
the
gorge
of
Cliviger
,
a
long
and
solitary
pass
among
the
English
Apennines
,
and
,
moreover
,
have
a
large
sum
of
money
about
him
,
he
tear
himself
away
by
a
great
effort
.
 
<EOS>
on
quit
the
smile
valley
of
Todmorden
,
and
draw
near
the
dangerous
defile
before
mention
,
some
misgiving
cross
him
,
and
he
almost
reproach
himself
with
foolhardiness
in
venture
within
it
at
such
an
hour
,
and
wholly
unattended
.
<EOS>
several
recent
case
of
robbery
,
some
of
them
attend
by
murder
,
have
occur
within
the
pass
;
and
these
now
occur
so
forcibly
to
the
squire
,
that
he
be
half
inclined
to
ride
back
to
Todmorden
,
and
engage
two
or
three
of
the
toper
he
have
leave
at
the
inn
to
serve
him
as
an
escort
as
far
as
Burnley
,
but
he
dismiss
the
idea
almost
as
soon
as
form
,
and
,
cast
one

at
the
green
and
woody
slope
around
him
,
strike
spur
into
Robin
,
and
dash
into
the
gorge
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
right
tower
a
precipice
,
on
the
bare
crest
of
which
stand
a
heap
of
stone
pile
like
a
column
--
the
remain
,
probably
,
of
a
cairn
.
<EOS>
on
this
commanding
point
Nicholas
perceive
a
female
figure
,
dilate
to
gigantic
proportion
against
the
sky
,
who
,
as
far
as
he
could
distinguish
,
seem
watch
him
,
and

;

.
 
<EOS>
precipitous

rock
,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

a
cursedly
bad
look
about

eye
--
a

.
<EOS>
what

the

must
be
!
<EOS>
without

.
<EOS>
why
,

have
this

's

,

.
<EOS>
oh
,

<EOS>
to

--

,

,

,

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
v.--the
end

MALKIN
TOWER
.
  
<EOS>

have

,

,

above
them
,
with
his
wide
heavy
wing
and
long

.
<EOS>
grip
howl
at

,
but
be
instantly
check
by
his

,
and
they

.
 
<EOS>
They
be
now
by
the
side
of
Pendle
Water
,
and

of

.
<EOS>
what

's

!
<EOS>
the

be

;

;

own

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
how

!
<EOS>
speed

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
be

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VI.--HOGHTON
TOWER
.
  
<EOS>
about

.

,

of
sheep
and
oxen
,
turkey
and
goose
,
pullet
and
capon
,
fish
,
bread
,
and
vegetable
,
all
bent
for
Hoghton
Tower
;
for
though
Sir
Richard
have
make
vast
preparation
for
his
guest
,
he
find
his
supply
,
great
as
they
be
,
wholly
inadequate
to
their
want
.
<EOS>
crack
their
whip
in
answer
to
the
shout
with
which
they
be
greet
,
the
purveyor
gallop
on
,
many
a
hungry
wight
look

after
them
.
 
<EOS>
Nicholas
and
his
companion
be
now
at
the
entrance
to
Hoghton
Park
,
through
which
the
Darwen
course
,
after
wash
the
base
of
the
rocky

on
which
the
mansion
be
situate
.
<EOS>
here
four
yeoman
of
the
guard
,
arm
with
halbert
,
and
an

,
be
station
,
and
no

be

an

Sir
Richard

.
<EOS>
possess
a
pass
,
the

and
his
companion
with
their
attendant
be
,
of
course
,
allow
to
enter
;
but
the
throng
accompany

be
send
over

bridge
,
and
along
a
devious
road
skirt

park
,
which
,
though
it
go
more
than
a
mile
round
,
eventually
bring
them
to

.
 
<EOS>
Hoghton
Park
,
though
not
very
extensive
,
boast
a
great
deal
of
magnificent

,
and
in
some

be
so

woode
,
that
,
accord

Dr.
Kuerden
,
"
a
man
pass
through
it
could
scarcely
have
see
the
sun
shine
at
middle
of
day
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
into
one
of
these
tenebrous
grove
the
horseman
now
plunge
,
and
for
some
moment
be
bury
in
the
gloom
produce
by
matted
and

.
<EOS>
issue
once
more
into
the
warm
sunshine
,
they
traverse
a
long
and
beautiful
silvan
glade
,
skirt
by
ancient
oak
,
with
mighty
arm
and
gnarl
limb
--
the
patriarch
of
the
forest
.
<EOS>
in
the
open
ground
on
the
left
be
scatter
a
few
ash
-
tree
,
and
beneath
them
browse
a
herd
of
fallow

;
while
cross
the
low
end
of
the
glade
be
a
large
herd
of
red
deer
,
for
which
the
park
be
famous
,
the
hind
trip
nimbly
and
timidly
away
,
but
the
lordly
stag
,
with
their
branching
antler
,
stand
for
a
moment
at
gaze
,
and
disdainfully
regard
the
intruder
on
their
domain
.
<EOS>
little
do
they
think
how
soon
and
severely
their
courage
would
be
try
,
or
how
soon
the
_
mort
<EOS>
_
would
be
sound
for
their
_
pryse
_
by
the
huntsman
.
<EOS>
but
if
,
happily

,
the
poor

-

could

,

be

,

predict

,
and

noble
hart
which

by

's

.
<EOS>
as

,
the

toss

,
and
plunge
into

adjoin

;
but
the
squire
note
the
spot
where
he
have

.
 
<EOS>
the
glade
lead
them
into
the
chase
,
a
glorious
hunting
-
ground
of
about
two
mile
in
circumference
,
surround
by
an
amphitheatre
of
wood
,
and
stud
by
noble
forest

.
<EOS>
variety
and
beauty
be
lend
to
it
by
an
occasional
knoll
crown
with
timber
,
or
by
numerous
ferny
dell
and
dingle
.
<EOS>
as
the
horseman
enter
upon
the
chase
,
they
observe
at
a
short
distance
from
them
a
herd
of
the
beautiful
,
but
fierce
wild
cattle
,
originally
from
Bowland
Forest
,
and
still
preserve
in
the
park
.
<EOS>
white
and
spangle
in
colour
,
with
short
sharp
horn
,
fine
eye
,
and
small
shapely
limb
,
these
animal
be
of
untameable
fierceness
,
possess
of
great
cunning
,
and
ever
ready
to
assault
any
one
who
approach
them
.
<EOS>
They
would
often
attack
a
solitary
individual
,
gore
him
,
and
trample
him
to
death
.
<EOS>
consequently
,
they
be
far
more
dreaded
than
the
wild
-

,
with
which
,
as
with
every
other
sort

,
the

wood
be
plentifully
stock
.
<EOS>
well
aware
of
the
danger
they
run
,
the
party
watch
the
herd
narrowly
and

,
and
would
have
gallop
on
;
but
this
would
only
have
provoke
pursuit
,
and
the
wild
cattle
be
swift
than
any
horse
.
<EOS>
suddenly
,
a
milkwhite
bull
trot
out
from
the
rest
of

,
bellow

,
lash
his
side
with

,
and
lower
his

to

,
as

.
<EOS>
His

be
speedily
follow
by
the
other
,
and
the

begin
to
beat

and
roar

.
<EOS>
much
alarm
by
these
hostile
manifestation
,
the
party
be
debate
whether
to
stand
the
onset
,
or
trust
to

of
their
steed
for

;
when
just
as

,
with

and

,
be

,

of
some

,
who
,
arm
with
long
pole
point

,
issue

from
an

opening
upon

.
<EOS>
at

,
the
whole

wheel

and

,
but
be
pursue
by
the

till

be

into

furth

.
<EOS>
six

remain

over

during

,
in

that
the
royal
hunting
-
party
may
not

,
and

echo

.
 
<EOS>
while
this
be
go

,
the

,

on

,

,

long

,

have

.
 
<EOS>
at

,
partly

,

,

,
rise

-

be

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

have

;

,

,

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
rouse

,

;

,

,

--

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

a

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Admittance

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
that

be

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
as

force

,

be

as

,

,

,

's

,

.
<EOS>

,

have

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
but

;

,

,

,

after

and

,
who
have

with

.
 
<EOS>
appropriate
chiefly
to
stable
and
other
office
,
the
base
court
of
Hoghton
Tower
consist
of
building
of
various
date
,
the
great
part
belong
to
Elizabeth
's
time
,
though
some
may
be
assign
to
an
early
period
,
while
many
alteration
and
addition
have
be
recently
make
,
in
anticipation
of
the
king
's
visit
.
<EOS>
date
back
as
far
as
Henry
II
.
<EOS>
,
the
family
have
originally
fix
their
residence
at
the
foot
of
the
hill
,
on
the
bank
of
the
Darwen
;
but
in
process
of
time
,
sway
by
prouder
notion
,
they
mount
the
craggy
height
above
,
and
build
a
tower
upon
their
crest
.
<EOS>
It
be
melancholy
to
think
that
so
glorious
a
pile
,
teem
with
so
many
historical
recollection
,
and
so

situate
,
should
be
abandon
,
and
suffer
to
go
to
decay;--the
<EOS>
family
have
,
many
year
ago
,
quit
it
for
Walton
Hall
,
near
Walton
-
le
-
Dale
,
and
consign
it
to
the
occupation
of
a
few
gamekeeper
.
<EOS>
Bereft
of
its
venerable
timber
,
its
court
grass
-
grow
,
its
fine
oak
staircase
rot
and
dilapidate
,
its
domestic
chapel
neglect
,
its
marble
chamber
broken
and
ruinous
,
its
wainscoting
and
ceiling
crack
and
mouldering
,
<EOS>
its
painting
mildew
and
half
efface
,
Hoghton
Tower
present
only
the
wreck
of
its
former
grandeur
.
<EOS>
Desolate
indeed
be
its
hall
,
and
their
glory
for
ever
depart
!
<EOS>
however
,
this
history
have
to
do
with
it
in
the
season
of
its
great

;
when
it
glisten
with

and

,
and
resound
with
loud

and

;
when
stately
noble
and
lovely

be
see
in

,
and
a

be
serve
in
the
great

;
when
its
countless
chamber
be
fill
to

,
and
its

echo
with
hasty

;
when
the
base
court
be
full
of

and

,
and
enliven
by
the

of

and

;
when
there
be
daily

in
the

,
and
nightly

and

in

be
with
Hoghton
Tower
at
this
season
that
the
present
tale
have
to
do
,
and
not
with
it
as
it
be
now
--
silent
,

,

,

,
but
still
whisper
of
the
glory
of

past
,
still
tell
of
the
kingly

that
once

.
 
<EOS>
the
base
court
be
divide
from
the
court
of
lodging
by
the
great

and
domestic

.
<EOS>
a
narrow
vaulted
passage
on
either

lead
to
the
upper
quadrangle
,
the

of
which
be
magnificent
,
and
far

in

and

to
the
rest
of

,
the

of
which
,

,

.
<EOS>
the
whole

of

upper

be

,
with

of

window
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
marble

,

,
have
be

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
a

stone

lead

,
and

be

,

--
a

.
<EOS>
in
this

all

,

here

be

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

;

,

pass

--

be

in

-
of
-

'

.
 
<EOS>
long

run
round
the
upper
story
in
this

of
the
mansion
,
and
communicate
with
an

,

,

be
,

,

,

be
find

for

,
many
be
send
to

new
erection
in

,
which
have
be
plan
to

by

.
<EOS>
the
noble
and
gentleman
be
,
however
,
far

by
their

,
and
the
confusion
occasion
by

run

and
fro
of
the
various

of

,

.
<EOS>
doublet
have
to
be
brush
,
ruff

,

,

,
and
all
with

great
possible

;
so
that
,

upon
Hoghton
Tower
,

be

from

to

.
<EOS>
many
favour
servant
sleep
in
truckle

bed
in
their
master
'

;
but
other
,
not

,
and

even
in

--
for

room
,
and

near
the
roof
,
be

--
sleep

in

,

sit

,
keep

with

cook
and
their

,
who
be

all

in

for
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
such
be
the
state
of
thing
inside
Hoghton
Tower
early
on
the
eventful
morning
in
question
,
and
out
of
door
,
especially
in
the
base
court
which
Nicholas
be
traverse
,
the
noise
,

,
and

be
equally
great
.
<EOS>
wide
as
be
the
area
,
it
be
fill
with
various
personage
,
some
newly
arrive
,
and
seek
information
as
to
their
quarter
--
not
very
easily
obtain
,
<EOS>
for
it
seem
every
body
's
business
to
ask
question
,
and
no
one
be
to
answer

--
<EOS>
some
gather
in
group
round
the
falconer
and
huntsman
,
who
have
suddenly
rise
into
great
importance
;
other
,
and
these
be
for
the
most
part
smart
young
page
,
in
brilliant
livery
,
chattering
,
and
make
love
to
every
pretty
damsel
they
encounter
,
put
them
out
of
countenance
by
their
licence
and
strange
oath
,
and
rouse
the
anger
of
their
parent
,
and
the
jealousy
of
their
rustic
admirer
;
other
,
of
a
graver
sort
,
with
dress
of
formal
cut
,
and
puritanical
expression
of
countenance
,
shrug

,
and
look
sourly
on
the
whole
proceeding
--
luckily
they
be
in
the
minority
,
for
the
generality
of
the
group
be
compose
of
lively
and
light
-
hearted
people
,
bent
apparently
upon
amusement
,
and
tolerably
certain
of
find
it
.
<EOS>
through
these
various
group
numerous
lackey
be
pass
swiftly
and
continuously
to
and
fro
,
bear
a
cap
,
a
mantle
,
or
a
sword
,
and
push
aside
all
who
interfere
with
their
progress
,
with
a
"
by
your
leave
,
my
master
--
your

,
fair

,
"
out
of
my
way
,
knave
!
"
<EOS>
and
,
as
the
stable
occupy
one
entire
angle
of
the
court
,
there
be
groom
without
end
dress
the
horse
at
the
door
,
water
them
at
the
troughs
,
or
lead
them
about
amid
the
admiring
or

bystander
.
<EOS>
the
King
's
horse
be
,
of
course
,
object
of
special

,
and
such
as
could
obtain
a
glimpse
of
them
and
of

royal
coach
think

especially
favour
.
<EOS>
besides
what
be
go
forward
below
,
the
window
look
into
the
court
be
all
full
of
curious
observer
,
and
much
loud
conversation
take
place
between
those
place
at
them
and
their
friend
underneath
.
<EOS>
from
all
this
some
idea
will
be
form
of
the
tremendous
din
that
prevail
;
but
though
with
much

there
be

,
still
less

,
for
yeoman
of
the
guard
be
station
at
various

,
perfect
order
be
maintain
.
<EOS>
several
minstrel
,
mummer
,
and
merry
-
maker
,
in
various
fantastic
habit
,
swell
the
throng
,
enliven
it
with
their
strain
or
feat
;
and

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII.--THE
ROYAL
DECLARATION
concern
LAWFUL
sport

.
  
<EOS>
not

King

of
Buckingham
,

in

,

,

,

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

pie
.
<EOS>
close
at
hand
be
a
clear
cold
spring
,
in
which
numerous
flask
of
wine
be
immerse
.
<EOS>
a
few
ember
,
too
,
have
be
light
,
on
which
carbonadoe
of
venison
be
prepare
.
 
<EOS>
no
great
form
or
ceremony
be
observe
at
the
entertainment
.
<EOS>
Sir
John
Finett
and
Sir
Thomas
Hoghton
be
in
close
attendance
upon
the
monarch
,
and
minister
to
his
want
;
but
several
of
the
noble
and
gentleman
stretch
themselves
on
the
sward
,
and
address
themselves
to
the
viand
set
before
them
by
the
page
.
<EOS>
none
of
the
dame
dismount
,
and
few
could
be
prevail
upon
to
take
any
refreshment
.
<EOS>
besides
the
flask
of
wine
,
there
be
two
barrel
of
ale
in
a
small
cart
,
draw
by
a
mule
,
both
of
which
be
broach
.
<EOS>
the
whole
scene
be
picturesque
and
pleasing
,
and
well
calculated
to
gratify
one
so
fond
of
silvan
sport
as
the
monarch
for
whom
it
be
provide
.
 
<EOS>
in
the
midst
of
all
this
tranquillity
and
enjoyment
an
incident
occur
which
interrupt
it
as
completely
as
if
a
thunder
-
storm
have
suddenly
come
on
.
<EOS>
just
when
the
mirth
be
at
the
high
,
and
when
the
flow
cup
be
at
many
a
lip
,
a
tremendous
bellowing
,
follow
by
the
crashing
of
branch
,
be
hear
in
the
adjoin
thicket
.
<EOS>
all
start
to
their
foot
at
the
appalling
sound
,
and
the
King
himself
turn
pale
.
 
<EOS>
"
what
in
Heaven
's
name
can
it
be
,
Sir
Richard
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquire
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
a
drove
of
wild
cattle
,
"
reply
the
baronet
,
tremble
.
 
<EOS>
"
wild
cattle
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculate
James
,
in
great
alarm
;
"
and
sae
near
us
.
<EOS>
zounds
!
<EOS>
we
shall
be
trample
and
gore
to
death
by
these
bull
of
Basan
.
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
,
ye
be
a
fause
traitor
thus
to
endanger
the
safety
o
'
your
sovereign
,
and
ye
shall
answer
for
it
,
if
harm
come
o
'
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
unable
to
account
for
it
,
sire
,
"
stammer
the
frightened
baronet
.
<EOS>
"
I
give
special
direction
to
the
pricker
to
drive
the
beast
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
ye
shouldna
keep
sic
deevil
i
'
your
park
,
man
,
"
cry
the
monarch
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
eh
!
<EOS>
what
be
that
?
"
 
<EOS>
amidst
all
this
consternation
and
confusion
the
bellowing
be
redouble
,
and
the
crashing
of
branch
draw
near
and
nearer
,
and
Nicholas
Assheton
rush
forward
with
the
King
's
horse
,
say
,
"
Mount
,
sire
;
mount
,
and
away
!
"
 
<EOS>
but
James
be
so
much
alarm
that
his
limb
refuse
to
perform
their
office
,
and
he
be
unable
to
put
foot
in
the
stirrup
.
<EOS>
see
his
condition
,
Nicholas
cry
out
,
"
Pardon
,
my
liege
;
but
at
a
moment
of
peril
like
the
present
,
one
must
not
stand
on
ceremony
.
"
 
<EOS>
so
say
,
he
take
the
King
round
the
waist
,
and
place
him
on
his
steed
.
 
<EOS>
at
this
juncture
,
a
loud
cry
be
hear
,
and
a
man
in
extremity
of
terror
issue
from
the
wood
,
and
dash
towards
the
hollow
.
<EOS>
close
on
his
heel
come
the
drove
of
wild
cattle
,
and
,
just
as
he
gain
the
very
verge
of
the
descent
,
the
foremost
of
the
herd
overtook
him
,
and
lower
his
curled
head
,
catch
him
on
the
point
of
his
horn
,
and
throw
him
forwards
to
such
a
distance
that
he
alight
with
a
heavy
crash
almost
at
the
King
's
foot
.
<EOS>
satisfied
,
apparently
,
with
their
vengeance
,
or
alarm
by
the
numerous
assemblage
,
the
drove
instantly
turn
tail
and
be
pursue
into
the
depth
of
the
forest
by
the
pricker
.
 
<EOS>
have
recover
his
composure
,
James
bid
some
of
the
attendant
raise
the
poor
wretch
,
who
be
lie
groan
upon
the
ground
,
evidently
so
much
injure
as
to
be
unable
to
move
without
assistance
.
<EOS>
His
garb
be
that
of
a
forester
,
and
his
bulk
--
for
he
be
stoutly
and
squarely
build
--
have
contribute
,
no
doubt
,
to
the
severity
of
the
fall
.
<EOS>
when
he
be
lift
from
the
ground
,
Nicholas
instantly
recognise
in
his
blacken
and
distorted
feature
those
of
Christopher
Demdike
.
 
<EOS>
"
what
?
"
<EOS>
he
exclaim
,
rush
towards
him
.
"
<EOS>
be
it
thou
,
villain
?
"
 
<EOS>
the
sufferer
only
reply
by
a
look
of
intense
malignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
eh
!
what
--
d'ye
ken
wha
it
be
?
"
demand
James
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
by
my
saul
!
<EOS>
I
fear
the
puir
fellow
have
maist
of
his
bane
break
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
great
matter
if
they
be
,
"
reply
Nicholas
,
"
and
it
may
save
the
application
of
torture
in
case
your
Majesty
desire
to
put
any
question
to
him
.
<EOS>
chance
have
most
strangely
throw
into
your
hand
one
of
the
most
heinous
offender
in
the
kingdom
,
who
have
long
escape
justice
,
but
who
will
at
length
meet
the
punishment
of
his
crime
.
<EOS>
the
villain
be
Christopher
Demdike
,
son
of
the
foul
hag
who
perish
in
the
flame
on
the
summit
of
Pendle
Hill
,
and
captain
of
a
band
of
robber
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
what
!
<EOS>
be
the
knave
a
warlock
and
a
riever
?
<EOS>
"
demand
James
,
regard
Demdike
with
abhorrence
,
mingle
with
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
both
,
sire
,
"
reply
Nicholas
,
"
and
an
assassin
to
boot
.
<EOS>
He
be
a
diabolical
villain
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
let
him
be
take
to
Hoghton
Tower
,
and
keep
in
some
strong
and
secure
place
till
we
have
leisure
to
examine
him
,
"
say
<EOS>
James,--"and
see
that
he
be
visit
by
some
skilful
chirurgeon
,
for
we
wadna
<EOS>
hae
him
dee
,
and
sae
rob
the
woodie
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Demdike
,
who
appear
to
be
in
great
agony
,
now
force
himself
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
make
important
disclosure
to
your
Majesty
,
"
he
say
,
in
hoarse
and
broken
tone
,
"
if
you
will
hear
them
.
<EOS>
I
be
not
the
only
offender
who
have
escape
from
justice
,
"
he
add
,
glance
vindictively
at
nicholas--"there
be
another
,
a
notorious
witch
and
murderess
,
who
be
still
screen
from
justice
.
<EOS>
I
can
reveal
her
hiding
-
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
Majesty
will
not
give
heed
to
such
a
villain
's
fabrication
?
"
say
Nicholas
.
 
<EOS>
"
be
they
fabrication
,
sir
?
"
rejoin
James
,
somewhat
sharply
.
<EOS>
"
We
maun
hear
and
judge
.
<EOS>
the
snake
,
though
scotch
,
will
still
bite
,
it
seem
.
<EOS>
We
hae
hangit
a
Highland
cateran
without
trial
afore
this
,
and
we
may
be
tempt
to
tak
the
law
into
our
ain
hand
again
.
<EOS>
bear
the
villain
hence
.
<EOS>
see
he
be
dispose
of
as
already
direct
,
and
take
good
care
he
be
strictly
guard
.
<EOS>
and
now
gie
us
a
crossbow
,
Sir
Richard
Hoghton
,
and
bid
the
pricker
drive
the
deer
afore
us
,
for
we
wad
try
our
skill
as
a
marksman
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
while
Demdike
be
place
on
the
litter
of
green
bough
which
have
recently
sustain
a
noble
burthen
in
the
fall
hart
,
and
in
this
sort
be
convey
to
Hoghton
Tower
,
James
ride
with
his
retinue
towards
a
long
glade
,
where
,
receive
a
crossbow
from
the
huntsman
,
he
take
up
a
favourable
position
behind
a
large
oak
,
and
several
herd
of
deer
be
drive
before
him
,
he
select
his
quarry
,
and
deliberately
take
aim
at
them
,
contrive
in
the
course
of
an
hour
to
bring
down
four
fat
buck
,
and
to
maim
as
many
other
,
which
be
pull
down
by
the
hound
.
<EOS>
and
with
this
slaughter
he
be
content
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Hoghton
then
inform
his
Majesty
that
a
huge
boar
,
which
,
in
sporting
phrase
,
have
leave
the
sounder
five
year
,
have
break
into
the
park
the
night
before
,
and
have
be
route
amongst
the
fern
.
<EOS>
the
age
and
size
of
the
animal
be
know
by
the
print
of
the
foot
,
the
toe
be
round
and
thick
,
the
edge
of
the
hoof
wear
and
blunt
,
the
heel
large
,
and
the
guard
,
or
dew
-
claw
,
great
and
open
,
from
all
which
appearance
it
be
adjudge
by
the
baronet
to
be
"
a
great
old
boar
,
not
to
be
refuse
.
"
 
<EOS>
James
at
once
agree
to
hunt
him
,
and
the
hound
be
take
away
,
six
couple
of
magnificent
mastiff
,
of
the
Lancashire
breed
,
be
bring
forward
,
and
the
monarch
,
under
the
guidance
of
Sir
Richard
Hoghton
and
the
chief
huntsman
,
repair
to
an
adjoin
thicket
,
in
which
the
boar
feed
and
couch
.
 
<EOS>
on
arrive
near
his
den
,
a
boar
-
spear
be
give
to
the
King
,
and
the
pricker
advance
into
the
wood
,
presently
afterwards
rear
the
enormous
brute
.
<EOS>
sallye
forth
,
and
freame
furiously
,
he
be
instantly
assail
by
the
mastiff
;
but
,
notwithstanding
the
number
of
his
assailant
,
he
make
light
of
them
,
shake
them
from
his
bristly
hide
,
crush
them
beneath
his
horny
foot
,
thrust
at
them
with
his
sharpened
tusk
,
and
commit
terrible
devastation
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
repeat
charge
be
make
upon
the
savage
animal
by
James
,
but
it
be
next
to
impossible
to
get
a
blow
at
him
for
some
time
;
and
when
at
length
the
monarch
make
the
attempt
,
he
strike
too
low
,
and
hit
him
on
the
snout
,
upon
which
the
infuriate
boar
,
find
himself
wound
,
spring
towards
the
horse
,
and
rip
him
open
with
his
tusk
.
 
<EOS>
the
noble
charger
instantly
roll
over
on
his
side
,
expose
the
royal
huntsman
to
the
fury
of
his
merciless
assailant
,
whose
tusk
must
have
plough
his
flesh
,
if
at
this
moment
a
young
man
have
not
ride
forward
,
and
at
the
great
personal
risk
approach
the
boar
,
and
,
strike
straight
downward
,
cleave
the
heart
of
the
fierce
brute
with
his
spear
.
 
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
the
King
,
have
be
disengage
by
the
pricker
from
his
wounded
steed
,
which
be
instantly
put
out
of
its
agony
by
the
sword
of
the
chief
huntsman
,
look
for
his
deliverer
,
and
,
discover
him
to
be
Richard
Assheton
,
be
loud
in
his
expression
of
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
"
Faith
!
<EOS>
ye
maun
claim
a
boon
at
our
hand
,
"
say
James
.
<EOS>
"
It
maun
never
be
say
the
King
be
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
what
can
we
do
for
you
,
lad
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
for
myself
nothing
,
sire
,
"
reply
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
"
but
for
another
meikle
--
be
that
what
ye
wad
<EOS>
hae
us
infer
?
<EOS>
"
cry
the
King
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Aweel
,
the
lassie
shall
hae
strict
justice
do
her
;
but
for
your
ain
sake
we
maun
inquire
into
the
matter
.
<EOS>
meantime
,
wear
this
,
"
he
add
,
take
a
magnificent
sapphire
ring
from
his
finger
,
"
and
,
if
you
should
ever
need
our
aid
,
send
it
to
us
as
a
token
.
"
 
<EOS>
Richard
take
the
gift
,
and
knelt
to
kiss
the
hand
so
graciously
extended
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
another
horse
have
be
provide
for
the
monarch
,
and
the
enormous
boar
,
with
his
foot
upwards
and
tie
together
,
be
suspend
upon
a
pole
,
and
borne
on
the
shoulder
of
four
stout
varlet
as
the
grand
trophy
of
the
chase
.
 
<EOS>
when
the
royal
company
issue
from
the
wood
a
strike
of
nine
be
blow
by
the
chief
huntsman
,
and
such
of
the
cavalcade
as
still
remain
on
the
field
be
collect
together
,
the
party
cross
the
chase
,
and
take
the
direction
of
Hoghton
Tower
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IX.--THE
BANQUET
.
  
<EOS>
on
the
King
's
return
to
Hoghton
Tower
,
order
be
give
by
Sir
Richard
for
the
immediate
service
of
the
banquet
;
it
be
the
hospitable
baronet
's
desire
that
festivity
should
succeed
each
other
so
rapidly
as
to
allow
of
no
tedium
.
 
<EOS>
the
_
coup
-
d'oeil
_
of
the
banquet
hall
on
the
monarch
's
entrance
be
magnificent
.
<EOS>
panel
with
black
lustrous
oak
,
and
light
by
mullion
window
,
fill
with
stained
glass
and
emblazon
with
the
armorial
bearing
of
the
family
,
the
vast
and
lofty
hall
be
hang
with
banner
,
and
decorate
with
panoply
and
trophy
of
the
chase
.
<EOS>
three
long
table
run
down
it
,
each
contain
a
hundred
cover
.
<EOS>
at
the
low
end
be
station
the
herald
,
the
pursuivant
,
and
a
band
of
yeoman
of
the
guard
,
with
the
royal
badge
,
a
demi
-
rose
crown
,
impale
with
a
demi
-
thistle
,
weave
in
gold
on
their
doublet
,
and
have
fringed
pole
-
axis
over
their
shoulder
.
<EOS>
behind
them
be
a
richly
carve
oak
screen
,
conceal
the
passage
lead
to
the
buttery
and
kitchen
,
in
which
the
clerk
of
the
kitchen
,
the
pantler
,
and
the
yeoman
of
the
cellar
and
ewery
,
be
hurry
to
and
fro
.
<EOS>
above
the
screen
be
a
gallery
,
occupy
by
the
trumpeter
and

;

.

<EOS>
the
strife
rage
furiously
for
some
time
,
and
,
as
the
champion
appear
pretty
well
matched
,
it
be
not

to
say
how

would
terminate
,
when
chance
seem
to
decide
in
favour
of
Davy
Droman
;
for
,
in
deal
a
heavy
blow
than
usual
,
Archie
's
dagger
snap
in
twain
,
leave
him
at
the
mercy
of
his

.
<EOS>
on
this
the
doughty
Davy
,
crow
lustily
like
chanticleer
,
call
upon
him
to
yield
;
but
Archie
be
so

at
his

,
that
,

,
he
spring

,
and
with

break
weapon
deal

on

side

the

,
not

,
but

on

.
<EOS>
the
punishment
he
have
receive
be
enough
for
poor
Davy
.
<EOS>
He
make
no
attempt
to
rise
,
and
Archie
,
crow
in
his

,

upon

,

,
be

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
with

;
and
,

be

,

<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
chapter
X.--EVENING
ENTERTAINMENTS
.
  
<EOS>
other

.
<EOS>

;

have

"

.

"
 
<EOS>
--dure

.
 
<EOS>
the
garden
at
Hoghton
Tower
,
though
necessarily
confine

,
owe
to

,

,

.
<EOS>

Darwen
,

,

.
<EOS>
the

constitute

,

be

,

,
into

,

.
<EOS>

--

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

--

.
<EOS>
besides

knot
,

be
term

be
labyrinth
,
and
clip
yew

,

that

,

.
<EOS>
in

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

;

,

,

her
upon

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

;

have

.
<EOS>
James
loll

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

's

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

'

]
 
<EOS>

Weel

,

,

.

.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XI.--FATALITY
.
  
<EOS>
along
the
eastern
terrace
a
youth
and
maiden
be
pace
slowly
.
<EOS>
They
have
steal
forth
unperceived
from
the
revel
,
and
,
pass
through
a
door
stand
invitingly
open
,
have
enter
the
garden
.
<EOS>
though
overjoy
in
each
other
's
presence
,
the
solemn
beauty
of
the
night
,
so
powerful
in
its
contrast
to
the
riotous
scene
they
have
just
quit
,
profoundly
impress
them
.
<EOS>
above
,
be
the
deep
serene
heaven
,
light
up
by
the
starry
host
and
their
radiant
queen
--
below
,
the
immemorial
wood
,
steep
in
silvery
mist
arise
from
the
stream
flow
past
them
.
<EOS>
all
nature
be
hush
in
holy
rest
.
<EOS>
in
opposition
to
the
flood
of
soft
light
emanate
from
the
lovely
planet
overhead
,
and
which
turn
all
it
fall
on
,
whether
tree
,
or
tower
,
or
stream
,
to
beauty
,
be
the
artificial
glare
cause
by
the
torch
near
the
pavilion
;
while
the
discordant
sound
occasion
by
the
minstrel
tune
their
instrument
,
disturb
the
repose
.
<EOS>
as
they
go
on
,
however
,
these
sound
be
lose
in
the
distance
,
and
the
glare
of
the
torch
be
exclude
by
intervene
tree
.
<EOS>
then
the
moon
look
down
lovingly
upon
them
,
and
the
only
music
that
reach
their
ear
arise
from
the
nightingale
.
<EOS>
after
a
pause
,
they
walk
on
again
,
hand
-
in
-
hand
,
gaze
at
each
other
,
at
the
glorious
heavens
,
and
drink
in
the
thrill

of
the
songster
of
the
grove
.
 
<EOS>
at
the
angle
of
the
terrace
be
a
small
arbour
place
in
the
midst
of
a
bosquet
,
and
they
sit
down
within

.
<EOS>
then
,
and
not
till
then
,
do
their
thought
find
vent
in
word
.
<EOS>
forget
the
sorrow
they
have
endure
,
and
the
peril
by
which
they
be
environ
,
they
find
in
their
deep
mutual
love
a
shield
against
the
sharp
arrow
of
fate
.
<EOS>
in
low
gentle
accent
they
breathe
their
passion
,
solemnly
plight
their
faith
before
all
-
see
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
poor
soul
!
<EOS>
they
be
happy
then
--
intensely
happy
.
<EOS>
alas
!
<EOS>
that
their
happiness
should
be
so
short
;
for
those
few
moment
of
bliss
,
steal
from
a
waste
of
tear
,
be
all
that
be
allow
them
.
<EOS>
inexorable
fate
still
dog
their
footstep
.
 
<EOS>
amidst
the
bosquet
stand
a
listener
to
their
converse
--
a
little
girl
with
high

and
sharp
feature
,
on
which
diabolical
malice
be
stamp
.
<EOS>
two
yellow
eye
glisten
through
the
leave
beside
her
,
mark

of
a
cat
.
<EOS>
as

breathe
their
vow
,
and
indulge
in
hope
never
to
be

,
the

child
grin
,

,
and
,

short
-
live

,
seem

.
<EOS>
some
strong

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
what
be

pair
talking
of
now?--She
hear
<EOS>
her
own
name
mention

,

of

,
almost

--
pardon

have
do

,

.
<EOS>
but

's

,

must
have

.
 
<EOS>

little
girl
,
however
,
feel

.
<EOS>
infernal

have
take

of

,
and

.
<EOS>
She
hate
all

that
compassionate

,
and
return
evil
for

.
 
<EOS>
what
be
the
lover
talk
of
now
?
<EOS>
of
their
first
meeting
at
Whalley
Abbey
,
when
one
be
May
Queen
,
and
by

other
's

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
wofully

.
<EOS>
alas
!
<EOS>
alas
!
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She
hope

will

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
past

be

by

,
and

_
be
_

.
<EOS>
go

--
go

!
 
<EOS>
but

be

,
for

wish

on
that

,
that

.
<EOS>
and

,
alight

,

,

.
<EOS>
They
praise
the

's

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
for
the
little
girl
,
full
of

,
stretch

her

,
and
it
drop
to

,
as
if

.
 
<EOS>
"
be
thy
heart

,
poor

?
"

man
,
take

hapless

,
yet

and

.
"
<EOS>
to
die
in

thy

hard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
very
hard
!
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Its

seem
a
type
of

.
"
 
<EOS>

girl
laugh
,
but

,
and
to

.
 
<EOS>
the

then
grow
sad
.
<EOS>
this

have
touch

deeply
,
and
their
conversation
take

.
<EOS>
They
speak
of
the
blight
that
have
nip

love
in

--

that
have

--
of

that
so

,
threaten

.
 
<EOS>

girl
laugh

.
 
<EOS>
then
they
speak
of
the
grave
--
and
of
hope
beyond
the
grave
;
and
they

.
 
<EOS>
the
little
girl
could
laugh
no
longer
,
for
with
her
all
beyond

grave
be
despair
.
 
<EOS>
after

speak
of
the
terrible
power
that
Satan
have
lately
obtain
in
that
unhappy
district
,
of
the
art
he
have
employ
,
and

he
have
win
.
<EOS>
both
pray

that
his
snare
may

circumvent
,
and

rule
destroy
.
 
<EOS>
during
this
part
of
the
discourse
the
cat
swell
to
the
size
of
a
tiger
,
and
his
eye
glow
like

.
<EOS>
He
make

as
if

would

,
but
the

of
prayer
arrest

,
and
he

back
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Jennet
be
ensnare
by

Fiend
,
"
murmur

,
"
and

perish

.
<EOS>
Would
I
could
save
her
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
,
"
reply

young
man
.
<EOS>
"
She
be
beyond
redemption
.
"
 
<EOS>
the

girl
gnash
her

rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
but
my
mother
--
I
do
not
now
<EOS>
despair
of
her
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
She
have
break

be
enchain
,

,

to

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
aid

!
"
<EOS>
exclaim
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
scarcely

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
why
,
tib!--where
be
yo
,
Tib
?
<EOS>
ey
want
yo
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
but

do

.
 
<EOS>
"
where
con
he
ha
'
go
?
"
<EOS>
cry

;
"
tib
!
tib
!
"
 
<EOS>
still

come

.
 
<EOS>
"
then
ey
mun
do
the
wark
without
him
,
"
pursue

little
girl
;
"
an
ey
win
no
longer
delay
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
and

she
creep

round
the
arbour
,
and
,
approach
the
side
where
Richard
sit
,
watch
an

of
touch
him
unperceived
.
 
<EOS>
as

come

,

shoot

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
be

ill
?
"
<EOS>
she

,

his
pallid
feature
,
render

white

.
 
<EOS>
Richard
could
make
no
reply
,
and
Alizon
,
become

,
be
about
to
fly
for

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
ey
mun
now
run
an
tell
Mester
Potts
,
so
that
hoo
may
be
find
wi
'
him
,
"
mutter
Jennet
,
creep
away
.
 
<EOS>
just
then
Richard
recover
his
speech
,
but
his
word
be
faintly
utter
,
and
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Alizon
,
"
he
say
,
"
I
will
not

from

.
<EOS>
I
be
die
.
<EOS>
and

will
be
attribute
to
you
--
for
evil
-

person
have

the
King
that
you
have
bewitch

,
and
he

the
charge
now
.
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
would

the

of

--
if
you
would
console
my
late
moment
--
leave
me
,
and
quit
this

,
before
it
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!
Richard
,
"
she
cry

;
"
you
ask
more
than
I
can
perform
.
<EOS>
if
you
be
indeed
in

,
I
will

with

--
will

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
!
live

--
live
--
save

,
Alizon
,
"
implore
the
young
man
.
"
<EOS>
Your
danger
be
great
than

.
<EOS>
a

death
await

at
the

!
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
mercy
,
mercy
,

!
<EOS>
spare
her
--
in
pity
<EOS>
spare
<EOS>
her!--have
<EOS>
we
not

?
<EOS>
I
can
no

.
<EOS>
farewell
for

,
Alizon
--
one
kiss
--
the
last
.
"
 
<EOS>
and
as
their
lip
meet
,
his
strength
utterly

,
and
he

backwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
one
grave
!
"
<EOS>
he
murmur
;
"
one
grave
,
alizon!"--and
<EOS>
so
,
without
a

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
Alizon
neither
scream
nor
swoon
,
but
remain
in
a
state
of

,
gaze
at
the
body
.
<EOS>
as

fall
upon
the

,
they
look
as
if
lock
in

.
 
<EOS>
there
he
lie
--
<EOS>
the
young
,
the
brave
,
the
beautiful
,
the
loving
,
the
beloved
.
<EOS>
fate
have
triumph
.
<EOS>
death
have
do
his
work
;
but
he
have
only
perform

.
 
<EOS>
"
one
grave
--
one
grave
<EOS>
--
it
be
his
last

--
it
shall
be

!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
,
in

,
"
I
shall
thus
escape
my

,
and
avoid
the
horrible

would
doom

.
"
 
<EOS>
and
she
snatch
the

from

ill
-

youth
's

.
 
<EOS>
"
now
,
fate
,
I
defy
thee
!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
one
last

at
that
calm
beautiful
face
--
one
kiss
of
the
cold
lip
,
which
can
no

return
the
endearment
--
and
<EOS>
the

be
point

.
 
<EOS>
but

be

by
an

,

.
<EOS>
She
look
up
.
<EOS>
a

,
clothe

of
a

,
stand

.
<EOS>
She
know
the

at
once
,
for
she
have
see
them
before
,
hang
up
in
the
closet
adjoin
her
mother
's
chamber
at
Whalley
Abbey
--
and
the
feature
of
the
ghostly
monk
seem
familiar

.
 
<EOS>
"
raise
not
thy

against

,
"

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
It
be
the

prompt
thee
to
do

.
<EOS>
He
would
take

of
thy

to

thee
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

thee
for

,
"
reply
Alizon
,
gaze
at
him
with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
who
art
thou
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
the
enemy
of
thy
enemy
,
and

,
"
reply

.
<EOS>
"
I

have
save
thy

if

,

be
not
to

avert
.
<EOS>
but
,
rest

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

--
I

,
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
wilt
soon

,
"

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
arise
,

.
<EOS>
thy

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My

!
<EOS>
"

,
clear

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
.
<EOS>
a

be
at

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
be

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
one
grave
--
lie
us

one
grave
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
do

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
and
he
glide

with

.
 
<EOS>
Alizon
follow
him
along
the

.
 
<EOS>
presently

come
to
a
dark
yew
-
tree
walk
,
lead
to
a

,
and
track
it
swiftly
,
as
well
as
the
overarched
and
intricate
path
to
which

conduct
,
they
enter

,
whence
a
flight
of
step
descend
to
a

passage
,
hew
out
of
the
rock
.
<EOS>
along
this
passage
,
which
be
of
some
extent
,
the
monk
proceed
,
and
Alizon
follow
him
.
 
<EOS>
at
last

come
to
another
flight

step
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
be
now
beneath

,
where

find

mother
,
"
he
say
.
<EOS>
"
Mount
!
<EOS>
the

clear
before

.
<EOS>
I

other

.
"
 
<EOS>
Alizon
obey
;
and
,

,
be

go
.
<EOS>
He
have
neither
pass

nor

step
,
and
must
,

,
have
sink
into

earth
.
    
<EOS>
chapter
XII.--THE
last
hour
.
  
<EOS>
within
the
pavilion
sit
Alice
Nutter
.
<EOS>
She
be
clothe
in
deep
mourning
,
but
her
dress
seem
disorder
as
if
by
hasty
travel
.
<EOS>
Her
look
be
full
of
anguish
and
terror
;
her
blanch
tress
,
once
so
dark
and
beautiful
,
hang
dishevel
over
her
shoulder
;
and
her
thin
hand
be
clasp
in
supplication
.
<EOS>
Her
cheek
be
ashy
pale
,
but
on
her
brow
be
a
bright
red
mark
,
as
if
trace
by
a
finger
dip
in
blood
.
 
<EOS>
a
lamp
be
burn
on
the
table
beside
her
.
<EOS>
near
it
be
a
skull
,
and
near
this
emblem
of
mortality
an
hourglass
,
run
fast
.
 
<EOS>
the
window
and
door
of
the
building
be
closed
,
and
it
would
seem
the
unhappy
lady
be
a
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
She
have
be
bring
there
secretly
that
night
,
with
what
intent
<EOS>
she
know
not
;
but
she
feel
sure
it
be
with
no
friendly
design
towards
herself
.
<EOS>
early
in
the
day
three
horseman
have
arrive
at
her
retreat
in
Pendle
Forest
,
and
without
make
any
charge
against
her
,
or
explain
whither
they
mean
to
take
her
,
or
indeed
answer
any
inquiry
,
have
bring
her
off
with
them
,
and
,
proceed
across
the
country
,
have
arrive
at
a
forester
's
hut
on
the
outskirt
of
Hoghton
Park
.
<EOS>
here
they
tarry
till
evening
,
place
her
in
a
room
by
herself
,
and
keep
strict
watch
over
her
;
and
when
the
shadow
of
night
fall
,
they
convey
her
through
the
wood
,
and
by
a
private
entrance
to
the
garden
of
the
Tower
,
and
with
equal
secresy
to
the
pavilion
,
where
,
set
a
lamp
before
her
,
they
leave
her
to
her
meditation
.
<EOS>
all
refuse
to
answer
her
inquiry
,
but
one
of
them
,
with
a
sinister
smile
,
place
the
hourglass
and
skull
beside
her
.
 
<EOS>
leave
alone
,
the
wretched
lady
vainly
seek
some
solution
of
the
enigma
--
why
she
have
be
bring
thither
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
solve
it
;
but
she
determine
,
if
her
capture
have
be
make
by
any
lawful
authority
,
to
confess
her
guilt
and
submit
to
condign
punishment
.
 
<EOS>
though
the
window
and
door
be
close
as
before
mention
,
sound
from
without
reach
her
,
and
she
hear
confused
and
tumultuous
noise
as
if
from
a
large
assemblage
.
<EOS>
for
what
purpose
be
they
meet
?
<EOS>
Could
it
be
for
her
execution
?
<EOS>
no
--
there
be
strain
of
music
,
and
burst
of
laughter
.
<EOS>
and
yet
she
have
hear
that
the
burning
of
a
witch
be
a
spectacle
in
which
the
populace
delight
--
that
they
look
upon
it
as
a
show
,
like
any
other
;
and
why
should
they
not
laugh
,
and
have
music
at
it
?
<EOS>
but
could
she
be
execute
without
trial
,
without
judgment
?
<EOS>
She
know
not
.
<EOS>
all
she
know
be
she
be
guilty
,
and
deserve
to
die
.
<EOS>
but
when
this
idea
take
possession
of
her
,
the
laughter
sound
in
her
ear
like
the
yell
of
demon
,
and
the
strain
like
the
fearful
harmony
she
have
hear
at
weird
sabbath
.
 
<EOS>
all
at
once
she
recollect
with
indescribable
terror
,
that
on
this
very
night
the
compact
she
have
enter
into
with
the
Fiend
expire
.
<EOS>
that
at
midnight
,
unless
by
her
penitence
and
prayer
she
have
work
out
her
salvation
,
he
could
claim
her
.
<EOS>
She
recollect
also
,
and
with
increase
uneasiness
,
that
the
man
who
have
set
the
hourglass
on
the
table
,
and
who
have
regard
her
with
a
sinister
smile
as
he
do
so
,
have
say
it
be
eleven
o'clock
!
<EOS>
Her
last
hour
then
have
arrive
--
nay
,
be
partly
spend
,
and
the
moment
be
pass
swiftly
by
.
 
<EOS>
the
agony
she
endure
at
this
thought
be
intense
.
<EOS>
She
feel
as
if
reason
be
forsake
her
,
and
,
but
for
her
determined
effort
to
resist
it
,
such
a
crisis
may
have
occur
.
<EOS>
but
she
know
that
her
eternal
welfare
depend
upon
the
preservation
of
her
mental
balance
,
and
she
strove
to
maintain
it
,
and
in
the
end
succeed
.
 
<EOS>
Her
gaze
be
fix
intently
on
the
hourglass
.
<EOS>
She
see
the
sand
trickle
silently
but
swiftly
down
,
like
a
current
of
life
-
blood
,
which
,
when
it
cease
,
life
would
cease
with
it
.
<EOS>
She
see
the
shine
grain
above
insensibly
diminish
in
quantity
,
and
,
as
if
she
could
arrest
her
destiny
by
the
act
,
she
seize
the
glass
,
and
would
have
turn
it
,
but
the
folly
of
the
proceeding
arrest
her
,
and
she
set
it
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
then
horrible
thought
come
upon
her
,
crush
her
and
overwhelm
her
,
and
she
feel
by
anticipation
all
the
torment
she
would
speedily
have
to
endure
.
<EOS>
ocean
of
fire
,
in
which
miserable
soul
be
for
ever
toss
,
roll
before
her
.
<EOS>
yell
,
such
as
no
human
anguish
can
produce
,
smote
her
ear
.
<EOS>
monster
of
frightful
form
yawn
to
devour
her
.
<EOS>
fiend
,
arm
with
terrible
implement
of
torture
,
such
as
the
wildest
imagination
can
not
paint
,
menace
her
.
<EOS>
all
hell
,
and
its
horror
,
be
there
,
its
dreadful
gulf
,
its
roaring
furnace
,
its
river
of
molten
metal
,
ever
burn
,
yet
never
consume
its
victim
.
<EOS>
a
hot
sulphureous
atmosphere
oppress
her
,
and
a
film
of
blood
dim
her
sight
.
 
<EOS>
She
endeavour
to
pray
,
but
her
tongue
clove
to
the
roof
of
her
mouth
.
<EOS>
She
look
about
for
her
Bible
,
but
it
have
be
leave
behind
when
she
be
take
from
her
retreat
.
<EOS>
She
have
no
safeguard
--
none
.
 
<EOS>
still
the
sand
run
on
.
 
<EOS>
new
agony
assail
her
.
<EOS>
Hell
be
before
her
again
,
but
in
a
new
form
,
and
with
new
torment
.
<EOS>
She
close
her
eye
.
<EOS>
She
shut
her
ear
.
<EOS>
but
she
see
it
still
,
and
hear
its
terrific
yell
.
 
<EOS>
again
she
consult
the
hourglass
.
<EOS>
the
sand
be
run
on
--
ever
diminish
.
 
<EOS>
new
torment
assail
her
.
<EOS>
She
think
of
all
she
love
most
on
earth
--
of
her
daughter
!
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
if
Alizon
be
near
her
,
she
may
pray
for
her
--
may
scare
away
these
frightful
vision
--
may
save
her
.
<EOS>
She
call
to
her
--
but
she
answer
not
.
<EOS>
no
,
she
be
utterly
abandon
of
God
and
man
,
and
must
perish
eternally
.
 
<EOS>
again
she
consult
the
hourglass
.
<EOS>
one
quarter
of
an
hour
be
all
that
remain
to
her
.
<EOS>
oh
!
that
she
could
employ
it
in
prayer
!
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
that
she
could
kneel
--
or
even
weep
!
 
<EOS>
a
large
mirror
hang
against
the
wall
,
and
she
be
draw
towards
it
by
an
irresistible
impulse
.
<EOS>
She
see
a
figure
within
it
--
but
she
do
not
know
herself
.
<EOS>
Can
that
cadaverous
object
,
with
the
white

,

-

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
CHAPTER
xiii.--the
masque
of
DEATH
.
  
<EOS>
short

have

,
James
be

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
James
then

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wha

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?

<EOS>
"

,

be

<EOS>
"

,
weel
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
enter
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wha
speak
?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

be

!

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
that
canna

<EOS>
the

o
'

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

'

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
CHAPTER

GRAVE
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

have

;

,

,

--

.
 
<EOS>
Nicholas
's

make

cousin
at

,

.
<EOS>

vow

,

,

;

.

,

.
<EOS>

;

,

,

.

Journal,[6
]
<EOS>
part

;

of

here
relate
,

.
<EOS>
He
die
in
1625
-
-at

.
 
<EOS>
but

go

.
<EOS>
a

,

be

.
<EOS>

--

--
<EOS>

,

upon
every
countenance
.
<EOS>
the
day
,
too
,
be
gloomy
.
<EOS>
the
feathered
summit
of
Whalley
Nab
be
wreathe
in
mist
,
and
a
fine
rain
descend
in
the
valley
.
<EOS>
the
Calder
look
dull
and
discolour
as
it
flow
past
the
wall
of
the
ancient
Abbey
.
<EOS>
the
church
bell
toll
mournfully
,
and
a
large
concourse
be
gather
in
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
not
far
from
one
of
the
three
crosse
of
Paulinus
,
which
stand
near
the
church
porch
,
a
grave
have
be
digge
,
and
almost
every
one
look
into
it
.
<EOS>
the
grave
,
it
be
say
,
be
intend
to
hold
two
coffin
.
<EOS>
soon
after
this
,
a
train
of
mourner
issue
from
the
ancient
Abbey
gateway
,
and
sure
enough
there
be
two
coffin
on
the
shoulder
of
the
bearer
;
They
be
meet
at
the
gate
by
Doctor
Ormerod
,
who
be
so
deeply
affected
as
scarcely
to
be
able
to
perform
the
needful
office
for
the
dead
.
<EOS>
the
principal
mourner
be
Sir
Richard
Assheton
of
Middleton
,
Sir
Ralph
Assheton
,
and
Nicholas
.
<EOS>
amid
the
tear
and
sobs
of
all
the
bystander
,
the
body
of
Richard
and
Alizon
be
commit
to
the
earth
--
lay
together
in
one
grave
.
 
<EOS>
thus
be
their
late
wish
fulfil
.
<EOS>
flower
grow
upon
the
turf
that
cover
them
,
and
there
be
the
early
primrose
see
,
and
the
late
violet
.
<EOS>
many
a
fond
youth
and
trust
maiden
have
visit
their
lowly
tomb
,
and
many
a
tear
,
fresh
from
the
heart
,
have
drop
upon
the
sod
cover
the
ill
-
fate
lover
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XV.--LANCASTER
CASTLE
.
  
<EOS>
behold
the
grim
and
giant
fabric
,
rebuild
and
strengthen
by
           
<EOS>
"
Old
John
of
Gaunt
,
time
-
honour'd
lancaster
!
"
 
<EOS>
within
one
of
its
turret
call
John
of
Gaunt
's
Chair
,
and
at
eventide
,
stand
a
lady
under
the
care
of
a
jailer
.
<EOS>
It
be
the
last
sunset
she
will
ever
see
--
the
last
time
she
will
look
upon
the
beauty
of
earth
;
for
she
be
a
prisoner
,
condemn
to
die
an
ignominious
and
terrible
death
,
and
her
execution
will
take
place
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
leave
her
alone
within
the
turret
,
the
jailer
lock
the
door
and
stand
outside
it
.
<EOS>
the
lady
cast
a
long
,
linger
look
around
.
<EOS>
all
nature
seem
so
beautiful
--
so
attractive
.
<EOS>
the
sunset
upon
the
broad
watery
sand
of
Morecambe
Bay
be
exquisite
in
varied
tint
.
<EOS>
the
fell
of
Furness
look
black
and
bold
,
and
the
winding
of
the
Lune
be
clearly
trace
out
.
<EOS>
but
she
cast
a
wistful
glance
towards
the
mountainous
ridge
of
Lancashire
,
and
fancy
she
can
detect
amongst
the
height
the
rounded
summit
of
Pendle
Hill
.
<EOS>
then
her
gaze
settle
upon
the
grey
old
town
beneath
her
,
and
,
as
her
glance
wander
over
it
<EOS>
,
certain
terrible
object
arrest
it
.
<EOS>
in
the
area
before
the
Castle
she
see
a
ring
of
tall
stake
.
<EOS>
She
know
well
their
purpose
,
and
count
them
.
<EOS>
They
be
thirteen
in
number
.
<EOS>
thirteen
wretched
being
be
to
be
burn
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
not
far
from
the
stake
be
an
enormous
pile
of
fagot
.
<EOS>
all
be
prepared
.
<EOS>
fascinate
by
the
sight
,
she
remain
gaze
at
the
place
of
execution
for
some
time
,
and
when
she
turn
,
she
behold
a
tall
dark
man
stand
beside
her
.
<EOS>
at
first
she
think
it
be
the
jailer
,
and
be
about
to
tell
the
man
she
be
ready
to
descend
to
her
cell
,
when
she
recognise
him
,
and
recoil
in
terror
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
here
--
again
!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
save
thee
from
the
stake
,
if
thou
wilt
,
Alice
Nutter
,
"
he
say
.
 
<EOS>
"
hence
!
<EOS>
"
she
exclaim
.
"
<EOS>
Thou
temptest
me
in
vain
.
<EOS>
hence
!
"
 
<EOS>
and
with
a
howl
of
rage
the
demon
disappear
.
 
<EOS>
convey
back
to
her
cell
,
situate
within
the
dread
Dungeon
Tower
<EOS>
,
Alice
Nutter
pass
the
whole
of
that
night
in
prayer
.
<EOS>
towards
four
o'clock
,
weary
out
,
she
drop
into
a
slumber
;
and
when
the
clergyman
,
from
whom
she
have
receive
spiritual
consolation
,
come
to
her
cell
,
he
find
her
still
sleep
,
but
with
a
sweet
smile
upon
her
lip
--
the
first
he
have
ever
beheld
there
.
 
<EOS>
unwilling
to
disturb
her
,
he
kneel
down
and
pray
by
her
side
.
<EOS>
at
length
the
jailer
come
,
and
the
executioner
's
aid
.
<EOS>
the
divine
then
lay
his
hand
upon
her
shoulder
,
and
she
instantly
arise
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
ready
,
"
she
say
,
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
have
a
happy
dream
,
daughter
,
"
he
observe
.
 
<EOS>
"
a
bless
dream
,
reverend
sir
,
"
she
reply
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
see
my
child
,
Richard
and
Alizon
,
in
a
fair
garden
--
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
how
angelic
they
look
--
and
they
tell
me
I
should
be
with
them
soon
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
and
I
doubt
not
the
vision
will
be
realise
,
"
reply
the
clergyman
.
<EOS>
"
Your
redemption
be
fully
work
out
,
and
your
salvation
,
I
trust
,
secure
.
<EOS>
and
now
you
must
prepare
for
your
last
trial
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
fully
prepared
,
"
she
reply
;
"
but
will
you
not
go
to
the
other
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
alas
!
<EOS>
my
dear
daughter
,
"
he
reply
,
"
they
all
,
except
Nance
Redferne
,
refuse
my
service
,
and
will
perish
in
their
iniquity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
then
go
to
her
,
<EOS>
sir
,
I
entreat
of
you
,
"
she
say
;
"
she
may
yet
be
save
.
<EOS>
but
what
of
Jennet
?
<EOS>
be
she
,
too
,
to
die
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
"
reply
the
divine
;
"
be
evidence
against
her
relative
,
her
life
be
spare
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
she
do
no
more
mischief
!
"
<EOS>
exclaim
Alice
Nutter
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
submit
herself
to
the
executioner
's
assistant
,
and
be
lead
forth
.
<EOS>
on
issue
into
the
open
air
a
change
come
over
her
,
and
such
an
exceed
faintness
that
she
have
to
be
support
.
<EOS>
She
be
lead
towards
the
stake
in
this
state
;
but
she
grow
fainter
and
fainter
,
and
at
last
fall
back
in
the
arm
of
the
man
that
support
her
.
<EOS>
still
they
carry
her
on
.
<EOS>
when
the
executioner
put
out
his
hand
to
receive
her
from
his
aid
,
she
be
find
to
be
quite
dead
.
<EOS>
nevertheless
,
he
tie
her
to
the
stake
,
and
her
body
be
consume
.
<EOS>
hundred
of
spectator
beheld
those
terrible
fire
,
and
exult
in
the
torment
of
the
miserable
sufferer
.
<EOS>
Their
shriek
and
blasphemy
be
terrific
,
and
the
place
resemble
a
hell
upon
earth
.
 
<EOS>
Jennet
escape
,
to
the
dismay
of
Master
Potts
,
who
fear
she
would
wreak
her
threaten
vengeance
upon
him
.
<EOS>
and
,
indeed
,
he
do
suffer
from
ache
and
cramp
,
which
he
attribute
to
her
;
but
which
be
more
reasonably
suppose
to
be
owe
to
rheum
catch
in
the
marsh
of
Pendle
Forest
.
<EOS>
He
have
,
however
,
the
pleasure
of
assist
at
her
execution
,
when
some
year
afterwards
retributive
justice
overtake
her
.
 
<EOS>
Jennet
be
the
last
of
the
Lancashire
Witches
.
<EOS>
ever
since
then
witchcraft
have
take
a
new
form
with
the
lady
of
the
county
--
though
their
fascination
and
spell
be
as
potent
as
ever
.
<EOS>
few
can
now
escape
them,--few
desire
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
but
to
all
who
be
afraid
of
a
bright
eye
and
a
bloom
cheek
,
and
who
desire
to
adhere
to
a
bachelor
's
condition
--
to
such
I
should
say
,
"
beware
of
the
lancashire
witches
!
"
  
<EOS>
the
end
.

M'CORQUODALE
and
CO
.

PRINTERS
,
LONDON
--
WORKS
,
NEWTON
.
